Abase.definition: To behave in a way that belittles or degrades someone; to lower in rank or prestige.
Abase.example: He was forced to abase himself before the king.

Abate.definition: To become less intense or widespread.
Abate.example: As the storm began to abate, we went outside to check for damage.

Abdicate.definition: To renounce one's throne, right, or power.
Abdicate.example: The king was forced to abdicate the throne after the scandal.

Aberration.definition: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
Aberration.example: The single poor grade on his report card was an aberration.

Abet.definition: To encourage or assist someone to do something wrong, in particular, to commit a crime.
Abet.example: He was found guilty of aiding and abetting the thief.

Abeyance.definition: A state of temporary disuse or suspension.
Abeyance.example: The project was held in abeyance until funding could be secured.

Abhor.definition: To regard with disgust and hatred.
Abhor.example: As a pacifist, I abhor violence in any form.

Abject.definition: Experienced or present to the maximum degree; completely without pride or dignity.
Abject.example: They lived in abject poverty after losing their home.

Abjure.definition: To solemnly renounce a belief, cause, or claim.
Abjure.example: He was forced to abjure his political beliefs to avoid persecution.

Abnegation.definition: The act of renouncing or rejecting something desired or valuable.
Abnegation.example: Her abnegation of rich food was an act of solidarity with the poor.

Abortive.definition: Failing to produce the intended result.
Abortive.example: The rebels' abortive attempt to overthrow the government was quickly suppressed.

Abridge.definition: To shorten a piece of writing without losing the sense.
Abridge.example: The editor's job was to abridge the long novel for a younger audience.

Abrogate.definition: To repeal or do away with a law, right, or formal agreement.
Abrogate.example: The treaty was abrogated by the new government.

Abscond.definition: To leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to avoid detection of or arrest for an unlawful action.
Abscond.example: The cashier absconded with the day's receipts.

Absolve.definition: To set or declare someone free from blame, guilt, or responsibility.
Absolve.example: The priest can absolve you of your sins.

Abstemious.definition: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking.
Abstemious.example: He lived an abstemious life, avoiding all luxuries.

Abstruse.example: The professor's lecture on quantum physics was too abstruse for most of the students.

Abut.definition: To be next to or have a common boundary with.
Abut.example: Their property abuts the new highway, which has decreased its value.

Abysmal.example: The team's performance this season has been abysmal.

Accede.definition: To agree to a demand, request, or treaty.
Accede.example: The management was unwilling to accede to the union's demands.

Acclivity.example: The steep acclivity of the hill made the hike challenging.

Accolade.definition: An award or privilege granted as a special honor or as an acknowledgment of merit.
Accolade.example: She received numerous accolades for her work in charity.

Accost.definition: To approach and address someone boldly or aggressively.
Accost.example: He was accosted by a stranger on the street asking for money.

Accretion.definition: The process of growth or increase, typically by the gradual accumulation of additional layers or matter.
Accretion.example: The accretion of cosmic dust over millions of years formed the planets.

Accrue.definition: To be received by someone in regular or increasing amounts over time (benefits or payments).
Accrue.example: Interest will accrue on the account at a rate of 5%.

Acerbic.definition: Sharp and forthright; tasting sour or bitter.
Acerbic.example: Her acerbic wit made her a formidable opponent in debates.

Acme.definition: The point at which someone or something is best, perfect, or most successful.
Acme.example: His career reached its acme when he was appointed CEO.

Acolyte.definition: A person assisting a priest in a religious service; a follower or assistant.
Acolyte.example: The famous designer was surrounded by her acolytes.

Acquiesce.definition: To accept something reluctantly but without protest.
Acquiesce.example: While I did not want to go to the party, I had to acquiesce because my friend insisted.

Acquisitive.definition: Excessively interested in acquiring money or material things.
Acquisitive.example: We live in an acquisitive society that is obsessed with consumer goods.

Acrid.definition: Having an irritatingly strong and unpleasant taste or smell.
Acrid.example: The acrid smoke from the burning tires filled the air.

Acrimonious.definition: Angry and bitter, typically of a speech or debate.
Acrimonious.example: The acrimonious divorce proceedings dragged on for months.

Acumen.definition: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions, typically in a particular domain.
Acumen.example: Her business acumen helped her build a successful company from scratch.

Adamant.definition: Refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
Adamant.example: She was adamant that she had not made a mistake.

Adduce.example: The lawyer will adduce several witnesses to support her client's case.

Admonish.definition: To warn or reprimand someone firmly.
Admonish.example: The teacher had to admonish the student for being disruptive in class.

Adroit.definition: Clever or skillful in using the hands or mind.
Adroit.example: He was an adroit negotiator, always getting the best deal.

Adulation.definition: Obsequious flattery; excessive admiration or praise.
Adulation.example: The rock star grew tired of the constant adulation from his fans.

Adulterate.definition: To render something poorer in quality by adding another substance.
Adulterate.example: It is illegal to adulterate food products with inferior ingredients.

Adumbrate.definition: To report or represent in outline; to foreshadow or symbolize.
Adumbrate.example: The director's early films adumbrate the themes of his later work.

Adventitious.definition: Happening or carried on according to chance rather than design or inherent nature.
Adventitious.example: The adventitious discovery of penicillin changed the course of medicine.

Aegis.definition: The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.
Aegis.example: The arts festival was held under the aegis of the city council.

Aesthetic.definition: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
Aesthetic.example: The minimalist aesthetic of the apartment was very calming.

Affable.definition: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
Affable.example: His affable personality made him popular with his colleagues.

Affectation.definition: Behavior, speech, or writing that is artificial and designed to impress.
Affectation.example: His French accent was just an affectation to seem more sophisticated.

Affidavit.definition: A written statement confirmed by oath or affirmation, for use as evidence in court.
Affidavit.example: The witness provided a signed affidavit detailing what she saw.

Affinity.definition: A spontaneous or natural liking or sympathy for someone or something.
Affinity.example: She has a natural affinity for animals and is training to be a veterinarian.

Affluence.definition: The state of having a great deal of money; wealth.
Affluence.example: The family's affluence was evident from their large house and expensive cars.

Affront.definition: An action or remark that causes outrage or offense.
Affront.example: His rude comment was a direct affront to the host.

Aggrandize.definition: To increase the power, status, or wealth of.
Aggrandize.example: The dictator sought to aggrandize himself by building enormous monuments.

Aggregate.definition: A whole formed by combining several separate elements; a sum total.
Aggregate.example: The aggregate score from all three judges determined the winner.

Aghast.example: She was aghast at the sight of the terrible accident.

Alacrity.example: She accepted the invitation with alacrity, eager for the new experience.

Albeit.example: He finally agreed to the plan, albeit reluctantly.

Allay.definition: To diminish or put at rest (fear, suspicion, or worry).
Allay.example: The government's statement was intended to allay public fears about the economy.

Allege.definition: To claim or assert that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically without proof.
Allege.example: The lawsuit alleges that the company engaged in fraudulent practices.

Allegory.definition: A story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically a moral or political one.
Allegory.example: George Orwell's 'Animal Farm' is an allegory for the Russian Revolution.

Alleviate.definition: To make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
Alleviate.example: The medication is designed to alleviate pain.

Allude.definition: To suggest or call attention to indirectly; hint at.
Allude.example: In his speech, he alluded to the recent scandal without mentioning any names.

Aloof.definition: Not friendly or forthcoming; cool and distant.
Aloof.example: He remained aloof from the noisy celebration, preferring his own company.

Altercation.definition: A noisy argument or disagreement, especially in public.
Altercation.example: The two drivers had a heated altercation after the minor collision.

Altruistic.definition: Showing a disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others; unselfish.
Altruistic.example: Her altruistic donation to the charity will help many people in need.

Amalgamate.definition: To combine or unite to form one organization or structure.
Amalgamate.example: The two smaller companies decided to amalgamate to better compete with larger corporations.

Ambiguous.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning.
Ambiguous.example: The politician gave an ambiguous answer to the reporter's direct question.

Ambivalent.definition: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
Ambivalent.example: She was ambivalent about moving to a new city; she was excited but also nervous.

Ameliorate.definition: To make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.
Ameliorate.example: The new policies are intended to ameliorate the working conditions for employees.

Amenable.definition: Open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded or controlled.
Amenable.example: He was amenable to the idea of a compromise.

Amenity.definition: A desirable or useful feature or facility of a building or place.
Amenity.example: The hotel's amenities include a swimming pool, a gym, and a spa.

Amiable.definition: Having or displaying a friendly and pleasant manner.
Amiable.example: The amiable host made everyone feel welcome at the party.

Amicable.definition: Characterized by friendliness and absence of discord.
Amicable.example: Despite their disagreements, they were able to reach an amicable settlement.

Amorphous.definition: Without a clearly defined shape or form.
Amorphous.example: The artist created an amorphous sculpture out of clay and wire.

Anachronism.definition: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists.
Anachronism.example: In today's digital world, a typewriter is an anachronism.

Analgesic.definition: Acting to relieve pain; a pain-killing drug or medicine.
Analgesic.example: The doctor prescribed a strong analgesic for the patient's post-surgery pain.

Analogous.definition: Comparable in certain respects, typically in a way that makes the nature of the things compared clearer.
Analogous.example: The structure of a human brain is analogous to that of a complex computer.

Anarchy.definition: A state of disorder due to absence or nonrecognition of authority.
Anarchy.example: The country descended into anarchy after the government collapsed.

Anathema.definition: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes; a formal curse by a pope or a council of the Church.
Anathema.example: Racial prejudice is anathema to our society's values.

Ancillary.definition: Providing necessary support to the primary activities or operation of an organization, institution, industry, or system.
Ancillary.example: The main business is software development, with ancillary services like training and support.

Anecdote.definition: A short and amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.
Anecdote.example: He told a humorous anecdote about his first day at work.

Animosity.example: There has been long-standing animosity between the two families.

Animus.definition: Hostility or ill feeling; motivation to do something.
Animus.example: His animus towards his rival was clear in his every action.

Anodyne.definition: Not likely to provoke dissent or offense; inoffensive, often deliberately so.
Anodyne.example: The politician's speech was anodyne and failed to inspire the crowd.

Anomalous.definition: Deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected.
Anomalous.example: The scientist was puzzled by the anomalous results of the experiment.

Antecedent.definition: A thing or event that existed before or logically precedes another.
Antecedent.example: The antecedents of the First World War are complex and varied.

Antediluvian.definition: Of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood; ridiculously old-fashioned.
Antediluvian.example: He has some antediluvian ideas about the role of women in society.

Antipathy.definition: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
Antipathy.example: She felt a strong antipathy towards her new boss.

Antithesis.definition: A person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
Antithesis.example: His charitable actions are the antithesis of his greedy reputation.

Apathy.definition: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
Apathy.example: There is widespread apathy among the electorate, leading to low voter turnout.

Aphorism.definition: A pithy observation that contains a general truth.
Aphorism.example: Benjamin Franklin was known for his aphorisms, such as 'a penny saved is a penny earned'.

Apocryphal.definition: Of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.
Apocryphal.example: The story about George Washington and the cherry tree is likely apocryphal.

Apostate.definition: A person who renounces a religious or political belief or principle.
Apostate.example: He was branded an apostate for questioning the party's core doctrines.

Appease.definition: To pacify or placate someone by acceding to their demands.
Appease.example: The government tried to appease the protesters with promises of reform.

Appellation.example: The city of Paris has earned the appellation 'The City of Light'.

Apposite.definition: Apt in the circumstances or in relation to something.
Apposite.example: His apposite remarks during the debate won him many supporters.

Apprise.example: Please apprise me of any changes to the schedule.

Approbation.example: The new policy was met with approbation from the public.

Appropriate.definition: To take something for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission.
Appropriate.example: The government was accused of appropriating private land for the new highway.

Arable.example: The valley has a large amount of arable land.

Arbiter.definition: A person who settles a dispute or has ultimate authority in a matter.
Arbiter.example: The court will act as the final arbiter in the dispute.

Arbitrary.definition: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
Arbitrary.example: The decision to fire him seemed completely arbitrary.

Arcane.definition: Understood by few; mysterious or secret.
Arcane.example: He was the only person who understood the arcane rules of the ancient game.

Archaic.example: The use of 'thou' and 'thee' is archaic in modern English.

Ardor.example: She spoke with great ardor about her love for classic literature.

Arduous.definition: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
Arduous.example: Climbing Mount Everest is an arduous and dangerous task.

Banal.definition: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
Banal.example: The movie's plot was so banal that I knew exactly how it would end.

Bane.definition: A cause of great distress or annoyance.
Bane.example: The constant traffic noise was the bane of his existence.

Bastion.definition: An institution, place, or person strongly defending or upholding particular principles, attitudes, or activities.
Bastion.example: The university was a bastion of academic freedom.

Beguile.definition: To charm or enchant someone, sometimes in a deceptive way.
Beguile.example: He beguiled the audience with his witty stories and charismatic personality.

Behemoth.definition: A huge or monstrous creature or thing.
Behemoth.example: The new shopping mall is a behemoth that covers three city blocks.

Beleaguer.definition: To lay siege to; to beset with difficulties.
Beleaguer.example: The beleaguered prime minister was facing criticism from all sides.

Belie.definition: To fail to give a true notion or impression of something; to disguise or contradict.
Belie.example: His calm demeanor belied the intense pressure he was under.

Bellicose.definition: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
Bellicose.example: The bellicose rhetoric of the politician raised fears of an impending war.

Belligerent.example: The belligerent man was shouting at the cashier over a minor mistake.

Benediction.definition: The utterance or bestowing of a blessing, especially at the end of a religious service.
Benediction.example: The priest offered a benediction for the congregation's health and happiness.

Beneficent.example: The beneficent donor funded the construction of the new hospital wing.

Benevolent.example: A benevolent stranger offered to help me with my heavy bags.

Benign.definition: Gentle and kindly; not harmful in effect.
Benign.example: Fortunately, the tumor was benign and posed no threat to his health.

Bequeath.definition: To pass (something) on or leave (something) to someone else.
Bequeath.example: He bequeathed his entire fortune to a charitable foundation.

Berate.definition: To scold or criticize someone angrily.
Berate.example: The coach would often berate his players for making careless mistakes.

Bereft.definition: Deprived of or lacking something, especially a nonmaterial asset.
Bereft.example: After his dog died, he felt completely bereft of joy.

Beseech.definition: To ask someone urgently and fervently to do something; implore.
Beseech.example: I beseech you to reconsider your decision for the sake of the team.

Besmirch.definition: To damage the reputation of (someone or something) in the opinion of others.
Besmirch.example: The scandal threatened to besmirch the good name of the company.

Bestow.definition: To confer or present an honor, right, or gift.
Bestow.example: The queen will bestow a knighthood upon the celebrated actor.

Bevy.definition: A large group of people or things of a particular kind.
Bevy.example: A bevy of reporters was waiting for the celebrity outside the courthouse.

Bibliophile.definition: A person who collects or has a great love of books.
Bibliophile.example: As a true bibliophile, his house was filled with floor-to-ceiling bookshelves.

Bifurcate.definition: To divide into two branches or forks.
Bifurcate.example: The path will bifurcate in about a mile; take the left fork to reach the lake.

Bilious.example: The critic's bilious review of the play was unnecessarily harsh.

Bilk.definition: To obtain or withhold money from someone by deceit or without justification; cheat or defraud.
Bilk.example: The con artist managed to bilk the elderly couple out of their life savings.

Blasphemy.definition: The act or offense of speaking sacrilegiously about God or sacred things.
Blasphemy.example: In the deeply religious community, his questioning of scripture was considered blasphemy.

Blatant.example: He told a blatant lie, but his friends were too polite to challenge him.

Blight.definition: A thing that spoils or damages something.
Blight.example: The abandoned, crumbling buildings were a blight on the otherwise beautiful neighborhood.

Blithe.definition: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper.
Blithe.example: She showed a blithe disregard for the rules, which eventually got her into trouble.

Boisterous.example: The boisterous laughter from the next room indicated the party was in full swing.

Bolster.definition: To support or strengthen; prop up.
Bolster.example: The new evidence will bolster the prosecution's case against the defendant.

Bombastic.definition: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
Bombastic.example: The politician's bombastic speech was full of promises but lacked any concrete plans.

Boorish.example: His boorish behavior at the dinner party embarrassed everyone.

Bourgeois.definition: Of or characteristic of the middle class, typically with reference to its perceived materialistic values.
Bourgeois.example: The artist rebelled against what he saw as the boring, bourgeois lifestyle of his parents.

Bovine.definition: Relating to cattle; of or like a cow or ox; sluggish, dull, and stolid.
Bovine.example: He stared at me with a dull, bovine expression on his face.

Brackish.definition: Slightly salty, as is the mixture of river water and seawater.
Brackish.example: The mangrove forest thrives in the brackish water of the estuary.

Brandish.definition: To wave or flourish something, especially a weapon, as a threat or in anger or excitement.
Brandish.example: The knight began to brandish his sword to intimidate his opponent.

Bravado.definition: A bold manner or a show of boldness intended to impress or intimidate.
Bravado.example: His bravado was just a cover for his deep-seated insecurity.

Brazen.example: She made a brazen attempt to cheat on the exam, right in front of the teacher.

Breach.definition: An act of breaking or failing to observe a law, agreement, or code of conduct.
Breach.example: Failing to deliver the goods on time was a clear breach of contract.

Brevity.definition: Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.
Brevity.example: For the sake of brevity, he omitted the minor details from his report.

Bristle.example: She would bristle at any suggestion that her work was not perfect.

Broach.definition: To raise a sensitive or difficult subject for discussion.
Broach.example: He was afraid to broach the subject of a salary increase with his boss.

Brook.definition: To tolerate or allow something, typically dissent or opposition.
Brook.example: The dictator would brook no criticism of his policies.

Bucolic.definition: Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life.
Bucolic.example: The painting depicted a bucolic scene of shepherds tending their flocks.

Bumptious.definition: Self-assertive or proud to an irritating degree.
Bumptious.example: The bumptious new intern acted as if he already ran the company.

Bungle.definition: To carry out a task clumsily or incompetently.
Bungle.example: They managed to bungle the simple task of assembling the furniture.

Buoy.definition: To cause to become cheerful or confident.
Buoy.example: The good news seemed to buoy her spirits after a difficult week.

Buoyant.example: Despite the setbacks, she remained buoyant and hopeful for the future.

Burgeon.definition: To begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
Burgeon.example: As the town's economy began to burgeon, new businesses sprang up everywhere.

Burlesque.definition: An absurd or comically exaggerated imitation of something; a parody.
Burlesque.example: The play was a burlesque of the classic tragedy, filled with slapstick humor.

Burnish.definition: To polish something, especially metal, by rubbing; to enhance or perfect something.
Burnish.example: He needed to burnish his reputation after the public relations disaster.

Buttress.definition: To provide a building or structure with support or reinforcement.
Buttress.example: The attorney used expert testimony to buttress his argument.

Bygone.example: She longed for the simplicity of a bygone era.

Byzantine.definition: Excessively complicated, and typically involving a great deal of administrative detail.
Byzantine.example: Navigating the company's byzantine approval process required weeks of paperwork.

Baleful.example: He gave me a baleful look that sent a shiver down my spine.

Balk.definition: To hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking.
Balk.example: The investors balked at the high price of the startup.

Banalize.definition: To make something so familiar that it seems trite and boring.
Banalize.example: The constant media coverage threatened to banalize the tragedy.

Bandied.definition: Passed from one to another or back and forth; discussed lightly.
Bandied.example: Rumors about the CEO's resignation were bandied about the office.

Banter.definition: The playful and friendly exchange of teasing remarks.
Banter.example: The lighthearted banter between the two colleagues made the office a more pleasant place.

Barb.example: His last comment was a cruel barb intended to wound her.

Baroque.definition: Highly ornate and extravagant in style.
Baroque.example: The palace was decorated in a baroque style, with gilded ceilings and elaborate carvings.

Barrage.definition: A concentrated outpouring, as of questions or blows.
Barrage.example: The press secretary faced a barrage of questions from the reporters.

Bauble.definition: A small, showy trinket or decoration.
Bauble.example: The market stall was filled with cheap baubles and souvenirs.

Bawdy.definition: Dealing with sexual matters in a comical and humorous way; humorously indecent.
Bawdy.example: The play was famous for its bawdy humor and clever wordplay.

Beatific.example: She had a beatific smile on her face as she watched her children play.

Bedlam.definition: A scene of uproar and confusion.
Bedlam.example: When the fire alarm went off, the crowded theater descended into bedlam.

Befuddle.definition: To make someone unable to think clearly.
Befuddle.example: The complex instructions served only to befuddle the new employees.

Begrudge.definition: To envy someone the possession or enjoyment of something.
Begrudge.example: I don't begrudge him his success; he has worked very hard for it.

Belabor.definition: To argue or elaborate a subject in excessive detail.
Belabor.example: There is no need to belabor the point; we all understand the situation.

Bellwether.definition: One that takes the lead or initiative; an indicator of trends.
Bellwether.example: The small town's election results are often seen as a bellwether for the national outcome.

Bemoan.definition: To express discontent or sorrow over something.
Bemoan.example: He would often bemoan the decline of traditional values.

Bemused.example: She looked at the abstract painting with a bemused expression.

Benison.example: The old woman's benison was a comfort to the young traveler.

Betoken.definition: To be a sign of; to indicate.
Betoken.example: The dark clouds betoken an approaching storm.

Bewail.definition: To express great regret, disappointment, or bitterness over something.
Bewail.example: The citizens bewail the loss of their historic library to the fire.

Bigotry.definition: Intolerance toward those who hold different opinions from oneself.
Bigotry.example: The community organized a protest to speak out against bigotry and hate.

Bivouac.definition: A temporary camp without tents or cover, used especially by soldiers or mountaineers.
Bivouac.example: The climbers made a bivouac on the narrow ledge for the night.

Blandish.definition: To coax someone with kind words or flattery.
Blandish.example: He tried to blandish his boss into giving him a promotion.

Blase.definition: Unimpressed or indifferent to something because one has experienced or seen it so often before.
Blase.example: After traveling the world, he was blase about the prospect of another trip.

Bloviate.definition: To talk at length, especially in an inflated or empty way.
Bloviate.example: The senator would often bloviate for hours, saying very little of substance.

Bohemian.definition: A person who has informal and unconventional social habits, especially an artist or writer.
Bohemian.example: She lived a bohemian lifestyle, moving from city to city and creating art.

Bonhomie.example: The party was filled with a sense of bonhomie and good cheer.

Boondoggle.definition: Work or activity that is wasteful or pointless but gives the appearance of having value.
Boondoggle.example: The new government project was criticized as a billion-dollar boondoggle.

Braggadocio.example: His braggadocio was off-putting to those who valued humility.

Bravura.definition: Great technical skill and brilliance shown in a performance or activity.
Bravura.example: The pianist's performance was a display of sheer bravura.

Bromide.definition: A trite and unoriginal idea or remark, typically intended to soothe or placate.
Bromide.example: His speech was full of empty bromides, such as 'every cloud has a silver lining'.

Brusque.definition: Abrupt or offhand in speech or manner.
Brusque.example: His brusque reply made it clear he didn't want to continue the conversation.

Bulwark.definition: A defensive wall; a person or thing that acts as a defense.
Bulwark.example: The rule of law is a bulwark against tyranny.

Bureaucracy.definition: A system of government in which most of the important decisions are made by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
Bureaucracy.example: Getting a permit required navigating a complex and inefficient bureaucracy.

Bedizen.definition: To dress up or decorate gaudily.
Bedizen.example: The old actress would bedizen herself in cheap jewels and flashy clothes.

Befog.example: The technical jargon in the manual served only to befog the issue.

Besot.definition: To infatuate; to make dull or stupid.
Besot.example: He was so besotted with his new girlfriend that he ignored all his old friends.

Bete noire.definition: A person or thing that one particularly dislikes.
Bete noire.example: Public speaking was his bete noire, and he avoided it at all costs.

Bibliomania.definition: Passionate enthusiasm for collecting and possessing books.
Bibliomania.example: His bibliomania led him to spend his entire inheritance on rare first editions.

Bicameral.definition: Having two branches or chambers, as a legislative body.
Bicameral.example: The United States has a bicameral legislature, consisting of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

Biennial.example: The international art exhibition is a biennial event.

Bipedal.definition: Using only two legs for walking.
Bipedal.example: Humans are bipedal creatures, which frees our hands for using tools.

Bluster.definition: To talk in a loud, aggressive, or indignant way with little effect.
Bluster.example: He tends to bluster when he's challenged, but he rarely follows through on his threats.

Bode.definition: To be an omen of a particular outcome.
Bode.example: The recent drop in sales does not bode well for the company's future.

Bogus.example: He was arrested for selling bogus concert tickets to unsuspecting fans.

Cabal.definition: A secret political clique or faction.
Cabal.example: A cabal of dissidents was plotting to overthrow the government.

Cache.definition: A collection of items of the same type stored in a hidden or inaccessible place.
Cache.example: The squirrel had a cache of nuts hidden for the winter.

Cacography.example: The teacher despaired at the student's cacography, which made his essays nearly illegible.

Cacophony.definition: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
Cacophony.example: The cacophony of car horns and shouting people filled the city street.

Cadge.definition: To ask for or obtain something to which one is not strictly entitled.
Cadge.example: He was known to cadge money and cigarettes from his friends.

Cajole.definition: To persuade someone to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery.
Cajole.example: She cajoled her friend into helping her with the difficult assignment.

Callow.definition: Inexperienced and immature, especially of a young person.
Callow.example: The callow intern made several mistakes during his first week on the job.

Calumny.definition: The making of false and defamatory statements to damage someone's reputation; slander.
Calumny.example: The politician was a victim of calumny, as his opponents spread lies about his past.

Canard.example: The rumor about the CEO's resignation was a canard started by a rival company.

Candor.definition: The quality of being open and honest; frankness.
Candor.example: I appreciated her candor in admitting that she had made a mistake.

Canon.definition: A general law, rule, principle, or criterion by which something is judged.
Canon.example: The works of Shakespeare are part of the literary canon of Western civilization.

Cant.definition: Hypocritical and sanctimonious talk, typically of a moral, religious, or political nature.
Cant.example: The politician's speech was full of cant about family values, yet he was known for his infidelity.

Cantankerous.example: My cantankerous neighbor complains about everything I do.

Capacious.definition: Having a lot of space inside; roomy.
Capacious.example: She carried a capacious handbag that seemed to hold an endless supply of items.

Capitulate.definition: To cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; to surrender.
Capitulate.example: After weeks of protest, the university administration finally capitulated to the students' demands.

Capricious.definition: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
Capricious.example: The capricious weather made it difficult to plan the outdoor wedding.

Captious.definition: Tending to find fault or raise petty objections.
Captious.example: The captious critic found fault with every aspect of the play, from the acting to the lighting.

Castigate.example: The coach castigated the team for their lackluster performance.

Catharsis.definition: The process of releasing, and thereby providing relief from, strong or repressed emotions.
Catharsis.example: Crying can be a catharsis for releasing pent-up sadness.

Caustic.definition: Sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
Caustic.example: His caustic remarks about her dress were hurtful and unnecessary.

Celerity.example: The cheetah is known for its celerity in chasing down prey.

Censure.definition: To express severe disapproval of someone or something, typically in a formal statement.
Censure.example: The senator was censured for his unethical behavior.

Cerebral.definition: Intellectual rather than emotional or physical.
Cerebral.example: Chess is a cerebral game that requires deep concentration and strategy.

Cerebration.definition: The action of thinking; a thought.
Cerebration.example: Deep cerebration was required to solve the complex philosophical problem.

Chagrin.definition: Distress or embarrassment at having failed or been humiliated.
Chagrin.example: To his chagrin, he realized he had forgotten his lines in the middle of the play.

Charlatan.definition: A person falsely claiming to have a special knowledge or skill; a fraud.
Charlatan.example: The so-called psychic was exposed as a charlatan who preyed on vulnerable people.

Chary.definition: Cautiously or suspiciously reluctant to do something.
Chary.example: She was chary of investing her money in the risky new venture.

Chasten.definition: To have a restraining or moderating effect on; to discipline.
Chasten.example: The near-death experience chastened him and made him appreciate life more.

Chauvinist.definition: A person displaying aggressive or exaggerated patriotism or belief in the superiority of their own group.
Chauvinist.example: His chauvinist attitude made it difficult for him to work with women as equals.

Chicanery.definition: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.
Chicanery.example: The company used financial chicanery to hide its losses from investors.

Chimerical.definition: Hoped for but illusory or impossible to achieve.
Chimerical.example: His chimerical dream of becoming a rock star never materialized.

Choleric.example: The choleric old man shouted at anyone who dared to walk on his lawn.

Circuitous.definition: Longer than the most direct way; indirect.
Circuitous.example: We took a circuitous route to avoid the traffic on the main highway.

Circumlocution.definition: The use of many words where fewer would do, especially in a deliberate attempt to be vague or evasive.
Circumlocution.example: The politician's speech was full of circumlocution, and he never gave a direct answer to the question.

Circumspect.definition: Wary and unwilling to take risks; cautious.
Circumspect.example: A wise investor is circumspect about where they put their money.

Circumvent.definition: To find a way around an obstacle or rule.
Circumvent.example: He found a way to circumvent the security system and enter the building.

Clandestine.definition: Kept secret or done secretively, especially because it is illicit.
Clandestine.example: The two spies arranged a clandestine meeting in the park.

Clemency.example: The prisoner was granted clemency by the governor and released from jail.

Coalesce.definition: To come together and form one mass or whole.
Coalesce.example: The small rebel groups coalesced into a unified army.

Coda.definition: A concluding event, remark, or section.
Coda.example: The final chapter of the book served as a coda to the main story, wrapping up loose ends.

Coerce.definition: To persuade an unwilling person to do something by using force or threats.
Coerce.example: The suspect claimed he was coerced into confessing to the crime.

Cogent.definition: Clear, logical, and convincing (of an argument or case).
Cogent.example: The lawyer presented a cogent argument that swayed the jury.

Cognizant.definition: Having knowledge or being aware of.
Cognizant.example: She was cognizant of the risks involved in the surgery.

Collusion.definition: Secret or illegal cooperation or conspiracy, especially to cheat or deceive others.
Collusion.example: The two companies were accused of collusion in fixing prices.

Commensurate.definition: Corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
Commensurate.example: His salary was commensurate with his experience and skills.

Compendium.definition: A collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject.
Compendium.example: The book is a compendium of knowledge about ancient civilizations.

Complacent.definition: Showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.
Complacent.example: After winning the championship, the team became complacent and lost their next game.

Complaisant.definition: Willing to please others; obliging and agreeable.
Complaisant.example: His complaisant nature made him popular, but also easily taken advantage of.

Complicit.definition: Involved with others in an illegal activity or wrongdoing.
Complicit.example: She was complicit in the cover-up, even though she didn't commit the crime herself.

Compunction.definition: A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that follows the doing of something bad.
Compunction.example: He felt no compunction about lying to get what he wanted.

Conciliatory.definition: Intended or likely to placate or pacify.
Conciliatory.example: She made a conciliatory gesture by offering to pay for the damage.

Concord.definition: Agreement or harmony between people or groups.
Concord.example: The two nations lived in concord for many years.

Condone.definition: To accept and allow behavior that is considered morally wrong or offensive to continue.
Condone.example: The school does not condone bullying in any form.

Conflagration.definition: An extensive fire which destroys a great deal of land or property.
Conflagration.example: The conflagration destroyed hundreds of homes in the forest.

Confluence.definition: The junction of two rivers; a coming together of people or things.
Confluence.example: The city is located at the confluence of the Missouri and Mississippi rivers.

Confound.definition: To cause surprise or confusion in someone, especially by acting against their expectations.
Confound.example: The magician's trick confounded the audience.

Congenial.definition: Pleasant because of a personality, qualities, or interests that are similar to one's own.
Congenial.example: He found a congenial group of friends who shared his love of music.

Congruity.definition: The quality of being in agreement or harmony.
Congruity.example: There was a lack of congruity between his words and his actions.

Connive.definition: To secretly allow something considered immoral or illegal to occur.
Connive.example: The guards were accused of conniving with the prisoners in their escape plan.

Connoisseur.definition: An expert judge in matters of taste.
Connoisseur.example: He was a connoisseur of fine wines and could identify a vintage by its aroma alone.

Consecrate.definition: To make or declare something sacred; to dedicate formally to a religious or divine purpose.
Consecrate.example: The new church was consecrated in a special ceremony.

Consternation.definition: Feelings of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected.
Consternation.example: The announcement of the company's bankruptcy was met with consternation by the employees.

Construe.definition: To interpret a word or action in a particular way.
Construe.example: His silence was construed as agreement.

Contentious.definition: Causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial.
Contentious.example: Abortion is a highly contentious issue in American politics.

Contiguous.example: The 48 contiguous states of the USA are all connected by land.

Contrite.definition: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt.
Contrite.example: The contrite student apologized for cheating on the exam.

Contrived.definition: Deliberately created rather than arising naturally or spontaneously.
Contrived.example: The movie's plot was contrived and unbelievable.

Contumacious.definition: Stubbornly or willfully disobedient to authority.
Contumacious.example: The contumacious defendant refused to answer the judge's questions.

Conundrum.definition: A confusing and difficult problem or question.
Conundrum.example: The question of how to solve the city's traffic problem is a real conundrum.

Convivial.definition: Friendly, lively, and enjoyable (of an atmosphere or event).
Convivial.example: The dinner party had a convivial atmosphere, and everyone had a great time.

Convoke.definition: To call together or summon an assembly or meeting.
Convoke.example: The president convoked a meeting of his top advisors to discuss the crisis.

Convoluted.definition: Extremely complex and difficult to follow (especially of an argument, story, or sentence).
Convoluted.example: The legal document was so convoluted that I couldn't understand it.

Copious.example: She took copious notes during the lecture to ensure she didn't miss anything.

Corpulent.definition: Fat; having a large, bulky body.
Corpulent.example: The corpulent man had difficulty fitting into the small chair.

Corroborate.definition: To confirm or give support to a statement, theory, or finding.
Corroborate.example: The witness's testimony corroborated the defendant's alibi.

Coruscate.example: The diamonds on her necklace seemed to coruscate under the ballroom lights.

Cosset.definition: To care for and protect in an overindulgent way.
Cosset.example: The wealthy parents cosseted their only child, who grew up spoiled and entitled.

Coterie.definition: A small group of people with shared interests or tastes, especially one that is exclusive.
Coterie.example: A coterie of artists and writers would meet at the cafe every week.

Countenance.definition: A person's face or facial expression; (as a verb) to admit as acceptable or possible.
Countenance.example: I could tell by his sad countenance that he had bad news; the school will not countenance cheating.

Countermand.definition: To revoke or cancel an order.
Countermand.example: The general countermanded the order to attack after new intelligence was received.

Countervail.definition: To oppose or exert a force against something with equal force; to counteract.
Countervail.example: The company's new marketing campaign was designed to countervail the negative publicity.

Covert.definition: Not openly acknowledged or displayed; secret.
Covert.example: The spy was involved in a covert operation to gather intelligence.

Covetous.definition: Having or showing a great desire to possess something belonging to someone else.
Covetous.example: He cast a covetous glance at his friend's new sports car.

Craven.example: The craven soldier deserted his post in the face of enemy fire.

Credence.definition: Belief in or acceptance of something as true.
Credence.example: I don't give any credence to the rumors I hear on the internet.

Credulity.definition: A tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true.
Credulity.example: The con artist took advantage of the old woman's credulity.

Credulous.definition: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things.
Credulous.example: Credulous people are often the victims of scams.

Crestfallen.example: He was crestfallen when he learned that he didn't get the job.

Cryptic.definition: Having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure.
Cryptic.example: He received a cryptic message that he couldn't decipher.

Culpable.example: The driver was found to be culpable for the accident.

Culmination.definition: The highest or climactic point of something, especially as attained after a long time.
Culmination.example: The culmination of her career was winning the Nobel Prize.

Cumbersome.definition: Large or heavy and therefore difficult to carry or use; unwieldy.
Cumbersome.example: The old computer was cumbersome and took up a lot of space on the desk.

Cupidity.example: The dictator's cupidity led him to plunder his country's wealth.

Curmudgeon.example: The old curmudgeon next door yelled at the children for playing in his yard.

Cursory.definition: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.
Cursory.example: He gave the report a cursory glance before signing it.

Curtail.definition: To reduce in extent or quantity; to impose a restriction on.
Curtail.example: We had to curtail our vacation due to a family emergency.

Cynical.definition: Believing that people are motivated by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity or integrity.
Cynical.example: His cynical view of the world made it hard for him to trust anyone.

Cynosure.definition: A person or thing that is the center of attention or admiration.
Cynosure.example: With her stunning gown and radiant smile, the bride was the cynosure of all eyes.

Dabble.definition: To take part in an activity in a casual or superficial way.
Dabble.example: He decided to dabble in painting, but he never took it seriously.

Daunt.definition: To make someone feel intimidated or apprehensive.
Daunt.example: The sheer scale of the project was enough to daunt even the most experienced engineer.

Dearth.definition: A scarcity or lack of something.
Dearth.example: There is a dearth of evidence to support his wild claims.

Debacle.definition: A sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco.
Debacle.example: The political campaign ended in a complete debacle after the candidate's controversial speech.

Debase.definition: To reduce something in quality or value; to degrade.
Debase.example: The dictator tried to debase the currency by printing more money.

Debauch.definition: To destroy or debase the moral purity of; to corrupt.
Debauch.example: He was accused of trying to debauch the youth of the nation with his radical ideas.

Debilitate.definition: To make someone weak and infirm.
Debilitate.example: The prolonged illness began to debilitate the old man.

Debonair.definition: Confident, stylish, and charming (typically used of a man).
Debonair.example: The debonair spy easily charmed his way into the exclusive party.

Debunk.definition: To expose the falseness or hollowness of a myth, idea, or belief.
Debunk.example: The scientist's research was able to debunk the popular theory.

Decadent.definition: Characterized by or reflecting a state of moral or cultural decline; luxuriously self-indulgent.
Decadent.example: The decadent lifestyle of the Roman emperors is well-documented.

Decimate.definition: To kill, destroy, or remove a large percentage or part of.
Decimate.example: The invasive species decimated the local bird population.

Decipher.definition: To convert a text written in code, or a coded signal, into normal language.
Decipher.example: It took the cryptographers years to decipher the enemy's code.

Declaim.definition: To utter or deliver words in a rhetorical or impassioned way, as if to an audience.
Declaim.example: The politician began to declaim against the evils of the new tax policy.

Declivity.example: The house was built on a sharp declivity, offering a stunning view of the valley below.

Decorum.definition: Behavior in keeping with good taste and propriety.
Decorum.example: He behaved with the utmost decorum at the formal dinner.

Decry.example: The activist group was quick to decry the company's harmful environmental practices.

Deduce.definition: To arrive at a fact or a conclusion by reasoning; to draw as a logical conclusion.
Deduce.example: From the evidence, the detective was able to deduce the identity of the culprit.

Defamation.definition: The action of damaging the good reputation of someone; slander or libel.
Defamation.example: The celebrity sued the tabloid for defamation of character.

Deference.example: He showed deference to his elders by listening quietly to their advice.

Defile.example: The vandals defiled the ancient monument with graffiti.

Definitive.definition: Done or reached decisively and with authority; conclusive.
Definitive.example: The Supreme Court's ruling was the definitive decision on the matter.

Defunct.example: The old, defunct railway station was now covered in weeds.

Deign.definition: To do something that one considers to be beneath one's dignity.
Deign.example: The queen did not deign to reply to the impertinent question.

Deleterious.example: The deleterious effects of smoking are well-known and widely documented.

Delineate.definition: To describe or portray something precisely.
Delineate.example: The report clearly delineates the steps needed to solve the problem.

Delude.definition: To impose a misleading belief upon someone; to deceive or fool.
Delude.example: He deluded himself into thinking he could pass the exam without studying.

Deluge.definition: A severe flood; a great quantity of something arriving at the same time.
Deluge.example: The office received a deluge of complaints after the system crashed.

Demagogue.definition: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices rather than by using rational argument.
Demagogue.example: The demagogue whipped the crowd into a frenzy with his fiery rhetoric.

Demur.definition: To raise doubts or objections or show reluctance.
Demur.example: She was too polite to demur to his suggestion, even though she disagreed.

Demure.definition: Reserved, modest, and shy (typically used of a woman).
Demure.example: With a demure smile, she accepted the award.

Denigrate.example: There is a tendency to denigrate the contributions of women in history.

Denizen.definition: An inhabitant or occupant of a particular place.
Denizen.example: The polar bear is a denizen of the Arctic.

Deplete.definition: To use up the supply or resources of.
Deplete.example: Overfishing has severely depleted the fish stocks in the area.

Deplore.definition: To feel or express strong disapproval of something.
Deplore.example: We deplore all acts of violence and terrorism.

Depose.definition: To remove from office suddenly and forcefully.
Depose.example: The military junta deposed the democratically elected president.

Depravity.example: He was a man of great depravity, known for his cruelty and vice.

Deprecate.definition: To express disapproval of; to belittle.
Deprecate.example: He always deprecates his own achievements, despite being very successful.

Derelict.definition: In a very poor condition as a result of disuse and neglect.
Derelict.example: The city has a plan to renovate the derelict warehouses by the waterfront.

Deride.definition: To express contempt for; to ridicule.
Deride.example: The other children derided him for his strange accent.

Derivative.definition: Imitative of the work of another person, and usually disapproved of for that reason.
Derivative.example: Her style of painting was considered derivative and unoriginal.

Derogatory.definition: Showing a critical or disrespectful attitude.
Derogatory.example: He made several derogatory comments about his opponent.

Desecrate.definition: To treat a sacred place or thing with violent disrespect.
Desecrate.example: The invaders desecrated the temple by looting its treasures.

Desiccate.definition: To remove the moisture from something; to cause to become completely dry.
Desiccate.example: The hot, arid wind will desiccate the land.

Desideratum.definition: Something that is needed or wanted.
Desideratum.example: A key desideratum for the new software was a user-friendly interface.

Desist.example: The judge ordered the company to desist from its deceptive advertising practices.

Despondent.definition: In low spirits from loss of hope or courage.
Despondent.example: She became despondent after failing the exam for the third time.

Despot.definition: A ruler or other person who holds absolute power, typically one who exercises it in a cruel or oppressive way.
Despot.example: The country was ruled by a cruel despot for decades.

Destitute.definition: Without the basic necessities of life.
Destitute.example: The long war left thousands of people destitute.

Desultory.definition: Lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm; occurring randomly or occasionally.
Desultory.example: He made a few desultory attempts at conversation but seemed distracted.

Deterrent.definition: A thing that discourages or is intended to discourage someone from doing something.
Deterrent.example: The threat of a large fine is a powerful deterrent to speeding.

Detrimental.example: Lack of sleep can be detrimental to your health.

Devoid.example: His speech was devoid of any emotion or passion.

Devout.definition: Having or showing deep religious feeling or commitment.
Devout.example: She was a devout Catholic who attended church every Sunday.

Dexterous.definition: Showing or having skill, especially with the hands.
Dexterous.example: The dexterous surgeon performed the delicate operation with ease.

Diabolical.definition: Characteristic of the Devil, or so evil as to be suggestive of the Devil.
Diabolical.example: The villain hatched a diabolical plan to take over the world.

Diaphanous.definition: Light, delicate, and translucent (especially of fabric).
Diaphanous.example: The bride wore a diaphanous veil that floated behind her.

Diatribe.definition: A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
Diatribe.example: He launched into a long diatribe against the government's policies.

Dichotomy.definition: A division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
Dichotomy.example: There is often a dichotomy between what politicians say and what they do.

Didactic.definition: Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
Didactic.example: The professor's didactic style of lecturing often bored the students.

Diffident.definition: Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence.
Diffident.example: He was diffident about expressing his opinion in front of his boss.

Diffuse.definition: To spread out over a large area; not concentrated.
Diffuse.example: The new technology helped to diffuse information across the globe.

Digress.definition: To leave the main subject temporarily in speech or writing.
Digress.example: The speaker tended to digress from his main points, making his lectures hard to follow.

Dilapidated.definition: In a state of disrepair or ruin as a result of age or neglect.
Dilapidated.example: They bought a dilapidated old farmhouse and spent years renovating it.

Dilatory.definition: Slow to act; intended to cause delay.
Dilatory.example: The government was accused of using dilatory tactics to avoid passing the bill.

Dilettante.definition: A person who cultivates an area of interest, such as the arts, without real commitment or knowledge.
Dilettante.example: He was a wealthy dilettante who dabbled in art but never produced anything of value.

Diligent.definition: Having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties.
Diligent.example: The diligent student spent hours in the library preparing for the exam.

Diminutive.example: She had a diminutive frame but a powerful voice.

Din.definition: A loud, unpleasant, and prolonged noise.
Din.example: The din from the construction site made it impossible to concentrate.

Dire.example: The country is in dire need of food and medical supplies.

Dirge.definition: A lament for the dead, especially one forming part of a funeral rite.
Dirge.example: The mournful dirge played by the piper brought tears to everyone's eyes.

Disabuse.definition: To persuade someone that an idea or belief is mistaken.
Disabuse.example: Let me disabuse you of the notion that this will be an easy task.

Disaffect.definition: To make someone dissatisfied or discontented, especially with people in authority.
Disaffect.example: The leader's broken promises began to disaffect his most loyal supporters.

Disavow.definition: To deny any responsibility or support for.
Disavow.example: The politician was quick to disavow the controversial statements made by his aide.

Discern.definition: To perceive or recognize something; to distinguish someone or something with difficulty by sight or with the other senses.
Discern.example: It was difficult to discern the truth from his web of lies.

Discomfit.definition: To make someone feel uneasy or embarrassed.
Discomfit.example: The reporter's aggressive questioning seemed to discomfit the mayor.

Disconcert.definition: To disturb the composure of; to unsettle.
Disconcert.example: The sudden change in plans was enough to disconcert everyone.

Disconsolate.example: The disconsolate widow mourned the loss of her husband.

Discordant.definition: Disagreeing or incongruous; (of sounds) harsh and jarring because of a lack of harmony.
Discordant.example: The discordant notes of the beginner's violin practice filled the house.

Discreet.definition: Careful and circumspect in one's speech or actions, especially in order to avoid causing offense or to gain an advantage.
Discreet.example: He was very discreet about his client's personal information.

Discrete.example: The process is broken down into a series of discrete steps.

Discretion.definition: The quality of behaving or speaking in such a way as to avoid causing offense or revealing private information.
Discretion.example: You can trust him; he is the soul of discretion.

Discursive.definition: Digressing from subject to subject; fluent and expansive.
Discursive.example: His discursive writing style made the book long but engaging.

Disdain.definition: The feeling that someone or something is unworthy of one's consideration or respect; contempt.
Disdain.example: She looked at the shabby apartment with disdain.

Disenfranchise.definition: To deprive someone of the right to vote or of a right or privilege.
Disenfranchise.example: New laws threatened to disenfranchise millions of poor and minority voters.

Disheveled.definition: Untidy; disordered (of a person's hair, clothes, or appearance).
Disheveled.example: He arrived at the meeting looking tired and disheveled.

Disingenuous.definition: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does.
Disingenuous.example: Her disingenuous claim of ignorance was not convincing.

Disparage.definition: To regard or represent as being of little worth.
Disparage.example: It is not fair to disparage his efforts when he tried his best.

Disparate.definition: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
Disparate.example: The study brought together a group of people from disparate backgrounds.

Dispassionate.definition: Not influenced by strong emotion, and so able to be rational and impartial.
Dispassionate.example: A judge must remain dispassionate when hearing a case.

Dispatch.definition: To send off to a destination or for a purpose; to deal with a task or opponent quickly and efficiently.
Dispatch.example: The company was able to dispatch the order within 24 hours.

Dispel.definition: To make a doubt, feeling, or belief disappear.
Dispel.example: A good explanation can dispel any confusion.

Dispensation.definition: Exemption from a rule or usual requirement.
Dispensation.example: He was granted a special dispensation to finish his thesis a semester late.

Disquieting.definition: Inducing feelings of anxiety or worry.
Disquieting.example: There was a disquieting silence in the house after the argument.

Dissemble.definition: To conceal one's true motives, feelings, or beliefs.
Dissemble.example: He tried to dissemble his fear with a show of bravado.

Disseminate.definition: To spread something, especially information, widely.
Disseminate.example: The organization's goal is to disseminate information about the disease.

Dissent.definition: The expression or holding of opinions at variance with those previously, commonly, or officially held.
Dissent.example: Two of the judges dissented from the majority opinion.

Dissident.definition: A person who opposes official policy, especially that of an authoritarian state.
Dissident.example: The political dissident was imprisoned for speaking out against the regime.

Dissipate.definition: To squander or fritter away money, energy, or resources; to disperse or scatter.
Dissipate.example: The morning mist began to dissipate as the sun rose higher.

Dissonance.definition: A lack of harmony among musical notes; a tension or clash resulting from the combination of two disharmonious elements.
Dissonance.example: The cognitive dissonance he felt between his beliefs and actions was profound.

Distend.definition: To swell or cause to swell by pressure from inside.
Distend.example: A diet high in gas-producing foods can cause the abdomen to distend.

Divisive.definition: Tending to cause disagreement or hostility between people.
Divisive.example: The issue of immigration has become a divisive topic in the country.

Docile.definition: Ready to accept control or instruction; submissive.
Docile.example: The normally docile dog suddenly became aggressive.

Doctrinaire.definition: Seeking to impose a doctrine in all circumstances without regard to practical considerations.
Doctrinaire.example: His doctrinaire approach to economics was not flexible enough for the real world.

Dogmatic.definition: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
Dogmatic.example: He was a dogmatic preacher who was not open to other interpretations.

Doleful.example: The doleful expression on her face told us the bad news.

Dour.definition: Relentlessly severe, stern, or gloomy in manner or appearance.
Dour.example: The dour old man rarely smiled or spoke to anyone.

Draconian.definition: Excessively harsh and severe (of laws or their application).
Draconian.example: The new draconian laws were met with widespread public protest.

Droll.definition: Curious or unusual in a way that provokes dry amusement.
Droll.example: His droll sense of humor was an acquired taste.

Dubious.definition: Hesitating or doubting; not to be relied upon; suspect.
Dubious.example: I was dubious about his chances of success from the very beginning.

Duplicity.example: He was accused of duplicity for promising one thing and doing another.

Ebullient.example: The ebullient crowd cheered for the winning team.

Eccentric.example: The eccentric old man wore a top hat and mismatched socks every day.

Eclectic.definition: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
Eclectic.example: Her home was filled with an eclectic collection of furniture from different eras.

Eclipse.definition: To obscure or block out; to surpass.
Eclipse.example: The new discovery threatened to eclipse all previous achievements in the field.

Efficacy.definition: The ability to produce a desired or intended result.
Efficacy.example: The efficacy of the new drug was confirmed through extensive clinical trials.

Effervescent.example: Her effervescent personality made her the life of every party.

Effete.definition: Affected, overrefined, and ineffectual; no longer capable of effective action.
Effete.example: The effete intellectual could not handle the rigors of manual labor.

Effrontery.example: He had the effrontery to challenge the professor's expertise on the subject.

Egalitarian.definition: Relating to or believing in the principle that all people are equal and deserve equal rights and opportunities.
Egalitarian.example: The country's new constitution was based on egalitarian principles.

Egregious.example: The company's egregious disregard for safety regulations led to a massive fine.

Elan.example: The dancers performed with great elan and captivated the audience.

Elicit.definition: To evoke or draw out a response, answer, or fact from someone.
Elicit.example: The detective's clever questioning was designed to elicit the truth from the suspect.

Elucidate.example: The professor used a diagram to elucidate the complex chemical process.

Elusive.definition: Difficult to find, catch, or achieve.
Elusive.example: The elusive concept of happiness is something philosophers have debated for centuries.

Emaciated.definition: Abnormally thin or weak, especially because of illness or a lack of food.
Emaciated.example: After weeks lost in the desert, the hiker was found alive but emaciated.

Emanate.definition: To issue or spread out from a source.
Emanate.example: A sense of calm seemed to emanate from the tranquil garden.

Emancipate.definition: To set free, especially from legal, social, or political restrictions.
Emancipate.example: The new law aimed to emancipate women from outdated and restrictive customs.

Embargo.definition: An official ban on trade or other commercial activity with a particular country.
Embargo.example: The government imposed an embargo on all goods from the hostile nation.

Embellish.definition: To make something more attractive by the addition of decorative details or features.
Embellish.example: He tended to embellish his stories to make them more exciting.

Embezzle.definition: To steal or misappropriate money placed in one's trust or belonging to an organization.
Embezzle.example: The accountant was caught trying to embezzle funds from his employer.

Embroil.definition: To involve someone deeply in an argument, conflict, or difficult situation.
Embroil.example: She became embroiled in a lengthy legal battle with her former business partner.

Emend.definition: To make corrections and improvements to a text.
Emend.example: The editor's job is to emend the manuscript before it goes to print.

Eminent.definition: Famous and respected within a particular sphere or profession.
Eminent.example: An eminent scientist was invited to give the keynote address at the conference.

Emollient.definition: Having the quality of softening or soothing; attempting to avoid confrontation.
Emollient.example: The diplomat's emollient tone helped to defuse the tense situation.

Empathy.definition: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another.
Empathy.example: A good therapist must have a great deal of empathy for their patients.

Empirical.definition: Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory.
Empirical.example: The scientist's conclusion was based on empirical evidence gathered from years of research.

Emulate.definition: To match or surpass a person or achievement, typically by imitation.
Emulate.example: Many young basketball players try to emulate their favorite NBA stars.

Enamor.definition: To be filled with a feeling of love for.
Enamor.example: He was completely enamored of the beautiful actress.

Encomium.definition: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.
Encomium.example: The retiring CEO received a heartfelt encomium from his successor.

Encroach.definition: To intrude on a person's territory or rights.
Encroach.example: The new development was criticized for encroaching on the protected wildlife area.

Encumber.definition: To restrict or burden in such a way that free action or movement is difficult.
Encumber.example: She was encumbered by a heavy backpack and struggled to climb the hill.

Endemic.definition: Regularly found among particular people or in a certain area.
Endemic.example: That particular species of frog is endemic to the Amazon rainforest.

Enervate.definition: To cause someone to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
Enervate.example: The relentless heat and humidity enervated the team of explorers.

Enfranchise.definition: To give the right to vote to.
Enfranchise.example: The new legislation was designed to enfranchise all citizens over the age of 18.

Engender.definition: To cause or give rise to a feeling, situation, or condition.
Engender.example: The government's new policies engendered a great deal of public debate.

Enigmatic.definition: Difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious.
Enigmatic.example: The artist's enigmatic smile in the self-portrait has puzzled critics for years.

Enjoin.definition: To instruct or urge someone to do something.
Enjoin.example: The judge enjoined the company to cease its illegal activities immediately.

Enmity.definition: The state or feeling of being actively opposed or hostile to someone or something.
Enmity.example: A deep-seated enmity existed between the two rival families.

Ennui.definition: A feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from a lack of occupation or excitement.
Ennui.example: Suffering from a sense of ennui, the bored aristocrat longed for adventure.

Enormity.definition: The great or extreme scale, seriousness, or extent of something perceived as bad or morally wrong.
Enormity.example: The world was shocked by the enormity of the crime.

Enthrall.definition: To capture the fascinated attention of.
Enthrall.example: The magician's performance was so captivating it seemed to enthrall the entire audience.

Ephemeral.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
Ephemeral.example: The beauty of the cherry blossoms is ephemeral, lasting only a few weeks each year.

Epicure.definition: A person who takes particular pleasure in fine food and drink.
Epicure.example: As a true epicure, he traveled the world to sample the finest cuisines.

Epigram.definition: A pithy saying or remark expressing an idea in a clever and amusing way.
Epigram.example: Oscar Wilde was famous for his witty epigrams, such as 'I can resist everything except temptation.'

Epiphany.definition: A moment of sudden revelation or insight.
Epiphany.example: While staring at the painting, she had an epiphany about the meaning of her own life.

Epistle.definition: A letter, especially a long or formal one.
Epistle.example: The apostle Paul wrote several epistles to the early Christian churches.

Epitome.definition: A person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type.
Epitome.example: With her grace and intelligence, she was the epitome of a modern leader.

Epitomize.definition: To be a perfect example of.
Epitomize.example: The new skyscraper seemed to epitomize the city's economic success.

Equanimity.definition: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
Equanimity.example: She faced the crisis with remarkable equanimity, never once panicking.

Equivocal.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
Equivocal.example: The politician gave an equivocal answer, leaving voters unsure of his true position.

Equivocate.definition: To use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself.
Equivocate.example: When asked about his involvement, the suspect began to equivocate and change the subject.

Eradicate.definition: To destroy completely; put an end to.
Eradicate.example: Scientists are working to eradicate diseases like polio and measles worldwide.

Errant.definition: Erring or straying from the proper course or standards.
Errant.example: An errant golf ball shattered the window of a nearby house.

Erratic.definition: Not even or regular in pattern or movement; unpredictable.
Erratic.example: His erratic behavior made it difficult for his friends to know how to help him.

Erudite.definition: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
Erudite.example: The erudite professor could speak at length on almost any historical topic.

Eschew.definition: To deliberately avoid using; abstain from.
Eschew.example: A devout vegan, she would eschew all animal products.

Esoteric.definition: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge.
Esoteric.example: The philosophy lecture was filled with esoteric concepts that were difficult for beginners to grasp.

Espouse.definition: To adopt or support a cause, belief, or way of life.
Espouse.example: The candidate espoused a platform of fiscal responsibility and social reform.

Esteem.definition: Respect and admiration for a person.
Esteem.example: She was held in high esteem by her colleagues for her integrity and hard work.

Estranged.definition: No longer close or affectionate to someone; alienated.
Estranged.example: After the bitter argument, the two brothers became estranged.

Ethereal.definition: Extremely delicate and light in a way that seems too perfect for this world.
Ethereal.example: The ballerina's ethereal grace made her seem as if she were floating across the stage.

Etymology.definition: The study of the origin of words and the way in which their meanings have changed.
Etymology.example: Studying etymology can provide deep insights into the history of a language.

Eulogy.definition: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone highly, typically someone who has just died.
Eulogy.example: He delivered a moving eulogy at his grandfather's funeral.

Euphemism.definition: A mild or indirect word substituted for one considered too harsh or blunt.
Euphemism.example: Saying someone 'passed away' is a common euphemism for 'died'.

Euphony.definition: The quality of being pleasing to the ear, especially through a harmonious combination of words.
Euphony.example: The poet's work was known for its perfect meter and euphony.

Euphoria.definition: A feeling or state of intense excitement and happiness.
Euphoria.example: She was in a state of euphoria after winning the championship.

Evanescent.definition: Soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
Evanescent.example: The evanescent morning mist vanished as the sun rose higher.

Evasive.definition: Tending to avoid commitment or self-revelation, especially by responding only indirectly.
Evasive.example: The politician was evasive when questioned about his campaign finances.

Evince.definition: To reveal the presence of a quality or feeling.
Evince.example: His grim expression evinced his deep disappointment.

Eviscerate.definition: To disembowel; to deprive something of its essential content.
Eviscerate.example: The critic's harsh review seemed to eviscerate the author's new novel.

Evoke.definition: To bring or recall to the conscious mind.
Evoke.example: The smell of cinnamon can evoke memories of winter holidays.

Exacerbate.definition: To make a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling worse.
Exacerbate.example: Pouring salt on the wound will only exacerbate the pain.

Exacting.definition: Making great demands on one's skill, attention, or other resources.
Exacting.example: The work of a brain surgeon is incredibly exacting and requires immense concentration.

Exalt.definition: To hold someone or something in very high regard; to praise.
Exalt.example: The community exalted the firefighter as a hero for his bravery.

Exasperate.definition: To irritate and frustrate someone intensely.
Exasperate.example: The constant delays began to exasperate the waiting passengers.

Exculpate.definition: To show or declare that someone is not guilty of wrongdoing.
Exculpate.example: The new evidence served to exculpate the defendant of all charges.

Execrable.example: The restaurant was shut down due to its execrable hygiene standards.

Exegesis.definition: Critical explanation or interpretation of a text, especially of scripture.
Exegesis.example: The scholar's exegesis of the ancient text revealed a new understanding of its meaning.

Exemplary.definition: Serving as a desirable model; representing the best of its kind.
Exemplary.example: Her exemplary performance in the classroom earned her a scholarship.

Exhort.definition: To strongly encourage or urge someone to do something.
Exhort.example: The coach exhorted his team to give their all in the final minutes of the game.

Exhume.definition: To dig out something buried, especially a corpse, from the ground.
Exhume.example: The authorities had to exhume the body to conduct a new autopsy.

Exigency.example: The exigencies of the wartime economy required strict rationing of supplies.

Exiguous.definition: Very small in size or amount.
Exiguous.example: He was forced to survive on an exiguous budget while studying abroad.

Exonerate.definition: To absolve someone from blame for a fault or wrongdoing.
Exonerate.example: The DNA evidence finally exonerated the man who had been wrongly convicted.

Exorbitant.definition: Of a price or amount charged, unreasonably high.
Exorbitant.example: The hotel charged an exorbitant price for a simple bottle of water.

Exorcise.definition: To drive out or attempt to drive out an evil spirit from a person or place.
Exorcise.example: She tried to exorcise the painful memories of her past through therapy.

Expansive.definition: Covering a wide area in terms of space or scope; extensive.
Expansive.example: The novel provides an expansive view of 19th-century Russian society.

Expatiate.definition: To speak or write at length or in detail.
Expatiate.example: The professor would often expatiate on her favorite philosophical theories.

Expatriate.definition: A person who lives outside their native country.
Expatriate.example: A community of American expatriates has formed in Paris.

Expedient.definition: Convenient and practical, although possibly improper or immoral.
Expedient.example: It was expedient to lie about his whereabouts, but it ultimately caused more trouble.

Expedite.definition: To make an action or process happen sooner or be accomplished more quickly.
Expedite.example: We paid an extra fee to expedite the shipping of our package.

Expiate.definition: To atone for guilt or sin.
Expiate.example: He tried to expiate his guilt by doing good deeds for the community.
