Explicate.definition: To analyze and develop an idea or principle in detail.
Explicate.example: The essay attempts to explicate the themes of alienation in modern literature.

Explicit.definition: Stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion or doubt.
Explicit.example: She gave explicit instructions on how to assemble the furniture.

Expunge.definition: To erase or remove completely something unwanted or unpleasant.
Expunge.example: The judge ordered that the minor's criminal record be expunged when he turned eighteen.

Expurgate.definition: To remove matter thought to be objectionable or unsuitable from a book or account.
Expurgate.example: The editor had to expurgate the novel to make it suitable for younger readers.

Extant.example: Several of Shakespeare's original manuscripts are still extant.

Extemporaneous.example: His extemporaneous speech was surprisingly eloquent and well-received.

Extenuate.definition: To make guilt or an offense seem less serious or more forgivable.
Extenuate.example: The defendant's lawyer argued that his client's difficult childhood should extenuate his crime.

Extirpate.definition: To root out and destroy completely.
Extirpate.example: The new government's primary goal was to extirpate corruption at all levels.

Extol.example: The critic extolled the virtues of the new film, calling it a masterpiece.

Extraneous.definition: Irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with.
Extraneous.example: Please stick to the main points and avoid any extraneous details.

Extrapolate.definition: To extend the application of a method or conclusion to an unknown situation by assuming that existing trends will continue.
Extrapolate.example: We can extrapolate future sales figures from the data of the past two years.

Extricate.definition: To free someone or something from a constraint or difficulty.
Extricate.example: The kitten was unable to extricate itself from the tangled yarn.

Extrinsic.definition: Not part of the essential nature of someone or something; coming or operating from outside.
Extrinsic.example: While he enjoyed his job, his primary motivation was extrinsic, driven by the high salary.

Exuberant.definition: Filled with or characterized by a lively energy and excitement.
Exuberant.example: The exuberant puppy jumped and licked everyone it met.

Exude.definition: To discharge or display an emotion or quality strongly and openly.
Exude.example: She seemed to exude confidence and charm wherever she went.

Exult.definition: To show or feel elation or jubilation, especially as the result of a success.
Exult.example: The team exulted in their victory after the final whistle blew.

Fabricate.definition: To invent or concoct something, typically with deceitful intent; to construct or manufacture.
Fabricate.example: The witness was accused of fabricating her testimony to protect the defendant.

Facet.definition: One side of something many-sided, especially of a cut gem; a particular aspect or feature of something.
Facet.example: The report examines every facet of the international trade agreement.

Facetious.definition: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor; flippant.
Facetious.example: His facetious remarks were not appreciated during the solemn ceremony.

Facile.definition: Appearing neat and comprehensive only by ignoring the true complexities of an issue; superficial.
Facile.example: The politician offered a facile solution to the complex problem of economic inequality.

Facsimile.definition: An exact copy, especially of written or printed material.
Facsimile.example: A facsimile of the original manuscript was displayed in the museum.

Faction.definition: A small, organized, dissenting group within a larger one, especially in politics.
Faction.example: A faction of the board of directors tried to oust the CEO.

Factious.definition: Relating or inclined to a state of faction; causing disagreement.
Factious.example: The factious council was unable to agree on a budget for the city.

Factitious.definition: Artificially created or developed; not genuine.
Factitious.example: The factitious friendliness of the sales staff was off-putting to customers.

Fallacious.definition: Based on a mistaken belief or unsound argument.
Fallacious.example: The idea that you can get rich quick is a fallacious notion.

Fallibility.definition: The tendency to make mistakes or be wrong.
Fallibility.example: The scientist was humble enough to admit the fallibility of her own research.

Fallow.definition: Plowed and harrowed but left unsown for a period in order to restore its fertility; inactive.
Fallow.example: The field lay fallow for a year to regain its nutrients.

Falter.definition: To lose strength or momentum; to speak or move in a hesitant, unsteady way.
Falter.example: Her voice began to falter as she told the emotional story.

Fanaticism.definition: The quality of being fanatical; excessive and single-minded zeal.
Fanaticism.example: The politician's speech was filled with a dangerous level of fanaticism.

Fanfare.definition: A short ceremonial tune or flourish played on brass instruments; a spectacular public display.
Fanfare.example: The new product was launched with great fanfare and a massive advertising campaign.

Farcical.definition: Relating to or resembling farce, especially because of absurd or ridiculous aspects.
Farcical.example: The trial descended into a farcical spectacle of accusations and counter-accusations.

Fastidious.definition: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail; very concerned about matters of cleanliness.
Fastidious.example: He was fastidious about his appearance, ensuring every hair was perfectly in place.

Fatalism.definition: The belief that all events are predetermined and therefore inevitable.
Fatalism.example: His fatalism led him to believe that there was no point in trying to change his circumstances.

Fathom.definition: To understand a difficult problem or an enigmatic person after much thought.
Fathom.example: I can't fathom why he would quit his job without another one lined up.

Fatuous.definition: Silly and pointless; complacently or inanely foolish.
Fatuous.example: The student's fatuous comments showed he hadn't understood the lecture at all.

Fawn.definition: To give a servile display of exaggerated flattery or affection, typically in order to gain favor.
Fawn.example: The courtiers would fawn over the king, hoping for a promotion.

Faze.example: The loud booing from the crowd didn't faze the experienced performer.

Fealty.definition: A feudal tenant's or vassal's sworn loyalty to a lord.
Fealty.example: The knights swore an oath of fealty to their queen.

Feasible.definition: Possible to do easily or conveniently.
Feasible.example: It is not feasible to finish the project by Friday with our current resources.

Feckless.definition: Lacking initiative or strength of character; irresponsible.
Feckless.example: The feckless manager was unable to motivate his team, and productivity plummeted.

Fecund.definition: Producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; fertile.
Fecund.example: The fecund soil of the valley produced a rich harvest year after year.

Feign.definition: To pretend to be affected by a feeling, state, or injury.
Feign.example: She would feign a headache to avoid attending the boring meetings.

Feint.definition: A deceptive or pretended blow, thrust, or other movement, especially in boxing or fencing.
Feint.example: The boxer made a feint with his left hand and then landed a solid right hook.

Felicitous.definition: Well chosen or suited to the circumstances; pleasing and fortunate.
Felicitous.example: Her felicitous choice of words made her speech both memorable and inspiring.

Felicity.definition: Intense happiness; the ability to find appropriate expression for one's thoughts.
Felicity.example: He expressed his admiration with great felicity of phrase.

Fell.definition: Of a terrible evil or ferocity; deadly.
Fell.example: The hero was determined to vanquish the fell dragon that terrorized the kingdom.

Feral.definition: In a wild state, especially after escape from captivity or domestication.
Feral.example: A pack of feral dogs roamed the outskirts of the abandoned city.

Ferocity.definition: The state or quality of being ferocious; savage fierceness.
Ferocity.example: The ferocity of the storm caught everyone by surprise.

Fervent.definition: Having or displaying a passionate intensity.
Fervent.example: He was a fervent supporter of the environmental movement.

Fervid.definition: Intensely enthusiastic or passionate, especially to an excessive degree.
Fervid.example: The candidate's fervid supporters would not tolerate any criticism of him.

Fervor.example: The crowd cheered with patriotic fervor during the national anthem.

Fester.definition: To become worse or more intense, especially through long-term neglect or indifference.
Fester.example: Resentment between the two families was left to fester for decades.

Fetid.example: The fetid smell of the stagnant water filled the air.

Fetter.definition: A chain or manacle used to restrain a prisoner; a restraint or check on someone's freedom.
Fetter.example: The new regulations were seen as a fetter on economic growth.

Fiasco.definition: A thing that is a complete failure, especially in a ludicrous or humiliating way.
Fiasco.example: The company's new product launch was a complete fiasco.

Fiat.definition: A formal authorization or proposition; a decree.
Fiat.example: The dictator ruled by fiat, issuing commands that were to be obeyed without question.

Fickle.definition: Changing frequently, especially as regards one's loyalties, interests, or affection.
Fickle.example: The fickle crowd, which had once adored the singer, now booed her off the stage.

Fidelity.definition: Faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief, demonstrated by continuing loyalty and support.
Fidelity.example: He prized fidelity in his friends above all other qualities.

Figment.definition: A thing that someone believes to be real but that exists only in their imagination.
Figment.example: The monster under the bed was just a figment of the child's imagination.

Filibuster.definition: An action such as a prolonged speech that obstructs progress in a legislative assembly.
Filibuster.example: The senator threatened a filibuster to prevent the bill from being passed.

Filial.definition: Of or due from a son or daughter.
Filial.example: She felt a strong sense of filial duty to care for her aging parents.

Finesse.definition: Intricate and refined delicacy; artful subtlety, typically that used for handling a difficult situation.
Finesse.example: The diplomat handled the sensitive negotiations with great finesse.

Finicky.definition: Fussy about one's needs or requirements; showing excessive attention to detail.
Finicky.example: My cat is a finicky eater and will only eat one specific brand of food.

Fissure.definition: A long, narrow opening or line of breakage made by cracking or splitting.
Fissure.example: A deep fissure had opened up in the rock face after the earthquake.

Fitful.definition: Active or occurring spasmodically or intermittently; not regular or steady.
Fitful.example: He had a fitful night's sleep, waking up every hour.

Flabbergasted.example: I was flabbergasted when I heard that he had won the lottery.

Flaccid.definition: Soft and hanging loosely or limply, especially so as to look or feel unpleasant; lacking force or effectiveness.
Flaccid.example: The once-strong political party had become a flaccid and ineffective organization.

Flag.definition: To become tired, weaker, or less enthusiastic.
Flag.example: After walking for hours, my energy began to flag.

Flagrant.example: It was a flagrant violation of the rules to cheat so openly.

Flaunt.definition: To display something ostentatiously, especially in order to provoke envy or admiration.
Flaunt.example: He constantly flaunted his new sports car around the neighborhood.

Fledgling.definition: A person or organization that is immature, inexperienced, or underdeveloped.
Fledgling.example: The fledgling company struggled to compete with established giants in the industry.

Fleeting.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
Fleeting.example: She caught a fleeting glimpse of the celebrity before he was whisked away by his security.

Flippant.definition: Not showing a serious or respectful attitude.
Flippant.example: His flippant response to the serious question angered the reporter.

Florid.definition: Having a red or flushed complexion; elaborately or excessively intricate or complicated.
Florid.example: The author's florid prose was filled with unnecessary adjectives and complex sentences.

Flotsam.definition: The wreckage of a ship or its cargo found floating on or washed up by the sea.
Flotsam.example: After the storm, the beach was littered with flotsam and jetsam.

Flout.definition: To openly disregard a rule, law, or convention.
Flout.example: Some companies flout environmental regulations to save money.

Flummox.definition: To perplex someone greatly; to bewilder.
Flummox.example: The unexpected question completely flummoxed the politician during the debate.

Flux.definition: The action or process of flowing or flowing out; continuous change.
Flux.example: The political situation is in a state of flux, with no clear outcome in sight.

Foible.definition: A minor weakness or eccentricity in someone's character.
Foible.example: We all have our little foibles; his is a tendency to talk to himself.

Foil.definition: To prevent something considered wrong or undesirable from succeeding.
Foil.example: The police managed to foil the bank robbery.

Foment.definition: To instigate or stir up an undesirable or violent course of action.
Foment.example: The agitator was accused of trying to foment rebellion among the workers.

Foppish.definition: Concerned with one's clothes and appearance in an affected and excessive way (typically used of a man).
Foppish.example: The foppish dandy spent hours choosing his outfit for the evening.

Forage.definition: To search widely for food or provisions.
Forage.example: The squirrels forage for nuts to store for the winter.

Forbearance.example: He showed great forbearance in dealing with the difficult customer.

Ford.definition: A shallow place in a river or stream allowing one to walk or drive across; to cross a river at such a place.
Ford.example: The pioneers had to ford the river with their wagons.

Foreboding.definition: A feeling that something bad will happen; fearful apprehension.
Foreboding.example: She had a sense of foreboding that the trip would not go well.

Forensic.definition: Relating to or denoting the application of scientific methods and techniques to the investigation of crime.
Forensic.example: The forensic evidence found at the scene was crucial to solving the case.

Forerunner.definition: A person or thing that precedes the coming or development of someone or something else; a precursor.
Forerunner.example: The abacus was a forerunner of the modern computer.

Foreshadow.definition: To be a warning or indication of a future event.
Foreshadow.example: The dark clouds seemed to foreshadow an impending storm.

Forestall.definition: To prevent or obstruct an anticipated event or action by taking action ahead of time.
Forestall.example: He bought the stocks to forestall a hostile takeover of the company.

Forfeit.definition: To lose or be deprived of property or a right or privilege as a penalty for wrongdoing.
Forfeit.example: If you cancel your ticket less than 24 hours in advance, you forfeit the entire fee.

Forgo.definition: To omit or decline to take something pleasant or valuable; to go without.
Forgo.example: To save money for the trip, she decided to forgo her daily coffee purchase.

Forlorn.definition: Pitifully sad and abandoned or lonely.
Forlorn.example: The forlorn puppy sat by the side of the road, waiting for its owner to return.

Formidable.definition: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable.
Formidable.example: The champion was a formidable opponent for the young challenger.

Forsake.definition: To abandon or leave someone or something.
Forsake.example: He promised never to forsake his friends in their time of need.

Forswear.definition: To agree to give up or do without something; to swear falsely.
Forswear.example: After his health scare, he decided to forswear all junk food.

Forte.definition: A thing at which someone excels.
Forte.example: While he was a decent writer, public speaking was his true forte.

Forthright.definition: Direct and outspoken; straightforward and honest.
Forthright.example: She was known for her forthright manner and always said exactly what she thought.

Fortitude.example: She endured the long illness with great fortitude.

Fortuitous.definition: Happening by accident or chance rather than design; happening by a lucky chance.
Fortuitous.example: Their fortuitous meeting at the conference led to a successful business partnership.

Foster.definition: To encourage or promote the development of something, typically something regarded as good.
Foster.example: The teacher's goal was to foster a love of reading in her students.

Founder.definition: To fill with water and sink (of a ship); to fail or break down, typically as a result of a particular problem.
Founder.example: The business venture began to founder after its main investor pulled out.

Fracas.example: The police were called to break up the fracas outside the bar.

Fractious.definition: Irritable and quarrelsome; difficult to control.
Fractious.example: The fractious child was always getting into arguments with his classmates.

Fraught.definition: Filled with or destined to result in something undesirable.
Fraught.example: The tense negotiation was fraught with danger and the possibility of failure.

Frenetic.definition: Fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way.
Frenetic.example: The day before the deadline was a scene of frenetic activity in the office.

Frivolous.definition: Not having any serious purpose or value; carefree and not serious.
Frivolous.example: The judge dismissed the lawsuit, calling it frivolous and a waste of the court's time.

Froward.definition: Difficult to deal with; contrary; habitually disposed to disobedience and opposition.
Froward.example: The froward student refused to follow any of the teacher's instructions.

Frugality.definition: The quality of being economical with money or food; thriftiness.
Frugality.example: Through years of frugality, she was able to save enough money to buy a house.

Fruition.definition: The point at which a plan or project is realized.
Fruition.example: After years of hard work, his ambitious plans finally came to fruition.

Fugacious.example: He was known for his fugacious memory, often forgetting names moments after hearing them.

Fulminate.definition: To express vehement protest; to explode violently or flash like lightning.
Fulminate.example: The columnist would often fulminate against the government's policies.

Fulsome.definition: Complimentary or flattering to an excessive degree; of large size or quantity.
Fulsome.example: The host's fulsome praise of the guest speaker made everyone in the audience uncomfortable.

Furtive.definition: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.
Furtive.example: She cast a furtive glance over her shoulder to see if she was being followed.

Fusillade.definition: A series of shots fired or missiles thrown all at the same time or in quick succession.
Fusillade.example: The reporters hit the politician with a fusillade of questions as soon as he left the building.

Futile.definition: Incapable of producing any useful result; pointless.
Futile.example: It is futile to argue with him once he has made up his mind.

Gaffe.definition: An unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment to its originator; a blunder.
Gaffe.example: He made a terrible gaffe when he asked about her ex-husband in front of her new one.

Gainsay.definition: To deny, contradict, or speak against; to oppose.
Gainsay.example: No one can gainsay the fact that she is the best student in the class.

Gall.example: He had the gall to ask for a raise after being late every day for a week.

Galvanize.definition: To shock or excite someone into taking action.
Galvanize.example: The impassioned speech galvanized the crowd into a frenzy of protest.

Gambit.definition: A device, action, or opening remark, typically one entailing a degree of risk, that is calculated to gain an advantage.
Gambit.example: His offer to take a pay cut was a strategic gambit to save the company.

Gambol.definition: To run or jump about playfully.
Gambol.example: The lambs gamboled in the green pasture.

Gamut.definition: The complete range or scope of something.
Gamut.example: The actress's performance ran the gamut of emotions from joy to despair.

Gargantuan.example: It took five people to move the gargantuan sofa into the living room.

Garish.definition: Obtrusively bright and showy; luridly colored.
Garish.example: The casino was decorated in a garish style with flashing lights and gold paint.

Garner.definition: To gather or collect something, especially information or approval.
Garner.example: Over the years, she has garnered a reputation for being a fair and honest leader.

Garrulous.definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
Garrulous.example: The garrulous old man held up the line as he told the cashier his life story.

Gauche.definition: Lacking ease or grace; unsophisticated and socially awkward.
Gauche.example: His gauche manners at the formal dinner made everyone uncomfortable.

Gauntlet.example: The new recruit had to run the gauntlet of initiation rituals.

Gavel.definition: A small mallet used by a judge or auctioneer to signal for attention or order.
Gavel.example: The judge banged her gavel on the desk to silence the courtroom.

Gawky.example: The gawky teenager tripped over his own feet as he walked onto the stage.

Gelid.example: We stared out at the gelid, unforgiving landscape of the arctic tundra.

Genealogy.definition: A line of descent traced continuously from an ancestor; the study of family ancestries.
Genealogy.example: He spent years researching his family's genealogy to create a complete family tree.

Generic.definition: Characteristic of or relating to a class or group of things; not specific.
Generic.example: She gave a generic answer that didn't really address the question.

Genesis.definition: The origin or mode of formation of something.
Genesis.example: The book details the genesis of the civil rights movement.

Genial.example: The host's genial manner made all the guests feel welcome.

Genre.definition: A category of artistic composition, characterized by similarities in form, style, or subject matter.
Genre.example: Science fiction is my favorite literary genre.

Genteel.definition: Polite, refined, or respectable, often in an affected or ostentatious way.
Genteel.example: The family lived a genteel life in their country estate, far from the city's chaos.

Gentry.definition: People of good social position, specifically the class of people next below the nobility.
Gentry.example: The local gentry were invited to the ball at the manor house.

Germane.definition: Relevant to a subject under consideration.
Germane.example: Please keep your comments germane to the topic we are discussing.

Germinate.definition: To begin to grow and put out shoots after a period of dormancy.
Germinate.example: The seeds will germinate in the spring if you plant them now.

Gesticulate.definition: To use gestures, especially dramatic ones, instead of speaking or to emphasize one's words.
Gesticulate.example: He gesticulated wildly to get the attention of the waiter across the crowded room.

Ghastly.definition: Causing great horror or fear; frightful or macabre.
Ghastly.example: The ghastly scene of the accident was something he would never forget.

Gibberish.definition: Unintelligible or meaningless speech or writing; nonsense.
Gibberish.example: After the anesthesia, he was speaking complete gibberish for an hour.

Gibe.definition: An insulting or mocking remark; a taunt.
Gibe.example: She ignored the gibes from her opponents and focused on her goal.

Gild.definition: To cover thinly with gold; to give a specious or deceptively attractive appearance to.
Gild.example: The politician tried to gild the bad news, but the public saw through the deception.

Gingerly.definition: In a careful or cautious manner.
Gingerly.example: She gingerly touched the hot pan to see if it had cooled down.

Girth.definition: The measurement around the middle of something, especially a person's waist.
Girth.example: The ancient oak tree was so large in girth that three people couldn't encircle it.

Gist.definition: The substance or essence of a speech or text.
Gist.example: I didn't read the whole report, but I got the gist of it.

Glacial.definition: Relating to ice; extremely cold or slow-moving.
Glacial.example: Progress on the project has been glacial, with deadlines repeatedly missed.

Glib.definition: Fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow.
Glib.example: His glib excuses for his tardiness were not convincing.

Glimmer.definition: A faint or wavering light; a faint sign of a feeling or quality.
Glimmer.example: There was a glimmer of hope that the missing hikers would be found.

Gloat.definition: To contemplate or dwell on one's own success or another's misfortune with smugness or malignant pleasure.
Gloat.example: It is not good sportsmanship to gloat over a victory.

Gloss.definition: To try to conceal or disguise something unfavorable by treating it briefly or representing it misleadingly (often used with 'over').
Gloss.example: The report tended to gloss over the company's financial problems.

Glower.definition: To have an angry or sullen look on one's face; to scowl.
Glower.example: He glowered at his rival across the boardroom table.

Glut.definition: An excessively abundant supply of something.
Glut.example: There is a glut of cheap apartments in the city, making it hard for landlords to find tenants.

Gluttony.definition: Habitual greed or excess in eating.
Gluttony.example: His gluttony was apparent in his inability to refuse a second or third helping of dessert.

Gnarled.definition: Knobbly, rough, and twisted, especially with age.
Gnarled.example: The old sailor's hands were gnarled from years of pulling ropes.

Goad.definition: To provoke or annoy someone so as to stimulate some action or reaction.
Goad.example: He was trying to goad her into an argument.

Gorge.definition: To eat a large amount greedily; to fill oneself with food.
Gorge.example: After fasting for a day, he wanted to gorge himself on pizza.

Gossamer.definition: Referring to something very light, thin, and insubstantial or delicate.
Gossamer.example: The bride's veil was made of a gossamer silk.

Gouge.example: The mechanic tried to gouge me for the repairs, charging twice the normal price.

Gourmand.definition: A person who enjoys eating and often eats too much; a connoisseur of good food.
Gourmand.example: He was a true gourmand, appreciating the finest wines and richest foods.

Gradation.definition: A scale or series of successive changes, stages, or degrees.
Gradation.example: The painting showed a beautiful gradation of colors from deep blue to pale yellow.

Grandiloquent.definition: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.
Grandiloquent.example: The politician's grandiloquent speech was full of fancy words but lacked any real substance.

Grandiose.definition: Impressive and imposing in appearance or style, especially pretentiously so.
Grandiose.example: He had grandiose plans for the company that were ultimately unrealistic.

Granular.definition: Resembling or consisting of small grains or particles; highly detailed.
Granular.example: The team needed a more granular breakdown of the data to understand the problem.

Grapple.definition: To engage in a close fight or struggle without weapons; to wrestle with a problem.
Grapple.example: The country continues to grapple with the issue of poverty.

Gratify.definition: To give someone pleasure or satisfaction.
Gratify.example: She was gratified to see the positive results of her hard work.

Gratis.example: The concert tickets were given to us gratis by the promoter.

Gratuitous.definition: Uncalled for; lacking good reason; unwarranted.
Gratuitous.example: The film was criticized for its gratuitous violence.

Gravity.example: The students did not understand the gravity of the situation until the principal arrived.

Gregarious.example: He was a gregarious and outgoing person who loved being the center of attention.

Grievance.definition: A real or imagined wrong or other cause for complaint or protest, especially unfair treatment.
Grievance.example: The employees filed a grievance with the union over the new work hours.

Grievous.definition: Very severe or serious (used to describe something bad).
Grievous.example: He made a grievous error in judgment that cost the company millions.

Grill.definition: To subject someone to intense questioning or interrogation.
Grill.example: The detectives grilled the suspect for hours about his whereabouts on the night of the crime.

Grimace.definition: An ugly, twisted expression on a person's face, typically expressing disgust, pain, or wry amusement.
Grimace.example: She made a grimace of pain as the doctor examined her injured arm.

Grisly.example: The newspaper published the grisly details of the murder.

Grit.definition: Courage and resolve; strength of character.
Grit.example: It takes true grit to succeed in such a competitive environment.

Grotesque.definition: Comically or repulsively ugly or distorted.
Grotesque.example: The gargoyles on the old cathedral had grotesque, leering faces.

Grouse.example: He was always grousing about the food in the cafeteria.

Grovel.definition: To act in an obsequious way in order to obtain someone's forgiveness or favor.
Grovel.example: He had to grovel to his boss to get his job back.

Grudging.definition: Given, granted, or allowed only reluctantly or resentfully.
Grudging.example: She gave a grudging apology after being forced to by her parents.

Grueling.example: The marathon was a grueling race, especially in the intense heat.

Gruff.definition: Abrupt or taciturn in manner; rough or stern.
Gruff.example: Despite his gruff exterior, he was a kind and generous man.

Gumption.definition: Shrewd or spirited initiative and resourcefulness.
Gumption.example: It takes a lot of gumption to start your own business from scratch.

Gustatory.definition: Concerned with tasting or the sense of taste.
Gustatory.example: The chef's creations were a gustatory delight, pleasing every palate.

Gusto.definition: Enjoyment and enthusiasm in doing something.
Gusto.example: She ate her meal with great gusto, savoring every bite.

Guile.example: The clever fox used its guile to outsmart the hunters.

Guileless.definition: Devoid of guile; innocent and without deception.
Guileless.example: The guileless child believed every word of the fantastic story.

Guise.definition: An external form, appearance, or manner of presentation, typically concealing the true nature of something.
Guise.example: He appeared in the guise of a friendly stranger to gain their trust.

Gullible.definition: Easily persuaded to believe something; credulous.
Gullible.example: The gullible tourist was an easy target for the street scam.

Gull.example: The con artist managed to gull the investors out of their life savings.

Gyrate.definition: To move or cause to move in a circle or spiral, especially quickly.
Gyrate.example: The dancers began to gyrate to the hypnotic beat of the music.

Garble.definition: To reproduce a message, sound, or transmission in a confused and distorted way.
Garble.example: The bad connection garbled his voice, making him impossible to understand.

Gerrymander.definition: To manipulate the boundaries of an electoral constituency so as to favor one party or class.
Gerrymander.example: The ruling party was accused of trying to gerrymander the districts to ensure their victory.

Gewgaw.definition: A showy thing, especially one that is useless or worthless; a trinket.
Gewgaw.example: Her shelves were cluttered with cheap gewgaws she had collected on her travels.

Gnostic.definition: Relating to knowledge, especially esoteric mystical knowledge.
Gnostic.example: The ancient text contained gnostic teachings known only to a select few.

Gourmandize.definition: To eat good food, especially to excess.
Gourmandize.example: They spent their vacation gourmandizing in the finest restaurants of Paris.

Grandeur.definition: Splendor and impressiveness, especially of appearance or style.
Grandeur.example: The grandeur of the mountains took our breath away.

Gravitas.definition: Dignity, seriousness, or solemnity of manner.
Gravitas.example: The judge's gravitas commanded respect in the courtroom.

Grisette.definition: A young French working-class woman, especially in 19th-century Paris.
Grisette.example: The artist's muse was a charming grisette he met in a Parisian cafe.

Guerrilla.definition: A member of a small independent group taking part in irregular fighting, typically against larger regular forces.
Guerrilla.example: The guerrilla fighters used their knowledge of the jungle to ambush the enemy.

Genteelism.definition: A word or phrase used to avoid a coarse or blunt one; a euphemism.
Genteelism.example: Using 'passed away' instead of 'died' is a common genteelism.

Glibness.definition: The quality of being fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow.
Glibness.example: His glibness made it difficult to trust anything he said.

Grotto.definition: A small picturesque cave, especially an artificial one in a park or garden.
Grotto.example: We discovered a hidden grotto behind the waterfall.

Grumble.definition: To complain or protest about something in a bad-tempered but low voice.
Grumble.example: He started to grumble about the amount of work he had to do.

Gusty.definition: Characterized by or blowing in gusts of wind.
Gusty.example: It was a gusty day, and the wind nearly blew my hat off.

Giddy.definition: Having a sensation of whirling and a tendency to fall or stagger; dizzy; excitable and frivolous.
Giddy.example: She felt giddy with excitement as she opened the acceptance letter.

Glossary.definition: An alphabetical list of terms or words found in or relating to a specific subject, with explanations.
Glossary.example: If you don't understand a term in the textbook, check the glossary at the back.

Glutton.example: He was a glutton for punishment, always taking on the most difficult tasks.

Grate.definition: To cause irritation; to make a harsh, scraping sound.
Grate.example: His constant complaining began to grate on her nerves.

Gross.definition: Very obvious and unacceptable; blatant (of wrongdoing).
Gross.example: The company was found guilty of gross negligence.

Grope.definition: To feel about or search blindly or uncertainly with the hands.
Grope.example: He had to grope for the light switch in the dark room.

Grind.example: After years of the daily grind, she was ready for a long vacation.

Gaudy.definition: Extravagantly bright or showy, typically so as to be tasteless.
Gaudy.example: She wore a gaudy dress covered in sequins and feathers.

Gesticulation.definition: A gesture, especially a dramatic one, used instead of speaking or to emphasize one's words.
Gesticulation.example: His speech was full of wild gesticulations and theatrical pauses.

Habiliments.definition: Clothing or attire, especially of a particular type.
Habiliments.example: The ceremonial habiliments of the king were stored in a climate-controlled vault.

Habituate.definition: To make or become accustomed or used to something.
Habituate.example: After a few months, she became habituated to the constant noise of the city.

Hagiography.definition: A biography that idealizes its subject, treating them as a saint.
Hagiography.example: The campaign literature was pure hagiography, ignoring the candidate's many flaws.

Halcyon.definition: Denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy and peaceful.
Halcyon.example: She often reminisced about the halcyon days of her childhood summers.

Hallmark.definition: A distinguishing feature, especially one of excellence.
Hallmark.example: Attention to detail is the hallmark of a fine craftsman.

Hapless.example: The hapless tourists had their luggage lost on the first day of their trip.

Harangue.definition: A lengthy and aggressive speech; a tirade.
Harangue.example: The coach delivered a furious harangue to the team after their poor performance.

Harbinger.definition: A person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another; a forerunner.
Harbinger.example: The robin is often considered a harbinger of spring.

Hardy.definition: Robust; capable of enduring difficult conditions.
Hardy.example: Only the hardiest of plants can survive the harsh desert climate.

Harrowing.example: The survivors of the shipwreck shared their harrowing tale of survival.

Haughtiness.definition: The appearance or quality of being arrogantly superior and disdainful.
Haughtiness.example: His haughtiness was so pronounced that he had very few friends.

Hauteur.example: She surveyed the room with an air of hauteur, dismissing everyone she saw.

Hedonism.definition: The pursuit of pleasure and sensual self-indulgence as a primary way of life.
Hedonism.example: His life of unchecked hedonism ultimately led to his downfall.

Hegemony.definition: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
Hegemony.example: The nation's economic hegemony was challenged by emerging global powers.

Heinous.definition: Utterly odious or wicked; shockingly evil.
Heinous.example: The dictator was responsible for numerous heinous crimes against his people.

Heresy.definition: Belief or opinion contrary to orthodox religious doctrine or accepted beliefs.
Heresy.example: Galileo was accused of heresy for his theory that the Earth revolved around the Sun.

Hermetic.definition: Completely sealed, especially against the escape or entry of air.
Hermetic.example: The ancient tomb was under a hermetic seal, preserving its contents for millennia.

Heterodox.definition: Not conforming with accepted or orthodox standards or beliefs.
Heterodox.example: Her heterodox views on economic policy were initially dismissed by her colleagues.

Heterogeneous.definition: Diverse in character or content; composed of parts of different kinds.
Heterogeneous.example: The student body at the university is remarkably heterogeneous.

Heuristic.definition: Enabling a person to discover or learn something for themselves; a problem-solving approach.
Heuristic.example: The teacher used a heuristic method, guiding students to find their own solutions.

Hiatus.definition: A pause or gap in a sequence, series, or process.
Hiatus.example: The popular television show is taking a one-year hiatus.

Hidebound.definition: Unwilling or unable to change because of tradition or convention.
Hidebound.example: The hidebound board of directors refused to consider any modern business practices.

Hierarchical.definition: Arranged in order of rank or authority.
Hierarchical.example: The military is a strictly hierarchical organization.

Hirsute.example: The professor was a kind but noticeably hirsute man.

Histrionic.definition: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
Histrionic.example: She gave a histrionic display of grief at the funeral, which many found insincere.

Hoary.example: He entertained us with a few hoary old jokes that we'd all heard before.

Hodgepodge.example: Her latest novel is a hodgepodge of different genres and ideas.

Holistic.definition: Characterized by the belief that parts of something are explicable only by reference to the whole.
Holistic.example: Holistic medicine treats the whole person, not just the symptoms of a disease.

Homage.definition: Special honor or respect shown publicly.
Homage.example: The film is an homage to the classic detective movies of the 1940s.

Homily.definition: A sermon or speech that gives moral or spiritual advice.
Homily.example: The priest delivered a thoughtful homily on the importance of compassion.

Homogeneous.definition: Of the same kind; alike; consisting of parts all of the same kind.
Homogeneous.example: The population of the small, isolated village was remarkably homogeneous.

Hone.definition: To sharpen or refine a skill over a period of time.
Hone.example: She moved to Paris to hone her skills as a pastry chef.

Honorific.definition: A title or word implying or expressing respect.
Honorific.example: Using the correct honorific, such as 'Dr.' or 'Professor,' is important in a formal setting.

Hortatory.definition: Tending or aiming to exhort; advisory.
Hortatory.example: The president's speech was hortatory, urging citizens to volunteer in their communities.

Hostelry.example: The weary travelers were relieved to find a quaint hostelry for the night.

Hovel.definition: A small, squalid, unpleasant, or simply constructed dwelling.
Hovel.example: The destitute family was forced to live in a wretched hovel.

Hubris.definition: Excessive pride or self-confidence, often leading to a downfall.
Hubris.example: In Greek tragedies, the hero's downfall is often a direct result of his hubris.

Humane.definition: Having or showing compassion or benevolence.
Humane.example: The organization is dedicated to the humane treatment of all animals.

Humdrum.definition: Lacking excitement or variety; dull; monotonous.
Humdrum.example: He longed for an adventure to escape his humdrum life.

Husbandry.definition: The care, cultivation, and breeding of crops and animals; careful management of resources.
Husbandry.example: Good animal husbandry is essential for maintaining a healthy and productive herd.

Hybrid.definition: A thing made by combining two different elements; a mixture.
Hybrid.example: The car is a hybrid that runs on both gasoline and electricity.

Hydra-headed.definition: Having many facets or aspects, especially difficult or intractable ones.
Hydra-headed.example: Urban poverty is a hydra-headed problem that requires a multifaceted solution.

Hyperbole.definition: Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally.
Hyperbole.example: His claim that he was so hungry he could eat a horse was pure hyperbole.

Hypercritical.definition: Excessively and unreasonably critical, especially of small faults.
Hypercritical.example: It's difficult to work for such a hypercritical boss who is never satisfied.

Hypocrisy.definition: The practice of claiming to have moral standards to which one's own behavior does not conform.
Hypocrisy.example: It is sheer hypocrisy for him to condemn gambling while he secretly bets on horses.

Hypothetical.definition: Based on or serving as a hypothesis; supposed but not necessarily real or true.
Hypothetical.example: For the sake of argument, let's consider a hypothetical scenario.

Hallowed.example: The soldiers were buried in the hallowed ground of the national cemetery.

Hap.example: By sheer hap, I found a twenty-dollar bill on the street.

Harried.definition: Feeling strained as a result of having persistent demands made on one; harassed.
Harried.example: The harried assistant juggled three phone calls while typing an urgent report.

Harrow.definition: To cause distress to; to vex.
Harrow.example: The images of the famine would harrow the conscience of the world.

Hegira.example: The family's hegira from their war-torn homeland was a long and dangerous journey.

Heliocentric.definition: Having or representing the sun as the center of the solar system.
Heliocentric.example: Copernicus's heliocentric model was a revolutionary idea in the 16th century.

Herald.definition: To be a sign that something is about to happen; to acclaim.
Herald.example: The new policy was heralded as a major breakthrough in environmental protection.

Heresiarch.definition: The founder of a heresy or the leader of a heretical sect.
Heresiarch.example: Martin Luther was considered a heresiarch by the established church of his time.

Heteromorphic.definition: Having different forms at different periods of the life cycle.
Heteromorphic.example: Butterflies are heteromorphic, changing from caterpillar to chrysalis to adult.

Hieratic.definition: Of or concerning priests; of a formal, stylized, or sacred character.
Hieratic.example: The ancient manuscript was written in a formal, hieratic script.

Holograph.definition: A manuscript handwritten by its author.
Holograph.example: The museum's most prized possession is a holograph of the poet's final work.

Homiletics.definition: The art of preaching or writing sermons.
Homiletics.example: The seminary student took a course in homiletics to improve his public speaking.

Homeostasis.definition: The tendency toward a relatively stable equilibrium between interdependent elements.
Homeostasis.example: The body's ability to regulate its internal temperature is a key part of homeostasis.

Horticulture.definition: The art or practice of garden cultivation and management.
Horticulture.example: She has a degree in horticulture and runs a successful landscape design business.

Hoyden.definition: A boisterous, high-spirited, and often tomboyish girl.
Hoyden.example: In the Victorian era, a girl who behaved like a hoyden was often reprimanded.

Hue.definition: A color or a shade of a color.
Hue.example: The sunset painted the sky in brilliant hues of orange and pink.

Humility.definition: A modest or low view of one's own importance; humbleness.
Humility.example: He accepted the prestigious award with genuine humility.

Hyperborean.definition: Of or relating to the far north; arctic.
Hyperborean.example: The explorers were well-equipped for the hyperborean conditions they would face.

Hypnagogic.definition: Relating to the state immediately before falling asleep.
Hypnagogic.example: He often experienced vivid, hypnagogic imagery as he drifted off to sleep.

Hypostatize.definition: To treat or represent an abstract concept as a concrete reality.
Hypostatize.example: It is a common philosophical error to hypostatize concepts like 'truth' and 'beauty'.

Hypothecate.definition: To pledge money or property as security for a loan without delivering possession.
Hypothecate.example: He had to hypothecate his house to secure the business loan.

Hagiolatry.example: The scholar's book examined the rise of hagiolatry during the Middle Ages.

Hegemonic.definition: Ruling or dominant in a political or social context.
Hegemonic.example: The company's hegemonic control over the market prevented any real competition.

Heliolatry.example: Heliolatry was a central part of many ancient religions, such as that of the Egyptians.

Hellenism.definition: The national character or culture of Greece, especially ancient Greece.
Hellenism.example: The conquests of Alexander the Great led to the spread of Hellenism across the ancient world.

Helot.definition: A member of a class of serfs in ancient Sparta, with a status between slaves and citizens.
Helot.example: The Spartan state was heavily dependent on the agricultural labor of the helots.

Hereditament.definition: Any item of property, whether tangible or intangible, that can be inherited.
Hereditament.example: The will clearly listed every hereditament, from the house to the stocks and bonds.

Hermeneutics.definition: The branch of knowledge that deals with interpretation, especially of the Bible or literary texts.
Hermeneutics.example: Biblical hermeneutics requires a deep understanding of ancient languages and cultures.

Hiemal.definition: Of or relating to winter; wintry.
Hiemal.example: The bears prepared for their long hiemal hibernation.

Hierophant.definition: A person, especially a priest, who interprets sacred mysteries or esoteric principles.
Hierophant.example: The hierophant was the chief interpreter of the oracle's cryptic prophecies.

Hippodrome.definition: A course for chariot or horse races in ancient Greece or Rome.
Hippodrome.example: The highlight of the festival was the thrilling chariot race at the hippodrome.

Homologate.definition: To approve or confirm officially; to grant official approval.
Homologate.example: The international committee must homologate the new car design before it can be used in races.

Homophone.definition: A word that is pronounced the same as another word but differs in meaning or spelling.
Homophone.example: The words 'to,' 'too,' and 'two' are common homophones that often cause confusion.

Hortative.definition: Giving exhortation; advisory. (A synonym for hortatory).
Hortative.example: The general's speech was hortative in tone, designed to inspire the troops before battle.

Humanism.definition: A system of thought attaching prime importance to human rather than divine or supernatural matters.
Humanism.example: Renaissance humanism celebrated the potential and achievements of the individual.

Humus.definition: The organic component of soil, formed by the decomposition of leaves and other plant material.
Humus.example: Adding compost to the garden increases the amount of nutrient-rich humus in the soil.

Hustings.definition: The political campaigning and speechmaking associated with an election.
Hustings.example: The candidate spent months on the hustings, trying to win over voters.

Hydrophobia.definition: Extreme or irrational fear of water; a symptom of rabies.
Hydrophobia.example: After the boating accident, he developed a severe case of hydrophobia.

Hygienic.definition: Conducive to maintaining health and preventing disease, especially by being clean; sanitary.
Hygienic.example: Food service workers must follow strict hygienic procedures.

Hyperkinesia.definition: Abnormally increased and sometimes uncontrollable muscle movement.
Hyperkinesia.example: The medication, while effective, sometimes caused hyperkinesia as a side effect.

Hypocorism.definition: A pet name, nickname, or diminutive.
Hypocorism.example: Using a hypocorism like 'Bobby' for 'Robert' can show familiarity and affection.

Hypogeal.example: Archaeologists discovered a network of hypogeal burial chambers.

Hypoxia.definition: Deficiency in the amount of oxygen reaching the tissues.
Hypoxia.example: Mountain climbers must acclimate slowly to avoid suffering from hypoxia at high altitudes.

Hagiology.definition: Literature dealing with the lives and legends of saints.
Hagiology.example: The monastery's library was filled with ancient texts on hagiology.

Hair-splitting.definition: The act of making overly fine or unnecessary distinctions.
Hair-splitting.example: The lawyers' debate devolved into pointless hair-splitting over minor clauses.

Hand-wringing.definition: The excessive display of concern or distress.
Hand-wringing.example: There was much public hand-wringing over the new tax policy, but little action.

Harlequin.definition: A stock comic character in traditional pantomime, typically masked and dressed in a diamond-patterned costume.
Harlequin.example: The agile harlequin danced across the stage, causing mischief wherever he went.

Heliotropism.definition: The directional growth of a plant in response to sunlight.
Heliotropism.example: The heliotropism of sunflowers causes them to face the sun throughout the day.

Hellenize.definition: To make Greek in character or culture.
Hellenize.example: The Romans admired Greek culture and sought to Hellenize many aspects of their own society.

Hemialgia.definition: Pain affecting one half of the body.
Hemialgia.example: The patient's rare neurological condition caused hemialgia on his entire left side.

Hinterland.definition: The remote areas of a country away from the coast or the banks of major rivers.
Hinterland.example: The new railroad opened up the vast hinterland for settlement and trade.

Holophrastic.definition: Expressing a complex of ideas in a single word or a fixed phrase.
Holophrastic.example: A baby's cry can be a holophrastic utterance, communicating hunger, pain, or fear.

Homunculus.definition: A very small human or humanoid creature, often associated with alchemy.
Homunculus.example: In the old alchemical text, there were fanciful instructions for creating a homunculus.

Iconoclast.definition: A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
Iconoclast.example: The iconoclast's controversial book challenged the very foundations of modern philosophy.

Idiosyncrasy.definition: A mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
Idiosyncrasy.example: His idiosyncrasy of always wearing mismatched socks made him a memorable character.

Idyllic.example: They enjoyed an idyllic vacation in a small cottage by the sea.

Ignominious.definition: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
Ignominious.example: The team suffered an ignominious defeat, losing by a margin of 50 points.

Illicit.definition: Forbidden by law, rules, or custom.
Illicit.example: The company was investigated for its illicit trade practices.

Imbroglio.definition: An extremely confused, complicated, or embarrassing situation.
Imbroglio.example: The political imbroglio was caused by the senator's conflicting statements.

Imbue.definition: To inspire or permeate with a feeling or quality.
Imbue.example: His speech was imbued with a sense of hope and determination.

Immutable.definition: Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
Immutable.example: The laws of physics are considered immutable.

Impassive.example: The poker player maintained an impassive face, hiding the strength of his hand.

Impeccable.definition: In accordance with the highest standards; faultless.
Impeccable.example: Her impeccable manners and style impressed everyone at the formal dinner.

Impecunious.example: The impecunious student had to work three jobs to pay for his tuition.

Impede.definition: To delay or prevent (someone or something) by obstructing them; hinder.
Impede.example: The fallen trees impeded the progress of the rescue team.

Imperative.example: It is imperative that we act now to address the climate crisis.

Imperceptible.example: The change in temperature was almost imperceptible.

Imperious.definition: Assuming power or authority without justification; arrogant and domineering.
Imperious.example: The imperious manager demanded absolute obedience from his staff.

Impermeable.definition: Not allowing fluid to pass through.
Impermeable.example: A raincoat is made of impermeable fabric to keep you dry.

Imperturbable.definition: Unable to be upset or excited; calm.
Imperturbable.example: Despite the chaos around him, the bomb disposal expert remained imperturbable.

Impervious.definition: Not allowing fluid to pass through; unable to be affected by.
Impervious.example: He seemed impervious to criticism, continuing his work with unwavering confidence.

Impetuous.definition: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
Impetuous.example: His impetuous decision to quit his job without another one lined up was a source of great stress.

Implacable.definition: Unable to be placated; relentless; unstoppable.
Implacable.example: The general was an implacable foe, known for his ruthless tactics.

Implausible.definition: Not seeming reasonable or probable; failing to convince.
Implausible.example: The defendant's alibi was so implausible that the jury dismissed it immediately.

Implicit.example: There was an implicit understanding between them that they would support each other.

Importune.definition: To harass (someone) persistently for or to do something.
Importune.example: He began to importune his friends for loans to cover his gambling debts.

Impregnable.definition: Unable to be captured or broken into.
Impregnable.example: The castle was surrounded by an impregnable wall.

Impromptu.definition: Done without being planned, organized, or rehearsed.
Impromptu.example: He gave an impromptu speech at his friend's wedding.

Improvident.definition: Not having or showing foresight; spendthrift or thoughtless.
Improvident.example: Her improvident spending habits left her with no savings for emergencies.

Impugn.definition: To dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive); call into question.
Impugn.example: The defense attorney tried to impugn the credibility of the witness.

Impunity.definition: Exemption from punishment or freedom from the injurious consequences of an action.
Impunity.example: The dictator ruled with impunity, ignoring international laws and human rights.

Inadvertent.definition: Not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning.
Inadvertent.example: The inadvertent disclosure of the secret formula caused a major crisis for the company.

Inane.example: Their inane chatter during the movie was incredibly distracting.

Inarticulate.definition: Unable to speak distinctly or express oneself clearly.
Inarticulate.example: Overcome with emotion, he was inarticulate and could only stammer a few words.

Incandescent.definition: Emitting light as a result of being heated; passionate or brilliant.
Incandescent.example: The incandescent performance by the lead actor earned him a standing ovation.

Incantation.definition: A series of words said as a magic spell or charm.
Incantation.example: The witch muttered an incantation to cast her spell.

Incessant.definition: (Of something regarded as unpleasant) continuing without pause or interruption.
Incessant.example: The incessant noise from the construction site made it impossible to concentrate.

Inchoate.definition: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
Inchoate.example: Her inchoate ideas for the novel needed more time to mature.

Incipient.definition: In an initial stage; beginning to happen or develop.
Incipient.example: He could feel the incipient signs of a cold, like a scratchy throat and a runny nose.

Incisive.definition: (Of a person or mental process) intelligently analytical and clear-thinking.
Incisive.example: Her incisive questions cut to the heart of the matter.

Incognito.example: The celebrity traveled incognito to avoid being recognized by fans.

Incoherent.definition: (Of spoken or written language) expressed in a confusing way; unclear.
Incoherent.example: After the accident, he was incoherent and could not explain what had happened.

Incongruous.definition: Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects of something.
Incongruous.example: The modern sculpture looked incongruous in the ancient cathedral.

Inconsequential.example: They argued over inconsequential details, wasting valuable time.

Incontrovertible.definition: Not able to be denied or disputed.
Incontrovertible.example: The DNA evidence provided incontrovertible proof of his guilt.

Incorrigible.definition: (Of a person or their tendencies) not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.
Incorrigible.example: The boy was an incorrigible prankster, always getting into trouble at school.

Incredulous.definition: (Of a person or their manner) unwilling or unable to believe something.
Incredulous.example: She gave him an incredulous look when he claimed to have seen a UFO.

Inculcate.definition: To instill (an attitude, idea, or habit) by persistent instruction.
Inculcate.example: The coach tried to inculcate a sense of discipline and teamwork in his players.

Incumbent.definition: Necessary for (someone) as a duty or responsibility.
Incumbent.example: It is incumbent upon the government to protect its citizens.

Indefatigable.definition: (Of a person or their efforts) persisting tirelessly.
Indefatigable.example: The indefatigable activist worked for decades to promote human rights.

Indelible.definition: Not able to be forgotten or removed.
Indelible.example: The tragic events of that day left an indelible mark on her memory.

Indemnify.definition: To compensate (someone) for harm or loss.
Indemnify.example: The insurance company will indemnify you for any damages to your car.

Indigenous.definition: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
Indigenous.example: The kangaroo is indigenous to Australia.

Indigent.example: The clinic provides free medical care for indigent patients.

Indignation.definition: Anger or annoyance provoked by what is perceived as unfair treatment.
Indignation.example: The announcement of pay cuts was met with widespread indignation among the employees.

Indiscriminate.definition: Done at random or without careful judgment.
Indiscriminate.example: The indiscriminate use of pesticides can harm the environment.

Indolent.definition: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
Indolent.example: The indolent cat spent the entire day sleeping in the sun.

Indomitable.example: She possessed an indomitable spirit that helped her overcome many hardships.

Indubitable.example: Her indubitable talent was clear to everyone who heard her sing.

Induce.definition: To succeed in persuading or influencing (someone) to do something.
Induce.example: Nothing could induce him to change his mind.

Indulgent.definition: Having or indicating a tendency to be overly generous to or lenient with someone.
Indulgent.example: The indulgent parents gave their child everything he asked for.

Ineffable.definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
Ineffable.example: The beauty of the sunset over the ocean was ineffable.

Ineffectual.definition: Not producing any or the desired effect.
Ineffectual.example: His attempts to fix the broken machine were ineffectual.

Ineluctable.definition: Unable to be resisted or avoided; inescapable.
Ineluctable.example: The characters in the tragedy moved toward their ineluctable fate.

Inept.definition: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
Inept.example: His inept handling of the situation only made things worse.

Inert.definition: Lacking the ability or strength to move.
Inert.example: He lay inert on the ground after the fall.

Inevitable.example: With such dark clouds, a storm seemed inevitable.

Inexorable.example: The inexorable march of time waits for no one.

Infallible.definition: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
Infallible.example: The pope was once considered infallible in matters of faith.

Infamous.definition: Well known for some bad quality or deed.
Infamous.example: The infamous pirate Blackbeard terrorized the seas.

Infantile.definition: Of or characteristic of an infant; childish.
Infantile.example: His infantile behavior and tantrums were inappropriate for a man his age.

Infer.definition: To deduce or conclude (information) from evidence and reasoning rather than from explicit statements.
Infer.example: From her smile, he could infer that she was pleased with the news.

Infinitesimal.example: The chances of winning the lottery are infinitesimal.

Infraction.definition: A violation or infringement of a law or agreement.
Infraction.example: A minor traffic infraction resulted in a small fine.

Ingenious.definition: (Of a person) clever, original, and inventive.
Ingenious.example: She came up with an ingenious solution to the complex problem.

Ingenuous.definition: (Of a person or action) innocent and unsuspecting.
Ingenuous.example: His ingenuous nature made him vulnerable to deception.

Ingrained.definition: (Of a habit, belief, or attitude) firmly fixed or established; difficult to change.
Ingrained.example: His prejudice was so ingrained that it was impossible to reason with him.

Ingrate.example: She felt he was an ingrate for not thanking her for the generous gift.

Ingratiate.definition: To bring oneself into favor with someone by flattering or trying to please them.
Ingratiate.example: He tried to ingratiate himself with the new boss by complimenting her constantly.

Inherent.definition: Existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute.
Inherent.example: The desire for freedom is inherent in all people.

Inhibit.definition: To hinder, restrain, or prevent (an action or process).
Inhibit.example: Fear of failure can inhibit people from taking risks.

Inimical.definition: Tending to obstruct or harm; unfriendly; hostile.
Inimical.example: The policy was inimical to the interests of the working class.

Inimitable.definition: So good or unusual as to be impossible to copy; unique.
Inimitable.example: The comedian's inimitable style made him a legend.

Iniquity.example: The city was a den of iniquity, filled with corruption and vice.

Initiate.definition: To cause (a process or action) to begin.
Initiate.example: The government will initiate a new program to combat unemployment.

Injurious.definition: Causing or likely to cause damage or harm.
Injurious.example: Smoking is injurious to your health.

Innate.example: He has an innate talent for music.

Innocuous.example: What seemed like an innocuous comment was actually a subtle insult.

Innovation.definition: A new method, idea, product, etc.
Innovation.example: The company is known for its constant innovation in technology.

Innuendo.definition: An allusive or oblique remark or hint, typically a suggestive or disparaging one.
Innuendo.example: He made a sly innuendo about her relationship with her boss.

Inopportune.definition: Occurring at an inconvenient or inappropriate time.
Inopportune.example: His arrival at such an inopportune moment created an awkward silence.

Inordinate.example: He spent an inordinate amount of time on the project, neglecting his other duties.

Inscrutable.example: His inscrutable expression gave no clue as to what he was thinking.

Insidious.definition: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects.
Insidious.example: The insidious effects of the disease were not apparent at first.

Insinuate.definition: To suggest or hint (something bad or reprehensible) in an indirect and unpleasant way.
Insinuate.example: Are you insinuating that I cheated on the exam?

Insipid.definition: Lacking flavor; lacking vigor or interest.
Insipid.example: The soup was insipid, so I added some salt and pepper.

Insolent.definition: Showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect.
Insolent.example: The student's insolent behavior towards the teacher earned him a detention.

Insolvent.example: The company was declared insolvent after years of financial losses.

Instigate.definition: To bring about or initiate (an action or event).
Instigate.example: He was accused of instigating the riot.

Insular.definition: Ignorant of or uninterested in cultures, ideas, or peoples outside one's own experience.
Insular.example: Living in a small town, her views had become rather insular.

Insuperable.definition: (Of a difficulty or obstacle) impossible to overcome.
Insuperable.example: The team faced what seemed like an insuperable challenge to win the championship.

Intangible.definition: Unable to be touched or grasped; not having physical presence.
Intangible.example: Qualities like honesty and integrity are intangible assets.

Integral.definition: Necessary to make a whole complete; essential or fundamental.
Integral.example: Trust is an integral part of any healthy relationship.

Interloper.definition: A person who becomes involved in a place or situation where they are not wanted or do not belong.
Interloper.example: The locals viewed the tourists as interlopers who disrupted their quiet lives.

Interminable.definition: Endless or apparently endless (often used hyperbolically).
Interminable.example: The lecture seemed interminable, and I struggled to stay awake.

Intrepid.example: The intrepid explorer ventured deep into the uncharted jungle.

Jabber.definition: To talk rapidly and excitedly but with little sense.
Jabber.example: The children continued to jabber in the backseat, making it difficult for their mother to concentrate on driving.

Jacent.example: The detective found the ancient tome jacent on the dusty library floor, as if it had been dropped in a hurry.

Jacitation.example: His constant jacitation about his wealth and accomplishments made him unpopular at social gatherings.

Jactation.definition: The restless tossing of the body in severe illness or agitation.
Jactation.example: The patient's jactation was a clear sign of his extreme discomfort and fever.

Jaded.definition: Tired, bored, or lacking enthusiasm, typically after having had too much of something.
Jaded.example: After years of international travel, he had become jaded and found little excitement in visiting new places.

Jangle.definition: To make or cause to make a loud, harsh, ringing sound, often in a discordant way.
Jangle.example: The keys would jangle in his pocket with every step he took.

Janus-faced.definition: Having two sharply contrasting aspects or characteristics; deceitful or two-faced.
Janus-faced.example: The politician's Janus-faced approach involved promising tax cuts to the rich and increased social spending to the poor.

Jape.definition: A practical joke or a witty remark made in jest.
Jape.example: His lighthearted jape about the boss's tie was not well-received in the serious meeting.

Jargon.definition: Special words or expressions used by a particular profession or group that are difficult for others to understand.
Jargon.example: The medical jargon used by the doctors was incomprehensible to the patient's family.

Jarring.definition: Incongruous in a striking or shocking way; causing a physical jolt or shock.
Jarring.example: The jarring contrast between the beautiful scenery and the dilapidated building was unsettling.

Jaundiced.definition: Having or showing bitterness, resentment, or cynicism.
Jaundiced.example: His past failures gave him a jaundiced view of any new business venture.

Jaunty.definition: Having or expressing a lively, cheerful, and self-confident manner.
Jaunty.example: He walked with a jaunty step, whistling a cheerful tune.

Jeer.definition: To make rude and mocking remarks, typically in a loud voice.
Jeer.example: The crowd began to jeer at the opposing team when they missed an easy shot.

Jejune.definition: Naive, simplistic, and superficial; dry and uninteresting.
Jejune.example: The professor criticized the student's jejune analysis of the complex historical event.

Jeopardy.definition: Danger of loss, harm, or failure.
Jeopardy.example: The company's financial stability was in jeopardy after the market crash.

Jeremiad.definition: A long, mournful complaint or lamentation; a list of woes.
Jeremiad.example: The candidate's speech was less a plan for the future and more a jeremiad about the country's current state.

Jerry-built.definition: Badly or hastily built with cheap materials.
Jerry-built.example: The jerry-built shed collapsed during the first winter storm.

Jest.definition: A thing said or done for amusement; a joke.
Jest.example: He made the comment in jest, but it was taken seriously by some of his colleagues.

Jetsam.definition: Unwanted material or goods that have been thrown overboard from a ship and washed ashore.
Jetsam.example: The beach was littered with jetsam from the wrecked cargo ship.

Jettison.definition: To throw or drop something from an aircraft or ship; to abandon or discard something that is no longer wanted.
Jettison.example: To save the sinking ship, the crew had to jettison much of its cargo.

Jettatura.definition: The supposed magical power of the 'evil eye' to cause misfortune.
Jettatura.example: Believing the old woman possessed the power of jettatura, the villagers avoided her gaze.

Jetty.definition: A landing stage or small pier at which boats can dock or be moored.
Jetty.example: We walked along the jetty to get a better view of the sunset over the water.

Jib.definition: To be unwilling to proceed or to accept a proposal or course of action.
Jib.example: The committee jibbed at the enormous cost of the proposed new stadium.

Jibe.definition: An insulting or mocking remark; a taunt.
Jibe.example: He was tired of the constant jibes from his coworkers about his old car.

Jilt.definition: To suddenly reject or abandon a lover.
Jilt.example: She was devastated when her fianc decided to jilt her just weeks before the wedding.

Jimcrack.definition: A cheap, showy, but ultimately useless trinket or gadget.
Jimcrack.example: The souvenir shop was full of jimcracks that tourists bought but would soon discard.

Jingoism.definition: Extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy.
Jingoism.example: The politician's speech was criticized for its jingoism and for escalating international tensions.

Jinx.definition: A person or thing that brings bad luck.
Jinx.example: He considered himself a jinx after his team lost every game he attended.

Jittery.definition: Nervous or unable to relax; shaky.
Jittery.example: Too much caffeine made him feel jittery and anxious before the presentation.

Jobbery.definition: The practice of using a public office or position of trust for one's own gain or advantage; corruption.
Jobbery.example: The investigation uncovered widespread jobbery, with officials awarding contracts to their friends and family.

Jockey.definition: To struggle by every available means to gain or achieve something; to maneuver for position.
Jockey.example: The candidates began to jockey for the lead in the polls as the election neared.

Jocose.example: His jocose manner made him a favorite storyteller among the children.

Jocular.definition: Fond of or characterized by joking; humorous or playful.
Jocular.example: The jocular professor always started his lectures with a funny anecdote.

Jocund.example: The jocund atmosphere of the festival was infectious, and soon everyone was smiling.

Joiner.definition: A person who constructs the wooden components of a building, such as stairs, doors, and window frames.
Joiner.example: The skilled joiner crafted a beautiful, custom-made staircase for the new house.

Jointure.definition: An estate or property settled on a wife for the period during which she survives her husband.
Jointure.example: In the historical novel, the widow lived comfortably on the jointure provided by her late husband's will.

Joist.definition: A length of timber or steel supporting part of a building's structure, typically for a floor or ceiling.
Joist.example: The contractor inspected the old joists in the ceiling to ensure they could support the new floor above.

Jollification.example: The end-of-year party was a time of great jollification for all the employees.

Jollity.definition: Lively and cheerful activity or celebration.
Jollity.example: The air of jollity at the wedding reception was contagious.

Jostle.definition: To push, elbow, or bump against someone roughly, typically in a crowd.
Jostle.example: Fans began to jostle each other to get a better view of the celebrity.

Jounce.example: The old truck would jounce and rattle over the unpaved country road.

Journalize.definition: To record transactions in a journal, especially in bookkeeping.
Journalize.example: The accountant's first task each morning was to journalize the previous day's financial activities.

Journeyman.definition: A worker or sports player who is reliable but not outstanding; a trained worker who is employed by someone else.
Journeyman.example: He was a journeyman carpenter, skilled in his trade but not yet a master craftsman.

Joust.definition: To engage in a sporting contest in which two opponents on horseback fight with lances; to compete closely for superiority.
Joust.example: The two tech companies continue to joust for dominance in the smartphone market.

Jovial.example: The host's jovial personality made all his guests feel welcome and at ease.

Joyance.definition: A feeling of great pleasure and happiness; exultation.
Joyance.example: A feeling of pure joyance washed over her as she reached the mountain summit.

Jubilant.definition: Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph.
Jubilant.example: The jubilant fans swarmed the field after their team won the championship.

Jubilation.definition: A feeling of great happiness and triumph; rejoicing.
Jubilation.example: There was great jubilation in the streets when the war finally ended.

Judicature.definition: The administration of justice; a body of judges.
Judicature.example: The country's judicature is responsible for interpreting and upholding the constitution.

Judicatory.definition: Relating to the administration of justice; a court of law or justice.
Judicatory.example: The case was brought before a special judicatory panel for review.

Judicial.definition: Of, by, or appropriate to a court or judge.
Judicial.example: The judicial branch of government is responsible for interpreting laws.

Judicious.definition: Having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense.
Judicious.example: Making a judicious use of her limited resources, she was able to start a successful business.

Juggernaut.definition: A huge, powerful, and overwhelming force or institution.
Juggernaut.example: The tech company became a juggernaut in the industry, crushing all of its competitors.

Jugulate.definition: To cut the throat of; to check or suppress by extreme measures.
Jugulate.example: The dictator attempted to jugulate all dissent by imprisoning opposition leaders.

Juncture.definition: A particular point in events or time; a place where things join.
Juncture.example: At this critical juncture, we must decide whether to proceed or to abandon the project.

Junket.definition: A trip or tour, especially one made by an official at public expense.
Junket.example: The senator was criticized for taking a lavish junket to Europe funded by taxpayers.

Junta.definition: A military or political group that rules a country after taking power by force.
Junta.example: After the coup, the country was ruled by a military junta.

Jurant.definition: A person who takes an oath.
Jurant.example: Each jurant placed a hand on the sacred text and swore to uphold the law.

Juratory.example: The witness signed a juratory statement, confirming the truthfulness of their testimony under penalty of perjury.

Juridical.definition: Relating to judicial proceedings and the administration of the law.
Juridical.example: The law professor specialized in the juridical systems of ancient Rome.

Jurisdiction.definition: The official power to make legal decisions and judgments.
Jurisdiction.example: The case was outside the court's jurisdiction because the crime occurred in another state.

Jurisprudence.definition: The theory or philosophy of law; a legal system.
Jurisprudence.example: He studied jurisprudence at law school to better understand the principles behind the legal code.

Jurist.definition: An expert in or writer on law.
Jurist.example: The retired Supreme Court justice was a highly respected jurist known for his insightful opinions.

Juristic.definition: Relating to a jurist or jurisprudence.
Juristic.example: The article provided a juristic analysis of the recent court ruling.

Justiciar.definition: A high judicial officer in medieval England.
Justiciar.example: The king appointed a trusted justiciar to oversee the royal courts in his absence.

Justiciable.definition: Subject to trial in a court of law.
Justiciable.example: The court ruled that the political dispute was not a justiciable matter.

Justificatory.example: He wrote a long, justificatory letter to the board explaining his controversial decision.
