Justness.definition: The quality or state of being just, righteous, or fair.
Justness.example: The judge was known for the justness of her rulings and her commitment to equality.

Jut.definition: To extend out, over, or beyond the main body or line of something.
Jut.example: A rocky promontory began to jut out from the coastline into the sea.

Juvenescent.example: After the relaxing vacation, he felt a juvenescent energy he hadn't experienced in years.

Juvenilia.definition: Works produced by an author or artist while they were young.
Juvenilia.example: The museum's exhibit featured the famous painter's juvenilia, offering a glimpse into her early development.

Juxtapose.definition: To place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
Juxtapose.example: The artist chose to juxtapose the bright colors of the flowers with the dark, gloomy background.

Juxtaposition.definition: The fact of two things being seen or placed close together with contrasting effect.
Juxtaposition.example: The juxtaposition of wealth and poverty in the city was striking.

Jacobin.definition: A member of a radical political group during the French Revolution.
Jacobin.example: The Jacobins were known for their extreme egalitarianism and advocacy for a centralized republic.

Jacquerie.definition: A communal uprising or revolt of peasants.
Jacquerie.example: The historian wrote a book about the Jacquerie that occurred in 14th-century France.

Janissary.definition: A member of the Turkish infantry forming the Sultan's guard between the 14th and 19th centuries; a devoted follower or supporter.
Janissary.example: The CEO surrounded himself with a group of janissaries who would execute his orders without question.

Jargonize.definition: To speak or write in jargon.
Jargonize.example: The expert tended to jargonize, making it difficult for the audience to understand his presentation.

Jawbone.definition: To try to persuade or pressure by exhortation.
Jawbone.example: The president attempted to jawbone the industry leaders into lowering prices.

Jingoist.definition: A person who professes his or her patriotism loudly and excessively, favoring an aggressive, warlike foreign policy.
Jingoist.example: The jingoist called for military intervention, dismissing any attempts at diplomacy.

Jocosity.definition: The quality of being playful or humorous.
Jocosity.example: His natural jocosity made him the life of every party.

Jocularity.definition: The state or quality of being fond of or characterized by joking.
Jocularity.example: Despite the serious nature of their work, there was a surprising amount of jocularity in the office.

Jolliness.definition: The quality of being jolly; cheerfulness and conviviality.
Jolliness.example: The jolliness of the holiday season was evident in the festive decorations and cheerful music.

Jot.example: She used a small notepad to jot down ideas as they came to her.

Judaic.definition: Of or relating to Judaism or the Jews.
Judaic.example: The museum had an extensive collection of Judaic art and artifacts.

Judgement.definition: The ability to make considered decisions or come to sensible conclusions.
Judgement.example: She showed poor judgement when she decided to invest all her money in one stock.

Judgemental.definition: Having or displaying an overly critical point of view.
Judgemental.example: He tried not to be judgemental about his friend's unconventional lifestyle.

Judicially.definition: In a way that relates to the law or the administration of justice.
Judicially.example: The matter was settled judicially, with a final ruling from the high court.

Judiciously.example: The funds were distributed judiciously to the projects that needed them most.

Jugglery.definition: The art or skill of a juggler; trickery or deception.
Jugglery.example: The politician's explanation was a piece of verbal jugglery designed to obscure the truth.

Jumble.definition: An untidy collection or pile of things.
Jumble.example: I found my old keys in a jumble of papers and receipts at the bottom of the drawer.

Jumpy.definition: Anxious and uneasy; causing or characterized by sudden, nervous movements.
Jumpy.example: The loud, unexpected noise made the cat jumpy for the rest of the evening.

Justifiable.definition: Able to be shown to be right or reasonable; defensible.
Justifiable.example: Given the circumstances, her anger was completely justifiable.

Justification.definition: The action of showing something to be right or reasonable.
Justification.example: He offered no justification for his rude behavior.

Justly.definition: According to what is morally right or fair; deservedly.
Justly.example: The team was justly proud of their hard-earned victory.

Juvenile.definition: Of, for, or relating to young people; childish or immature.
Juvenile.example: His juvenile sense of humor was not appreciated in the professional setting.

Kaffeeklatsch.definition: An informal social gathering for coffee and conversation.
Kaffeeklatsch.example: The weekly kaffeeklatsch was a cherished tradition for the neighborhood friends.

Kairos.definition: A propitious moment for decision or action; the opportune time.
Kairos.example: The general recognized the kairos and ordered the decisive attack.

Kaiser.definition: The German emperor, the emperor of Austria, or the head of the Holy Roman Empire.
Kaiser.example: Kaiser Wilhelm II was the last German Emperor and King of Prussia.

Kakistocracy.definition: Government by the least suitable or competent citizens of a state.
Kakistocracy.example: The citizens feared their nation was descending into a kakistocracy, led by corrupt and inept officials.

Kalology.definition: The philosophical study of beauty and its nature.
Kalology.example: His interest in kalology led him to study aesthetics and the principles of artistic creation.

Kalopsia.definition: A condition in which things seem more beautiful than they really are.
Kalopsia.example: His nostalgic kalopsia made him remember his grim childhood as a wonderful adventure.

Karat.definition: A measure of the purity of gold, with pure gold being 24 karats.
Karat.example: She inherited a beautiful 18-karat gold necklace from her grandmother.

Katabasis.definition: A descent, such as a military retreat, a journey to the underworld, or a decline in status.
Katabasis.example: The hero's katabasis into the underworld was a crucial part of his epic journey.

Keck.definition: To retch or feel as if about to vomit.
Keck.example: The foul smell from the garbage can made him keck.

Keel.definition: To capsize or turn over; also, the main structural member of a ship.
Keel.example: The sudden, violent gust of wind caused the small sailboat to keel over.

Keen.definition: Having or showing eagerness or enthusiasm; sharp or penetrating.
Keen.example: She has a keen intellect and a great sense of humor.

Keep.definition: The strongest or most secure part of a castle, often used as a final refuge.
Keep.example: The royal family retreated to the keep when the castle walls were breached.

Keepsake.definition: A small item kept in memory of the person who gave it or the occasion on which it was received.
Keepsake.example: He treasured the old watch as a keepsake from his grandfather.

Keiretsu.definition: A network of businesses with interlocking business relationships and shareholdings, common in Japan.
Keiretsu.example: The company was part of a large keiretsu, which gave it significant advantages in the market.

Ken.definition: One's range of knowledge or sight.
Ken.example: The complex workings of quantum physics are beyond my ken.

Kennel.definition: A small shelter for a dog or cat; a place where dogs are bred or boarded.
Kennel.example: We left our dog at the kennel while we went on vacation.

Kerfuffle.definition: A commotion or fuss, especially one caused by conflicting views.
Kerfuffle.example: There was a kerfuffle at the meeting when the controversial new policy was announced.

Kernel.definition: The central or most important part of something.
Kernel.example: The kernel of his argument was that the plan was financially unsustainable.

Kerygma.definition: The apostolic proclamation of salvation through Jesus Christ.
Kerygma.example: The core kerygma of the early church focused on the death and resurrection of Jesus.

Keynote.definition: A prevailing tone or central theme in a speech, literary work, or conference.
Keynote.example: The keynote of the president's speech was the need for national unity.

Keystone.definition: A central stone at the summit of an arch, locking the whole together; the central principle of a system.
Keystone.example: Trust is the keystone of any healthy relationship.

Kibble.definition: Ground meal shaped into pellets, especially for pet food.
Kibble.example: The dog eagerly crunched on his morning kibble.

Kibbutz.definition: A collective community in Israel that was traditionally based on agriculture.
Kibbutz.example: She spent a year volunteering on a kibbutz in northern Israel.

Kibitzer.definition: A person who offers unwanted advice or commentary, especially at a card game.
Kibitzer.example: The chess players were annoyed by a kibitzer who kept suggesting moves.

Kibosh.definition: To put an end to; to halt or squelch.
Kibosh.example: The city council put the kibosh on the plan to build a new stadium.

Kickback.definition: A secret, illicit payment made to someone who has facilitated a transaction or appointment.
Kickback.example: The politician was accused of accepting kickbacks in exchange for government contracts.

Kick-off.definition: The start or beginning of an event or process.
Kick-off.example: The kick-off for the new marketing campaign is scheduled for next Monday.

Killjoy.definition: A person who deliberately spoils the enjoyment of others.
Killjoy.example: Don't be such a killjoy; let them have their fun.

Kiln.definition: A furnace or oven for burning, baking, or drying, especially one for firing pottery.
Kiln.example: The potter carefully placed the clay pots into the kiln.

Kilter.example: The unexpected news threw his carefully laid plans out of kilter.

Kin.example: She felt a deep sense of loyalty to her kin.

Kindhearted.definition: Having a kind and sympathetic nature.
Kindhearted.example: The kindhearted stranger offered to help the lost tourist.

Kindle.definition: To arouse or inspire an emotion or feeling; to set on fire.
Kindle.example: The speaker's passionate words kindled a sense of hope in the audience.

Kindred.definition: Similar in kind; related. Often used in the phrase 'kindred spirits'.
Kindred.example: They were kindred spirits, sharing a love for art and literature.

Kinematics.definition: The branch of mechanics concerned with the motion of objects without reference to the forces which cause the motion.
Kinematics.example: In physics class, we studied the kinematics of projectile motion.

Kinesis.definition: Movement; motion, especially in response to a stimulus.
Kinesis.example: The study of cellular kinesis is fundamental to understanding cell division.

Kinetic.definition: Relating to or resulting from motion.
Kinetic.example: The kinetic energy of a moving object is proportional to its mass and the square of its velocity.

Kingmaker.definition: A person or group that has great influence on a royal or political succession, without being a viable candidate themselves.
Kingmaker.example: The influential senator was seen as a kingmaker in the upcoming presidential election.

Kingpin.definition: A person or thing that is essential to the success of an organization or operation.
Kingpin.example: The police finally arrested the kingpin of the international drug cartel.

Kingship.definition: The state, office, or dignity of a king.
Kingship.example: The novel explored the burdens and responsibilities of kingship.

Kink.definition: A flaw, twist, or imperfection in a plan or system.
Kink.example: We need to iron out a few kinks in the software before the official launch.

Kinsfolk.example: During the holidays, the house was filled with kinsfolk from all over the country.

Kiosk.definition: A small open-fronted hut or cubicle from which newspapers, refreshments, or tickets are sold.
Kiosk.example: I bought a magazine from a kiosk at the train station.

Kismet.example: It was kismet that they met on that rainy day in Paris.

Kiss-off.definition: A dismissal or rejection, often abrupt or contemptuous.
Kiss-off.example: After a brief interview, he was given a polite but firm kiss-off.

Kitchen-sink.definition: Relating to a style of drama or art characterized by sordid, mundane realism.
Kitchen-sink.example: The film was a classic example of kitchen-sink drama, focusing on the struggles of a working-class family.

Kith.example: He invited all his kith and kin to the wedding celebration.

Kitsch.definition: Art, objects, or design considered to be in poor taste because of excessive garishness or sentimentality, but sometimes appreciated in an ironic way.
Kitsch.example: Her apartment was filled with flamingo-themed kitsch from the 1950s.

Kitschy.definition: Having the quality of being kitsch; tastelessly showy.
Kitschy.example: The souvenir shop sold all sorts of kitschy trinkets and memorabilia.

Kittenish.definition: Playful, lively, or flirtatious, like a kitten.
Kittenish.example: Her kittenish behavior charmed everyone at the party.

Kleptocracy.definition: A government with corrupt leaders (kleptocrats) that use their power to exploit the people and natural resources of their own territory in order to extend their personal wealth and political power.
Kleptocracy.example: Under the dictator's rule, the nation became a kleptocracy, with billions of dollars siphoned into foreign bank accounts.

Kleptomania.definition: A recurrent urge to steal, typically without regard for need or profit.
Kleptomania.example: The wealthy socialite was diagnosed with kleptomania after being caught shoplifting.

Kludge.definition: An ill-assorted collection of parts assembled to fulfill a particular purpose; a clumsy or inelegant solution to a problem.
Kludge.example: The programmer admitted that his code was a kludge, but it worked well enough for the demonstration.

Knack.definition: An acquired or natural skill at performing a task; a clever trick.
Knack.example: She has a knack for making people feel at ease.

Knacker.definition: A person whose business is the disposal of dead or unwanted animals, especially those whose flesh is not fit for human consumption.
Knacker.example: In the old days, a farmer would call the knacker to dispose of a horse that had died.

Knapsack.definition: A bag with shoulder straps, carried on the back, and typically made of canvas or other weatherproof material.
Knapsack.example: The hiker carried all his supplies in a sturdy knapsack.

Knave.example: He was a charming but ultimately untrustworthy knave.

Knavery.definition: Unprincipled, untrustworthy, or dishonest dealing; trickery.
Knavery.example: The villain's plot was full of knavery and deceit.

Knavish.definition: Dishonest or unscrupulous; characteristic of a knave.
Knavish.example: The swindler's knavish charm fooled many unsuspecting investors.

Knead.definition: To work dough or clay into a uniform mixture by pressing, folding, and stretching.
Knead.example: The baker had to knead the dough for ten minutes before letting it rise.

Knee-jerk.example: His knee-jerk reaction was to deny any involvement, even before he heard the full story.

Knell.definition: The sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral.
Knell.example: The distant knell of the church bell signaled the end of the day.

Knick-knack.definition: A small worthless object, especially a household ornament or trinket.
Knick-knack.example: The shelves were cluttered with various knick-knacks from her travels.

Knight-errant.definition: A medieval knight wandering in search of chivalrous adventures.
Knight-errant.example: Don Quixote imagined himself as a noble knight-errant, righting wrongs across the land.

Knight-errantry.definition: The deeds or characteristic behavior of a knight-errant; chivalrous or quixotic conduct.
Knight-errantry.example: His idealistic attempts to save the company were a modern form of knight-errantry.

Knightly.definition: Pertaining to or befitting a knight; chivalrous, brave, and honorable.
Knightly.example: He followed a knightly code of conduct, always treating others with respect.

Knit.definition: To unite or cause to unite; to make a garment by interlocking loops of wool.
Knit.example: The community was closely knit by shared traditions and values.

Knobby.example: The old tree had a gnarled, knobby trunk.

Knockabout.definition: Characterized by boisterous, physical comedy or rough, boisterous action.
Knockabout.example: The play was a piece of knockabout farce that had the audience in stitches.

Knock-down.definition: Irrefutable or overwhelming; (of a price) very low.
Knock-down.example: The prosecutor presented a knock-down argument that convinced the jury.

Knockoff.definition: A copy or imitation, especially of an expensive or designer product.
Knockoff.example: She bought a cheap knockoff of the designer handbag in a street market.

Knoll.example: They had a picnic on a grassy knoll overlooking the valley.

Knot.definition: A complex problem or an entanglement.
Knot.example: The legal dispute was a tangled knot of conflicting claims.

Knotty.definition: Full of knots; complex; difficult to solve.
Knotty.example: The committee was tasked with resolving the knotty problem of budget allocation.

Knout.definition: A whip with a lash of leather thongs, formerly used in Russia for flogging criminals.
Knout.example: The historical novel described the brutal punishment of prisoners with the knout.

Know-how.example: He has the technical know-how to fix any computer problem.

Knowing.definition: Showing or suggesting that one has secret knowledge or awareness.
Knowing.example: She gave him a knowing glance when the topic of the surprise party came up.

Knowledgeable.example: Our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable about the city's history.

Knuckle down.definition: To start working or studying hard.
Knuckle down.example: With exams just a week away, it's time to knuckle down and study.

Knuckle under.definition: To submit or yield to pressure or authority.
Knuckle under.example: The small company had to knuckle under to the demands of the large corporation.

Knurled.definition: Having a pattern of small ridges or grooves to assist gripping.
Knurled.example: The knurled knob on the radio was easy to turn even with gloves on.

Kook.example: The town eccentric was considered a harmless kook by the locals.

Kooky.definition: Eccentric, strange, or foolish in an amusing way.
Kooky.example: She had a kooky sense of style that was all her own.

Kosher.definition: Genuine and legitimate; satisfying the requirements of Jewish law.
Kosher.example: He checked to make sure the business deal was completely kosher.

Kowtow.definition: To act in an excessively subservient manner; to bow in a servile way.
Kowtow.example: He refused to kowtow to the whims of the demanding celebrity.

Kraal.definition: A traditional African village of huts, typically enclosed by a fence; an enclosure for cattle or sheep.
Kraal.example: The cattle were herded into the kraal for the night.

Kraken.definition: A legendary sea monster of giant size, said to dwell off the coasts of Norway and Greenland.
Kraken.example: Sailors of old told terrifying tales of the kraken dragging ships to the bottom of the sea.

Kremlin.definition: A citadel within a Russian town; often used to refer to the Russian government.
Kremlin.example: The Kremlin announced a new foreign policy initiative.

Krummholz.definition: Stunted, windblown trees growing at high altitudes or in alpine regions, near the treeline.
Krummholz.example: As they ascended the mountain, the tall pines gave way to a dense forest of krummholz.

Kudos.definition: Praise and honor received for an achievement.
Kudos.example: Kudos to the team for finishing the project ahead of schedule.

Kudize.example: The critics were quick to kudize the young author's brilliant debut novel.

Kukri.definition: A heavy, curved knife of Nepalese origin.
Kukri.example: The Gurkha soldiers are famous for their skill with the kukri.

Kulak.definition: A wealthy or prosperous peasant in the later Russian Empire and early Soviet Union.
Kulak.example: Under Stalin's collectivization policy, the kulaks were targeted as class enemies.

Kultur.definition: A nation's culture, civilization, and achievements, especially as conceived by German nationalists.
Kultur.example: The propaganda of the era emphasized the superiority of German Kultur.

Kurtosis.definition: A statistical measure that defines how heavily the tails of a distribution differ from the tails of a normal distribution.
Kurtosis.example: The financial analyst noted the high kurtosis of the stock's returns, indicating a high probability of extreme outcomes.

Kvell.definition: To be extraordinarily pleased; to burst with pride, as over a child's accomplishment.
Kvell.example: She couldn't help but kvell as her daughter accepted the award on stage.

Kvetch.example: He would kvetch for hours about the slightest inconvenience.

Kyphosis.definition: Excessive outward curvature of the spine, causing hunching of the back.
Kyphosis.example: Poor posture over many years can contribute to the development of kyphosis.

Kyrie.definition: A short, repeated invocation or prayer, used in many Christian liturgies.
Kyrie.example: The choir's haunting rendition of the Kyrie moved the congregation to tears.

Kymograph.definition: A scientific instrument that graphically records variations in pressure or motion.
Kymograph.example: The physiologist used a kymograph to record the muscle contractions.

Labyrinthine.definition: Intricately winding, complex, and confusing, like a labyrinth.
Labyrinthine.example: The old city's labyrinthine streets were easy to get lost in.

Laconic.definition: Using very few words; concise to the point of seeming rude or mysterious.
Laconic.example: His laconic reply of 'fine' did little to reassure me.

Lachrymose.definition: Tearful or given to weeping; inducing tears or sadness.
Lachrymose.example: The lachrymose film had the entire audience in tears by the end.

Lackadaisical.definition: Lacking enthusiasm and determination; carelessly lazy.
Lackadaisical.example: His lackadaisical attitude towards his studies resulted in poor grades.

Laity.definition: Lay people, as distinct from the clergy or professionals.
Laity.example: The new church policies were discussed with both the clergy and the laity.

Lambaste.definition: To criticize someone or something harshly.
Lambaste.example: The coach lambasted the team for their poor performance in the championship game.

Lament.definition: To express passionate grief or sorrow; to mourn.
Lament.example: She lamented the loss of her childhood home to the fire.

Lampoon.definition: To publicly criticize someone or something by using ridicule, irony, or sarcasm.
Lampoon.example: The satirical show was famous for its hilarious lampoon of political figures.

Languid.definition: Displaying a disinclination for physical exertion; slow and relaxed.
Languid.example: They spent a languid afternoon dozing by the pool.

Languish.definition: To lose or lack vitality; to grow weak or feeble.
Languish.example: The plant languished in the dark corner, deprived of sunlight.

Lapidary.definition: Relating to the engraving, cutting, or polishing of stones and gems; concise and elegant in style.
Lapidary.example: His lapidary prose was both beautiful and efficient.

Largesse.definition: Generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others.
Largesse.example: The university was able to build a new library thanks to the largesse of a wealthy alumnus.

Lascivious.definition: Feeling or revealing an overt and often offensive sexual desire.
Lascivious.example: He was fired for making lascivious comments to his coworkers.

Lassitude.definition: A state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy.
Lassitude.example: A feeling of lassitude washed over her after the long, stressful week.

Latent.definition: Existing but not yet developed or manifest; hidden or concealed.
Latent.example: He had a latent talent for music that only emerged in his late twenties.

Laud.definition: To praise a person or their achievements highly, especially in a public context.
Laud.example: The critics lauded the author's new novel as a masterpiece.

Laudable.example: Her efforts to raise money for the homeless were truly laudable.

Lavish.definition: Sumptuously rich, elaborate, or luxurious; to bestow something in generous quantities.
Lavish.example: They threw a lavish party to celebrate their anniversary.

Lax.definition: Not sufficiently strict, severe, or careful.
Lax.example: The company's lax security measures led to a major data breach.

Lecherous.definition: Having or showing excessive or offensive sexual desire.
Lecherous.example: The old man's lecherous gaze made her feel extremely uncomfortable.

Leery.definition: Cautious or wary due to realistic suspicions.
Leery.example: I've always been leery of offers that seem too good to be true.

Legacy.definition: Something handed down from the past; a bequest.
Legacy.example: The artist left behind a legacy of beautiful paintings and a generous donation to the arts.

Legerdemain.definition: Skillful use of one's hands when performing conjuring tricks; deception.
Legerdemain.example: The magician's legerdemain was so convincing that the audience was left speechless.

Legion.definition: A vast number of people or things.
Legion.example: Her fans are legion, spanning multiple generations and countries.

Lenient.definition: Merciful or tolerant; not harsh or strict.
Lenient.example: The lenient judge gave the first-time offender community service instead of jail time.

Lethargy.definition: A lack of energy and enthusiasm; sluggishness.
Lethargy.example: Symptoms of the illness include fever, headache, and lethargy.

Levity.definition: The treatment of a serious matter with humor or in a manner lacking due respect.
Levity.example: He tried to introduce a bit of levity into the somber meeting, but his joke fell flat.

Levy.definition: To impose a tax, fee, or fine.
Levy.example: The government decided to levy a new tax on sugary drinks.

Lewd.definition: Crude and offensive in a sexual way.
Lewd.example: He was arrested for making lewd gestures at passersby.

Lexicon.definition: The vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge.
Lexicon.example: The lexicon of a computer scientist includes terms like 'algorithm' and 'bandwidth'.

Liability.definition: The state of being responsible for something, especially by law; a person or thing whose presence is likely to cause embarrassment or put one at a disadvantage.
Liability.example: His gambling addiction made him a liability to the company.

Liaison.definition: Communication or cooperation that facilitates a close working relationship between people or organizations.
Liaison.example: She acts as a liaison between the management and the employees.

Libel.definition: A published false statement that is damaging to a person's reputation; a written defamation.
Libel.example: The celebrity sued the tabloid for libel after it printed false stories about her.

Libertine.definition: A person who behaves without moral principles, especially in sexual matters.
Libertine.example: He was a known libertine, famous for his decadent parties and scandalous affairs.

Libidinous.example: The novel was criticized for its overly libidinous characters.

Licentious.definition: Promiscuous and unprincipled in sexual matters; disregarding accepted rules.
Licentious.example: The ruler's licentious behavior shocked the conservative court.

Lien.definition: A right to keep possession of property belonging to another person until a debt owed by that person is discharged.
Lien.example: The bank placed a lien on his house after he defaulted on his loan.

Liminal.definition: Relating to a transitional or initial stage of a process; occupying a position at a boundary or threshold.
Liminal.example: Adolescence is a liminal stage between childhood and adulthood.

Limn.definition: To depict or describe in paint or words.
Limn.example: The author's vivid prose managed to limn the city's vibrant street life perfectly.

Limpid.definition: Completely clear and transparent, as in water or air; (of writing) easily understood.
Limpid.example: We could see the fish swimming in the limpid stream.

Lineage.definition: Direct descent from an ancestor; ancestry or pedigree.
Lineage.example: She was proud of her royal lineage and traced her family tree back for centuries.

Lingua franca.definition: A language that is adopted as a common language between speakers whose native languages are different.
Lingua franca.example: English has become the lingua franca of international business and science.

Lionize.definition: To give a lot of public attention and approval to someone; to treat as a celebrity.
Lionize.example: After his heroic rescue, the firefighter was lionized by the media.

Lissome.example: The lissome ballet dancer moved across the stage with effortless grace.

Listless.example: The hot, humid weather made everyone feel listless and tired.

Litany.definition: A tedious recital or repetitive series.
Litany.example: He went into a long litany of complaints about his job.

Lithe.example: The lithe gymnast performed a flawless routine on the balance beam.

Litigate.definition: To resort to legal action to settle a matter; to be a party to a lawsuit.
Litigate.example: He threatened to litigate if the company did not offer a fair settlement.

Litigious.definition: Unreasonably prone to go to law to settle disputes; concerned with lawsuits.
Litigious.example: Their litigious neighbor sued them over a tree branch that hung over his property.

Livid.definition: Furiously angry; dark bluish-gray in color, like a bruise.
Livid.example: She was livid when she discovered he had lied to her.

Loath.example: I was loath to admit that I had made a mistake.

Loathe.definition: To feel intense dislike or disgust for.
Loathe.example: I loathe people who are cruel to animals.

Lofty.definition: Of imposing height; of a noble or exalted nature; haughty and aloof.
Lofty.example: He had lofty ambitions of becoming a world-renowned scientist.

Logorrhea.example: The patient's logorrhea made it difficult for the doctor to get a word in.

Loquacious.definition: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative.
Loquacious.example: My loquacious aunt can talk for hours without taking a breath.

Lucid.definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand; showing ability to think clearly.
Lucid.example: Despite his high fever, he was lucid and able to answer all our questions.

Lucrative.definition: Producing a great deal of profit.
Lucrative.example: He left his teaching job for a more lucrative career in finance.

Lucre.definition: Money, especially when regarded as sordid or distasteful or gained in a dishonorable way.
Lucre.example: He was blinded by the pursuit of lucre and abandoned all his principles.

Lucubrate.definition: To write or study, especially by night; to produce scholarly work.
Lucubrate.example: The professor would lucubrate in his study for hours, surrounded by stacks of books.

Ludicrous.definition: So foolish, unreasonable, or out of place as to be amusing; ridiculous.
Ludicrous.example: The idea of a dog running for mayor is completely ludicrous.

Lugubrious.definition: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
Lugubrious.example: The lugubrious music at the funeral only deepened our sorrow.

Lukewarm.definition: Only moderately warm; showing little enthusiasm.
Lukewarm.example: The audience gave the mediocre performance a lukewarm reception.

Luminary.definition: A person who inspires or influences others, especially one prominent in a particular sphere.
Luminary.example: Stephen Hawking was a luminary in the field of theoretical physics.

Luminous.definition: Emitting or reflecting light; shining; bright or shining, especially in the dark.
Luminous.example: The full moon cast a luminous glow over the landscape.

Lummox.example: The big lummox tripped over his own feet and knocked over the vase.

Lurch.definition: To make an abrupt, unsteady, uncontrolled movement or series of movements; stagger.
Lurch.example: The train lurched forward, and I almost lost my balance.

Lurid.definition: Very vivid in color, especially so as to create an unpleasantly harsh or unnatural effect; presented in shocking or sensational terms.
Lurid.example: The tabloids printed lurid details of the celebrity's private life.

Lustrous.example: She brushed her hair until it was smooth and lustrous.

Luxuriant.definition: Rich and profuse in growth; lush.
Luxuriant.example: The tropical island was covered in luxuriant vegetation.

Luxuriate.definition: To enjoy oneself in a luxurious way; to take self-indulgent delight.
Luxuriate.example: After a long week, she wanted nothing more than to luxuriate in a hot bath.

Lyrical.definition: Expressing the writer's emotions in an imaginative and beautiful way.
Lyrical.example: The poet's lyrical descriptions of nature captivated the audience.

Labile.example: Because the enzyme was labile, it had to be kept at a very low temperature.

Lacuna.definition: An unfilled space or interval; a gap in a manuscript, argument, or series.
Lacuna.example: There is a lacuna in the historical record, leaving the events of that year a mystery.

Laic.definition: Relating to lay people and not to the clergy; secular.
Laic.example: The new education policy was a laic initiative, separate from religious institutions.

Lagniappe.definition: Something given as a bonus or extra gift.
Lagniappe.example: The friendly baker always added a lagniappe of a small cookie to every purchase.

Lamellar.definition: Composed of or arranged in thin layers or plates.
Lamellar.example: Mica is a mineral with a lamellar structure, easily splitting into thin sheets.

Lanceolate.definition: Shaped like a lance head; tapering to a point at each end.
Lanceolate.example: The botanist identified the plant by its distinctive lanceolate leaves.

Langsyne.definition: Long ago; in the distant past.
Langsyne.example: He often reminisced about the friends of langsyne.

Lanuginous.definition: Covered with down or fine soft hair.
Lanuginous.example: The lanuginous leaves of the plant felt like velvet.

Lapidate.example: In some ancient societies, the punishment for certain crimes was to lapidate the offender.

Larceny.example: He was charged with grand larceny for stealing the valuable painting.

Latency.definition: The state of existing but not yet being developed or manifest.
Latency.example: The latency period of the disease can be several weeks.

Lateral.definition: Of, at, towards, or from the side or sides.
Lateral.example: He made a lateral move to a different department but kept the same job title.

Laudatory.example: The film received laudatory reviews from all the major critics.

Legate.definition: A member of the clergy, especially a cardinal, representing the Pope; an envoy or messenger.
Legate.example: The papal legate was sent to mediate the dispute between the two kingdoms.

Legitimist.definition: A supporter of legitimate authority, especially that of a monarch.
Legitimist.example: The legitimists argued for the restoration of the deposed royal family.

Leitmotif.definition: A recurrent theme throughout a musical or literary composition, associated with a particular person, idea, or situation.
Leitmotif.example: The ominous leitmotif played every time the villain appeared on screen.

Leonine.definition: Of or resembling a lion or lions.
Leonine.example: The old patriarch had a magnificent, leonine head of white hair.

Leporine.definition: Of or resembling a hare or hares.
Leporine.example: She had a distinctive leporine nose and a quick, twitchy way of moving.

Lexicography.example: His lifelong passion for words led him to a career in lexicography.

Libation.definition: A drink poured out as an offering to a deity.
Libation.example: Before drinking, the ancient Greeks would pour a libation to the gods.

Libretto.definition: The text of an opera or other long vocal work.
Libretto.example: While the music was beautiful, many critics found the opera's libretto to be weak.

Macerate.definition: To soften or break up something by soaking it in a liquid.
Macerate.example: The chef decided to macerate the berries in sugar and liqueur to create a rich dessert topping.

Machiavellian.definition: Cunning, scheming, and unscrupulous, especially in politics or in advancing one's career.
Machiavellian.example: His Machiavellian tactics to gain power involved betraying his closest allies.

Machination.definition: A crafty and involved plot or scheme, usually with a sinister purpose.
Machination.example: The conspirators' machinations to overthrow the government were discovered at the last minute.

Macabre.definition: Disturbing and horrifying because of involvement with or depiction of death and injury.
Macabre.example: The macabre stories of Edgar Allan Poe are famous for their dark and gruesome themes.

Magnanimous.definition: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or someone less powerful than oneself.
Magnanimous.example: The magnanimous victor offered a hand of friendship to his defeated opponent.

Magnate.definition: A wealthy and influential person, especially in business.
Magnate.example: The shipping magnate owned a fleet of over a hundred vessels.

Maladroit.example: His maladroit handling of the situation only made matters worse.

Malady.example: In the 19th century, many people succumbed to a malady that is now easily curable.

Malaise.definition: A general feeling of discomfort, illness, or uneasiness whose exact cause is difficult to identify.
Malaise.example: A sense of malaise and economic uncertainty spread throughout the country.

Malediction.definition: A magical word or phrase uttered with the intention of bringing about evil; a curse.
Malediction.example: The witch uttered a malediction against the royal family.

Malefactor.definition: A person who commits a crime or some other wrong.
Malefactor.example: The police apprehended the malefactor responsible for the series of robberies.

Malevolent.definition: Having or showing a wish to do evil to others.
Malevolent.example: The villain in the story had a malevolent grin that sent shivers down the hero's spine.

Malfeasance.definition: Wrongdoing, especially by a public official.
Malfeasance.example: The mayor was impeached for malfeasance after the corruption scandal was exposed.

Malign.definition: To speak about someone in a spitefully critical manner; evil in nature or effect.
Malign.example: I cannot believe he would malign his former friend in public just to get ahead.

Malinger.definition: To exaggerate or feign illness in order to escape duty or work.
Malinger.example: The soldier was accused of malingering to avoid being sent to the front lines.

Malleable.definition: Easily influenced; pliable; or able to be hammered or pressed into shape without breaking.
Malleable.example: The young student's mind was malleable and open to new ideas.

Mandate.definition: An official order or commission to do something; the authority to carry out a policy.
Mandate.example: The government was given a clear mandate by the voters to reform the healthcare system.

Manifold.example: The manifold challenges of the project required a team with diverse skills.

Manifest.definition: Clear or obvious to the eye or mind; to display or show a quality or feeling.
Manifest.example: Her relief was manifest on her face when she heard the good news.

Manifesto.definition: A public declaration of policy and aims, especially one issued before an election by a political party or candidate.
Manifesto.example: The party's manifesto included promises of tax cuts and increased public spending.

Marginalize.definition: To treat a person, group, or concept as insignificant or peripheral.
Marginalize.example: The new policies unfortunately served to marginalize the poorest communities.

Mar.definition: To impair the appearance of; to disfigure or spoil.
Mar.example: A single scratch can mar the surface of a polished table.

Martinet.definition: A strict disciplinarian, especially in the armed forces.
Martinet.example: The drill sergeant was a martinet who demanded absolute obedience from his recruits.

Matriculate.definition: To be enrolled at a college or university.
Matriculate.example: After years of hard work, she was thrilled to matriculate at her dream university.

Maudlin.definition: Self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental, often through drunkenness.
Maudlin.example: The film became maudlin and overly sentimental in its final scenes.

Maverick.example: He was a maverick in the political party, often voting against the official platform.

Mawkish.definition: Sentimental in a feeble or sickly way.
Mawkish.example: The poet's mawkish verses about love were met with groans from the audience.

Maxim.definition: A short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct.
Maxim.example: He lived his life by the maxim, 'Actions speak louder than words.'

Meager.example: They had to survive on a meager ration of bread and water.

Meander.definition: To follow a winding course; to wander at random.
Meander.example: The river began to meander through the lush, green valley.

Meddlesome.example: Her meddlesome aunt was always giving unsolicited advice about her personal life.

Mediocre.definition: Of only moderate quality; not very good.
Mediocre.example: The team's performance was mediocre, and they finished in the middle of the league.

Melancholy.definition: A feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause.
Melancholy.example: A deep melancholy settled over him after his friend moved away.

Mellifluous.definition: Pleasingly smooth and musical to hear.
Mellifluous.example: The mellifluous sound of the cello filled the concert hall.

Mendacious.example: The mendacious politician was caught in a web of his own deceit.

Mendicant.example: In the city square, a mendicant friar asked passersby for alms.

Menial.definition: Not requiring much skill and lacking prestige.
Menial.example: He had to perform menial tasks like scrubbing floors and washing dishes.

Mercurial.definition: Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.
Mercurial.example: Her mercurial temperament made it difficult to know how she would react to the news.

Meretricious.definition: Apparently attractive but having in reality no value or integrity.
Meretricious.example: The meretricious decorations looked flashy but were made of cheap plastic.

Meritorious.example: Her meritorious service to the community was recognized with an award.

Mesmerize.definition: To hold the attention of someone to the exclusion of all else or so as to transfix them.
Mesmerize.example: The magician's incredible tricks seemed to mesmerize the entire audience.

Metamorphosis.definition: A change of the form or nature of a thing or person into a completely different one.
Metamorphosis.example: The caterpillar's metamorphosis into a butterfly is a marvel of nature.

Metaphysical.definition: Relating to the branch of philosophy that deals with the first principles of things, including abstract concepts such as being, knowing, substance, cause, identity, time, and space.
Metaphysical.example: The poet John Donne is known for his metaphysical conceits and complex imagery.

Meticulous.definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
Meticulous.example: The meticulous researcher checked every data point three times to ensure accuracy.

Mettle.definition: A person's ability to cope well with difficulties or to face a demanding situation in a spirited and resilient way.
Mettle.example: The young soldier proved his mettle in battle.

Miasma.definition: A highly unpleasant or unhealthy smell or vapor; an oppressive or unpleasant atmosphere.
Miasma.example: A miasma of despair hung over the city after the devastating flood.

Microcosm.definition: A miniature representation of a larger world or system.
Microcosm.example: The small island community was a microcosm of the country as a whole.

Mien.definition: A person's look or manner, especially one of a particular kind indicating their character or mood.
Mien.example: He had a cautious and serious mien, which made him seem older than he was.

Militate.definition: To be a powerful or conclusive factor in preventing something.
Militate.example: His lack of experience will militate against his chances of getting the job.

Minatory.example: The dictator delivered a minatory speech, warning of severe consequences for any dissent.

Minuscule.example: The chances of winning the lottery are minuscule.

Mirth.definition: Amusement, especially as expressed in laughter.
Mirth.example: The comedian's jokes filled the room with mirth.

Misanthrope.definition: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
Misanthrope.example: The old man was a misanthrope who lived alone and chased children off his lawn.

Misapprehension.definition: A mistaken belief about or interpretation of something; a misunderstanding.
Misapprehension.example: I was under the misapprehension that the meeting was scheduled for tomorrow.

Misconstrue.definition: To interpret something, especially a person's words or actions, wrongly.
Misconstrue.example: He did not want the reporter to misconstrue his comments, so he spoke very carefully.

Miscreant.definition: A person who behaves badly or in a way that breaks the law.
Miscreant.example: The miscreant was finally caught after a long and difficult police investigation.

Misgiving.definition: A feeling of doubt or apprehension about the outcome or consequences of something.
Misgiving.example: Despite her reassurances, I had a deep misgiving about the plan.

Misnomer.definition: A wrong or inaccurate name or designation.
Misnomer.example: Calling the tiny, aggressive dog 'Fluffy' was a hilarious misnomer.

Mitigate.definition: To make less severe, serious, or painful.
Mitigate.example: The company took steps to mitigate the environmental damage caused by the oil spill.

Mnemonic.definition: A device such as a pattern of letters, ideas, or associations that assists in remembering something.
Mnemonic.example: He used the mnemonic 'ROY G. BIV' to remember the colors of the rainbow.

Modicum.definition: A small quantity of a particular thing, especially something considered desirable or valuable.
Modicum.example: If he had a modicum of common sense, he wouldn't have made that decision.

Modish.definition: Conforming to or following what is currently popular and fashionable.
Modish.example: She wore a modish dress that was the latest trend from Paris.

Modulate.definition: To exert a modifying or controlling influence on; regulate or adjust.
Modulate.example: He learned to modulate his voice to be more persuasive during presentations.

Mollify.definition: To appease the anger or anxiety of someone.
Mollify.example: The manager tried to mollify the angry customer with a full refund and an apology.

Momentous.definition: Of great importance or significance, especially in its bearing on the future.
Momentous.example: The signing of the peace treaty was a momentous occasion for both nations.

Monastic.definition: Relating to monks, nuns, or monasteries; resembling the simple, austere life of a monk.
Monastic.example: He lived a monastic existence, dedicated entirely to his research.

Monolithic.definition: Large, powerful, and intractably indivisible and uniform.
Monolithic.example: The monolithic corporation was slow to adapt to changes in the market.

Monotony.definition: Lack of variety and interest; tedious repetition and routine.
Monotony.example: She longed for a vacation to break the monotony of her daily life.

Morass.definition: A complicated or confused situation; a swamp or bog.
Morass.example: The legal case was a morass of conflicting testimony and evidence.

Moratorium.definition: A temporary prohibition of an activity.
Moratorium.example: The government declared a moratorium on all new construction in the protected area.

Morbid.definition: Characterized by an abnormal and unhealthy interest in disturbing and unpleasant subjects, especially death and disease.
Morbid.example: He had a morbid fascination with the details of the crime.

Mordant.definition: Having or showing a sharp or critical quality; biting (especially of humor).
Mordant.example: The talk show host was famous for her mordant wit and sarcastic commentary.

Mores.definition: The essential or characteristic customs and conventions of a community.
Mores.example: The novel explores the changing social mores of early 20th-century America.

Moribund.definition: At the point of death; in terminal decline.
Moribund.example: The moribund industry was struggling to compete with new technologies.

Morose.example: He became morose and withdrawn after losing his job.

Motley.definition: Incongruously varied in appearance or character; disparate.
Motley.example: The conference was attended by a motley crew of academics, artists, and entrepreneurs.

Mottled.definition: Marked with spots or smears of color.
Mottled.example: The snake's skin was mottled with shades of green and brown.

Mountebank.definition: A person who deceives others, especially in order to trick them out of their money; a charlatan.
Mountebank.example: The mountebank sold 'miracle cures' from the back of his wagon.

Multifarious.definition: Having many varied parts or aspects.
Multifarious.example: New York is a multifarious city with a diverse population and endless activities.

Mundane.example: He longed for adventure to escape his mundane, nine-to-five existence.

Munificent.definition: Larger or more generous than is usual or necessary.
Munificent.example: The munificent donation from the anonymous benefactor saved the struggling art museum.

Murky.definition: Dark and gloomy, especially due to thick mist; obscure or morally questionable.
Murky.example: The politician has a murky past involving several financial scandals.

Muse.definition: To be absorbed in thought; a person or personified force who is the source of inspiration for a creative artist.
Muse.example: The artist would often sit by the lake and muse for hours, waiting for inspiration.

Muster.definition: To collect or assemble (a number or amount); to summon up (a particular feeling, attitude, or response).
Muster.example: She finally mustered the courage to ask for a raise.

Mutinous.definition: Refusing to obey the orders of a person in authority; rebellious.
Mutinous.example: The mutinous sailors took control of the ship from the captain.

Myopic.definition: Nearsighted; lacking imagination, foresight, or intellectual insight.
Myopic.example: The company's myopic focus on short-term profits led to its eventual downfall.

Myriad.definition: A countless or extremely great number.
Myriad.example: A myriad of stars filled the clear night sky.

Mystify.definition: To utterly bewilder or perplex someone.
Mystify.example: The strange disappearance of the airplane continues to mystify investigators.

Myth.definition: A traditional story concerning the early history of a people or explaining some natural or social phenomenon, and typically involving supernatural beings or events; a widely held but false belief.
Myth.example: It is a popular myth that lightning never strikes the same place twice.

Nadir.definition: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization.
Nadir.example: The company's fortunes reached their nadir during the economic recession.

Nascent.definition: Just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential.
Nascent.example: The nascent tech industry in the city shows great promise for economic growth.

Nebulous.definition: In the form of a cloud or haze; hazy, vague, or ill-defined.
Nebulous.example: He had only a nebulous idea of what he wanted to do with his life.

Nefarious.definition: Wicked or criminal (typically of an action or activity).
Nefarious.example: The villain's nefarious plot was to take over the world.

Negligible.definition: So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering; insignificant.
Negligible.example: The difference in cost between the two options was negligible.

Neologism.definition: A newly coined word or expression.
Neologism.example: The word 'google' as a verb is a neologism that has entered common usage.

Neophyte.definition: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief; a novice or beginner.
Neophyte.example: As a neophyte in the world of chess, he was easily defeated by the grandmaster.

Nettle.example: His constant interruptions began to nettle the other members of the committee.

Nexus.definition: A connection or series of connections linking two or more things; a central or focal point.
Nexus.example: The city serves as a nexus for trade and transportation in the region.

Noisome.definition: Having an extremely offensive smell; disagreeable or unpleasant.
Noisome.example: The noisome stench from the garbage dump was unbearable.

Nominal.definition: Existing in name only; very small, far below the real value or cost.
Nominal.example: He was the nominal head of the company, but his daughter made all the important decisions.

Nonchalant.definition: Feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed; not displaying anxiety, interest, or enthusiasm.
Nonchalant.example: She remained nonchalant despite the chaos erupting around her.

Nonplussed.definition: Surprised and confused so much that one is unsure how to react.
Nonplussed.example: The unexpected question left him completely nonplussed and speechless.

Nostalgia.definition: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past, typically for a period or place with happy personal associations.
Nostalgia.example: Looking at old photographs filled her with a deep sense of nostalgia.

Noxious.example: The factory was fined for releasing noxious fumes into the atmosphere.

Nuance.definition: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
Nuance.example: A good actor can convey a wide range of emotions through subtle nuance.

Nugatory.definition: Of no value or importance; useless or futile.
Nugatory.example: His arguments were nugatory and did not influence the final decision.

Nadir.definition: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization; the point of greatest adversity or despair.
Nadir.example: After losing his job and his home in the same week, he felt he had reached the nadir of his life.

Nascent.definition: Just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential.
Nascent.example: The nascent tech company was already attracting the attention of major investors.

Nebulous.definition: In the form of a cloud or haze; hazy, vague, indistinct, or ill-defined.
Nebulous.example: She had a few nebulous ideas about what she might want to do in the future, but nothing concrete.

Nefarious.example: The spy uncovered a nefarious plot to destabilize the government.

Negligible.definition: So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering; insignificant.
Negligible.example: The difference in cost between the two options was negligible, so they chose the one with better features.

Nemesis.definition: A long-standing rival; an inescapable agent of someone's or something's downfall.
Nemesis.example: The heroic detective finally confronted his nemesis, the criminal mastermind who had eluded him for years.

Neologism.definition: A newly coined word or expression.
Neologism.example: The word 'google' as a verb is a neologism that has become a standard part of the English language.

Neophyte.definition: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief; a beginner or novice.
Neophyte.example: As a neophyte in the world of coding, he spent hours watching tutorials and practicing.

Nepotism.definition: The practice among those with power or influence of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs.
Nepotism.example: The CEO was accused of nepotism after he promoted his underqualified son to a senior management position.

Nettle.definition: To irritate, annoy, or provoke someone.
Nettle.example: His constant bragging started to nettle his friends.

Nexus.definition: A connection or series of connections linking two or more things; a central or focal point.
Nexus.example: The university library served as the nexus of campus life, a place where students from all disciplines converged.

Niggling.definition: Causing slight but persistent annoyance, discomfort, or anxiety.
Niggling.example: She had a niggling feeling that she had forgotten to lock the back door.

Nihilism.definition: The rejection of all religious and moral principles, often in the belief that life is meaningless.
Nihilism.example: The protagonist's descent into nihilism was marked by his disregard for societal norms and personal relationships.

Nimble.definition: Quick and light in movement or action; agile.
Nimble.example: The nimble rock climber scaled the cliff face with ease.

Nocturnal.definition: Done, occurring, or active at night.
Nocturnal.example: Owls are nocturnal predators, hunting for their prey under the cover of darkness.

Noisome.definition: Having an extremely offensive smell; disagreeable or unpleasant.
Noisome.example: The noisome stench from the garbage dump was a constant complaint from local residents.

Nominal.definition: Existing in name only; very small, far below the real value or cost.
Nominal.example: He was the nominal head of the company, but his wife made all the important decisions.

Nonchalant.definition: Feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed; not displaying anxiety, interest, or enthusiasm.
Nonchalant.example: She tried to appear nonchalant, but her trembling hands betrayed her nervousness.

Noncommittal.definition: Not expressing or revealing a definite opinion or intention.
Noncommittal.example: When asked about his future plans, the politician gave a noncommittal answer.

Nondescript.definition: Lacking distinctive or interesting features or characteristics.
Nondescript.example: The witness could only describe the suspect's car as a nondescript, mid-sized sedan.

Nonentity.definition: A person or thing with no special or interesting qualities; an unimportant person or thing.
Nonentity.example: He went from being a nonentity in the company to the head of his department in less than a year.

Nonpareil.definition: Having no match or equal; unrivaled.
Nonpareil.example: The chef's skills in the kitchen were nonpareil, earning him three Michelin stars.

Nonplus.definition: To surprise and confuse someone so much that they are unsure how to react.
Nonplus.example: The unexpected question seemed to nonplus the expert, who stammered for a moment before answering.

Nostalgia.definition: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for a period in the past.
Nostalgia.example: Listening to the old songs filled him with a deep sense of nostalgia for his college days.

Notorious.definition: Famous or well known, typically for some bad quality or deed.
Notorious.example: The city is notorious for its traffic jams and high cost of living.

Novel.definition: New or unusual in an interesting way.
Novel.example: The scientist proposed a novel approach to solving the energy crisis.

Novice.definition: A person new to and inexperienced in a job or situation.
Novice.example: Even a novice can learn the basics of the software in a few hours.

Noxious.example: The factory was fined for releasing noxious fumes into the atmosphere.

Nuance.definition: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
Nuance.example: A good translator must be sensitive to every nuance of the original language.

Nugatory.definition: Of no value or importance; useless or futile.
Nugatory.example: His arguments were dismissed as nugatory, having no real impact on the outcome of the debate.

Nullify.definition: To make legally null and void; to invalidate or make of no use or value.
Nullify.example: The court's decision could nullify the new law.

Numinous.definition: Having a strong religious or spiritual quality; indicating or suggesting the presence of a divinity.
Numinous.example: Standing in the ancient cathedral, she was overcome by a numinous sense of awe and reverence.

Nurture.definition: To care for and encourage the growth or development of.
Nurture.example: It is important to nurture young talent and provide opportunities for growth.

Naivete.definition: Lack of experience, wisdom, or judgment; innocence or unsophistication.
Naivete.example: Her naivete led her to trust the con artist completely.

Narcissism.definition: Excessive interest in or admiration of oneself and one's physical appearance.
Narcissism.example: His constant posts on social media were a clear display of his narcissism.

Natty.definition: Smart and fashionable in appearance or dress.
Natty.example: He was known for his natty suits and perfectly polished shoes.

Nautical.definition: Of or concerning sailors or navigation; maritime.
Nautical.example: The museum was filled with nautical charts and instruments from the 18th century.

Necessitate.definition: To make something necessary as a result or consequence.
Necessitate.example: The increase in student enrollment will necessitate the hiring of more teachers.

Negate.definition: To nullify or make ineffective; to deny the existence, evidence, or truth of.
Negate.example: The new evidence threatened to negate the jury's guilty verdict.

Neonate.example: The hospital has a specialized intensive care unit for premature neonates.

Neurotic.example: His neurotic obsession with cleanliness meant he washed his hands every ten minutes.

Neutralize.definition: To render something ineffective or harmless by applying an opposite force or effect.
Neutralize.example: She added a base to the acid to neutralize the solution.

Newfangled.definition: Different from what one is used to; objectionably new.
Newfangled.example: My grandfather refuses to use any of these newfangled smartphones.

Nicety.definition: A fine detail or distinction, especially one regarded as intricate and fussy.
Nicety.example: They spent hours debating the niceties of the legal contract.

Niche.definition: A comfortable or suitable position in life or employment; a specialized segment of the market for a particular kind of product or service.
Niche.example: She finally found her niche as a writer of historical fiction.

Nigh.definition: Near in space, time, or relation; almost.
Nigh.example: The end of the semester is drawing nigh.

Nirvana.definition: A transcendent state of ultimate peace and freedom from suffering.
Nirvana.example: For the exhausted hiker, reaching the summit was a moment of pure nirvana.

Nival.definition: Of, relating to, or growing in or under snow.
Nival.example: The botanist was studying the unique nival flora of the high alpine region.

Nobility.definition: The quality of being noble in character, mind, birth, or rank.
Nobility.example: He was a man of great nobility, always acting with integrity and honor.

Nocturne.definition: A short musical composition of a romantic or dreamy character, typically for piano.
Nocturne.example: The pianist played a beautiful Chopin nocturne as an encore.

Node.definition: A point in a network or diagram at which lines or pathways intersect or branch.
Node.example: Each computer in the network acts as a node that can send and receive data.

Nomenclature.definition: The devising or choosing of names for things, especially in a science or other discipline.
Nomenclature.example: The Linnaean system of binomial nomenclature is used to classify all living organisms.

Nom de plume.definition: A pen name used by an author.
Nom de plume.example: Samuel Clemens wrote his most famous works under the nom de plume Mark Twain.

Nonagenarian.definition: A person who is from 90 to 99 years old.
Nonagenarian.example: The sprightly nonagenarian still lived independently and went for a walk every day.

Nonconformist.definition: A person whose behavior or views do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.
Nonconformist.example: As a nonconformist, she always challenged conventional wisdom and forged her own path.

Nonplussed.definition: Surprised and confused so much that one is unsure how to react.
Nonplussed.example: She was completely nonplussed by his sudden proposal of marriage.

Normative.definition: Establishing, relating to, or deriving from a standard or norm, especially of behavior.
Normative.example: The study was not just descriptive, but also normative, suggesting how people ought to behave.

Nostrum.definition: A medicine of doubtful effectiveness; a pet scheme or favorite remedy, especially one for bringing about some social or political reform.
Nostrum.example: The politician's plan to fix the economy was dismissed by critics as a populist nostrum.

Notable.definition: Worthy of attention or notice; remarkable.
Notable.example: The town is notable for its beautiful architecture and historic landmarks.

Notoriety.definition: The state of being famous or well known for some bad quality or deed.
Notoriety.example: The gangster gained notoriety for his ruthless tactics and extravagant lifestyle.

Novella.definition: A short novel or a long short story.
Novella.example: George Orwell's 'Animal Farm' is a classic novella that critiques totalitarianism.

Novitiate.definition: The period or state of being a novice, especially in a religious order; a novice.
Novitiate.example: During her novitiate, she learned the rules and customs of the convent.

Nucleus.definition: The central and most important part of an object, movement, or group, forming the basis for its activity and growth.
Nucleus.example: A small group of dedicated activists formed the nucleus of the protest movement.

Nudge.definition: To prod someone gently to attract attention; to coax or gently encourage someone to do something.
Nudge.example: She gave him a gentle nudge to remind him it was his turn to speak.

Nugget.definition: A small lump of a valuable metal or mineral; a valuable idea or fact.
Nugget.example: The book was filled with interesting nuggets of information about ancient history.

Nuisance.definition: A person, thing, or circumstance causing inconvenience or annoyance.
Nuisance.example: The constant construction noise next door has become a real nuisance.

Numismatist.definition: A person who collects or studies coins, paper currency, and medals.
Numismatist.example: The numismatist carefully examined the rare Roman coin under a magnifying glass.

Nuptial.example: The couple exchanged nuptial vows in a beautiful ceremony by the sea.

Nascency.definition: The state of beginning to exist or develop; birth or origin.
Nascency.example: The nascency of the digital age can be traced back to the development of the first microprocessors.

Negligence.definition: Failure to take proper care in doing something, resulting in damage or injury to another.
Negligence.example: The accident was caused by the driver's negligence.

Nether.definition: Lower in position; situated below or beneath.
Nether.example: In the mythology, heroes often journeyed to the nether regions to confront demons.

Nihilistic.definition: Embracing or relating to the rejection of all religious and moral principles.
Nihilistic.example: The film's dark, nihilistic worldview left the audience feeling unsettled.

Nil.example: His chances of winning the lottery were practically nil.

Nodality.definition: The quality or state of being a node or having nodes; a point of intersection or focus.
Nodality.example: The city's position as a transportation hub gave it a high degree of nodality in the region's economy.

Nomad.definition: A person who does not stay long in the same place; a wanderer.
Nomad.example: After college, she lived as a digital nomad, working remotely from different countries.

Non sequitur.definition: A conclusion or statement that does not logically follow from the previous argument or statement.
Non sequitur.example: His response was a complete non sequitur that had nothing to do with my question.

Nosegay.definition: A small, sweet-scented bunch of flowers.
Nosegay.example: She carried a delicate nosegay of violets and lavender.

Notion.definition: A conception of or belief about something; an impulse or desire.
Notion.example: He had a vague notion that he wanted to travel, but no specific plans.

Noxiousness.definition: The quality of being harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant.
Noxiousness.example: The noxiousness of the chemical spill required an immediate evacuation of the area.

Nudnik.definition: A pestering, nagging, or irritating person; a bore.
Nudnik.example: Stop being such a nudnik and let me finish my work in peace.

Nympholepsy.definition: A state of rapture or frenzy of emotion, as for something unattainable.
Nympholepsy.example: The artist was in a state of nympholepsy, obsessed with capturing the fleeting beauty of the sunset.

Nystagmus.definition: Rapid, involuntary, oscillatory movements of the eyeballs.
Nystagmus.example: The doctor checked for nystagmus as a potential sign of a neurological issue.

Nefandous.definition: Not to be spoken of; unmentionable; abominable.
Nefandous.example: The tyrant was known for his nefandous acts of cruelty.

Nescient.example: He was completely nescient of the complex political situation he had walked into.

Nimiety.definition: The state of being more than is necessary or desirable; excess.
Nimiety.example: The nimiety of details in the report made it difficult to grasp the main points.

Nivicolous.definition: Living or growing in or on snow.
Nivicolous.example: Certain species of algae are nivicolous, giving the snow a reddish tint.

Nocent.example: The defense argued that the defendant was not the nocent party in the altercation.

Noetic.definition: Of or relating to mental activity or the intellect.
Noetic.example: The philosopher was interested in the noetic sciences and the nature of consciousness.

Nomothetic.definition: Relating to the study or discovery of general scientific laws.
Nomothetic.example: Psychology often uses a nomothetic approach to understand universal principles of human behavior.

Nonesuch.definition: A person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality; a paragon.
Nonesuch.example: As a hostess, she was a nonesuch, making every guest feel welcome and cherished.

Nosology.definition: The branch of medical science dealing with the classification of diseases.
Nosology.example: The development of a clear nosology is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Nacreous.definition: Having a pearly, iridescent luster; resembling mother-of-pearl.
Nacreous.example: The inside of the seashell had a beautiful nacreous sheen.

Nictitate.example: Owls can nictitate with a third, translucent eyelid to clean their eyes.

Nidificate.example: The robins return to the same tree every spring to nidificate.

Nidifugous.definition: Leaving the nest shortly after hatching.
Nidifugous.example: Ducks and chickens are nidifugous birds, able to walk and feed themselves almost immediately.

Niddering.example: The knight was branded a niddering for fleeing the battle.

Obdurate.definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
Obdurate.example: Despite the evidence against him, the politician remained obdurate in his denial.

Obfuscate.definition: To deliberately make something unclear, confusing, or unintelligible.
Obfuscate.example: The company's lawyers tried to obfuscate the issue with irrelevant financial details.

Obfuscation.definition: The action of making something obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
Obfuscation.example: His lengthy explanation was a masterpiece of obfuscation, leaving everyone more confused than before.

Oblation.definition: A thing presented or offered to a god or a god; a religious offering.
Oblation.example: The villagers made an oblation at the shrine, hoping for a good harvest.

Oblique.definition: Not expressed or done in a direct way; indirect or slanting.
Oblique.example: She made an oblique reference to her financial troubles without stating them outright.

Oblivious.definition: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around one.
Oblivious.example: Engrossed in his book, he was completely oblivious to the commotion outside.

Obloquy.definition: Strong public criticism, verbal abuse, or disgrace.
Obloquy.example: He endured years of obloquy for his controversial scientific theories.

Obsequious.definition: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
Obsequious.example: The obsequious assistant complimented his boss on every minor decision.

Obsequy.example: The king's obsequies were attended by dignitaries from around the world.

Obsolescent.definition: In the process of becoming outdated and no longer used.
Obsolescent.example: With the rise of smartphones, dedicated MP3 players are now obsolescent.

Obstinate.definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion, despite attempts to persuade one to do so.
Obstinate.example: The obstinate child refused to eat his vegetables, no matter how much his parents pleaded.

Obstreperous.definition: Noisy, unruly, and difficult to control.
Obstreperous.example: The obstreperous crowd was difficult for the security team to manage.

Obtrude.definition: To become noticeable in an unwelcome or intrusive way.
Obtrude.example: He had no wish to obtrude on their private conversation.

Obtuse.definition: Annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand; difficult to comprehend.
Obtuse.example: He was too obtuse to take the hint that it was time for him to leave.

Obverse.definition: The side of a coin or medal bearing the head or principal design; the opposite or counterpart of a fact or truth.
Obverse.example: The obverse of his kindness was a surprisingly sharp temper.

Obviate.definition: To remove a need or difficulty; to avoid or prevent something.
Obviate.example: A peaceful resolution would obviate the need for military intervention.

Occlude.definition: To stop, close up, or obstruct an opening or passage.
Occlude.example: A build-up of plaque can occlude a major artery, leading to a heart attack.

Occult.definition: Relating to mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena.
Occult.example: She had a keen interest in the occult and spent her weekends reading about ancient rituals.

Odious.example: The odious task of cleaning the grease trap fell to the newest employee.

Odoriferous.definition: Having or giving off a strong or distinctive smell.
Odoriferous.example: The odoriferous durian fruit is banned on many forms of public transport in Southeast Asia.

Odyssey.definition: A long, adventurous journey or experience.
Odyssey.example: His journey from a small village to a successful entrepreneur was a true odyssey.

Oeuvre.definition: The complete body of works of a writer, an artist, or a composer.
Oeuvre.example: The museum hosted a retrospective of the painter's entire oeuvre.

Officious.definition: Assertive of authority in a domineering way, especially with regard to trivial matters; meddlesome.
Officious.example: The officious security guard took great pleasure in bossing the visitors around.

Ogle.definition: To stare at in a lecherous or impertinent manner.
Ogle.example: It's extremely uncomfortable when strangers ogle you on the subway.

Oligarchy.definition: A form of government in which all power is vested in a few persons or in a dominant class or clique.
Oligarchy.example: The country was ruled by an oligarchy composed of wealthy landowners and industrialists.

Oligopoly.definition: A state of limited competition where a market is shared by a small number of producers.
Oligopoly.example: The telecommunications industry is often cited as an example of an oligopoly.

Olio.definition: A miscellaneous collection of things; a hodgepodge.
Olio.example: The book was an olio of short stories, poems, and personal essays.

Ominous.definition: Giving the impression that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen; threatening.
Ominous.example: The ominous dark clouds gathered on the horizon, signaling an approaching storm.

Omission.definition: The act of leaving something out or the state of being left out.
Omission.example: Her omission from the list of speakers was a deliberate snub by the organizers.

Omnibus.definition: Comprising several items; a volume containing several works previously published separately.
Omnibus.example: The television channel will air an omnibus edition of the week's episodes on Sunday.

Omnipotent.example: In the story, the wizard was an omnipotent being who could control the very fabric of reality.

Omnipresent.definition: Widely or constantly encountered; common or widespread.
Omnipresent.example: In today's world, the influence of social media is omnipresent.

Omniscient.example: The novel is told from the perspective of an omniscient narrator who knows the thoughts of all characters.

Omnivorous.definition: Feeding on both plants and animals; taking in everything, as with the mind.
Omnivorous.example: She was an omnivorous reader, enjoying everything from sci-fi to historical biographies.

Oncogenic.definition: Causing the development of a tumor or tumors.
Oncogenic.example: Certain viruses, like HPV, are known to have oncogenic properties.

Onerous.definition: Involving a great deal of effort, trouble, or difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.
Onerous.example: He found the responsibility of managing the international project to be an onerous task.

Onomatopoeia.definition: The formation of a word from a sound associated with what is named.
Onomatopoeia.example: Words like 'buzz,' 'cuckoo,' and 'sizzle' are common examples of onomatopoeia.

Onus.definition: A duty or responsibility; the burden of proof.
Onus.example: The onus is on the prosecution to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

Ontology.definition: The branch of metaphysics dealing with the nature of being, becoming, existence, or reality.
Ontology.example: The philosopher's work focused on ontology and the fundamental questions of what it means to exist.

Opacity.definition: The quality of being difficult to see through or understand.
Opacity.example: The opacity of the legal document made it nearly impossible for a layperson to comprehend.

Opaque.definition: Not able to be seen through; not transparent.
Opaque.example: The opaque curtains blocked out the morning sun completely.

Opalescent.definition: Showing varying colors as an opal does; iridescent.
Opalescent.example: The morning dew on the spiderweb had an opalescent sheen in the sunlight.

Operatic.example: He gestured with operatic flair, drawing attention from everyone in the room.

Operose.definition: Involving or showing great industry or labor; laborious.
Operose.example: Compiling the comprehensive dictionary was an operose task that took decades to complete.

Ophidian.example: The creature moved with a sinuous, ophidian grace across the floor.

Opiate.definition: A drug used to relieve pain or induce sleep; something that soothes or dulls the senses.
Opiate.example: For the masses, mindless entertainment served as an opiate, distracting them from their problems.

Opine.definition: To hold and state as one's opinion.
