Static.definition: Lacking in movement, action, or change, especially in a way viewed as undesirable or uninteresting.
Static.example: For years, his career remained static, with no opportunities for advancement.

Steadfast.definition: Resolutely or dutifully firm and unwavering.
Steadfast.example: She remained steadfast in her belief in his innocence.

Stentorian.definition: Of a person's voice: loud and powerful.
Stentorian.example: The drill sergeant's stentorian commands echoed across the parade ground.

Tacit.definition: Understood or implied without being stated.
Tacit.example: They had a tacit agreement that he would be the one to wash the dishes.

Taciturn.definition: Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
Taciturn.example: The taciturn farmer responded to my questions with only a nod.

Talisman.definition: An object, typically an inscribed ring or stone, that is thought to have magic powers and to bring good luck.
Talisman.example: He wore a small talisman around his neck to ward off evil spirits.

Tangential.definition: Diverging from a previous course or line; erratic or irrelevant.
Tangential.example: The speaker's tangential remarks about his childhood were interesting but unrelated to the main topic.

Tantamount.definition: Equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as.
Tantamount.example: His silence was tantamount to an admission of guilt.

Tarry.definition: To stay longer than intended; to delay leaving a place.
Tarry.example: We were hoping to tarry a bit longer at the beautiful lakeside, but we had to catch our train.

Tautology.definition: The saying of the same thing twice in different words, generally considered to be a fault of style.
Tautology.example: The phrase 'a new innovation' is a tautology because an innovation is by definition new.

Tawdry.definition: Showy but cheap and of poor quality.
Tawdry.example: She bought some tawdry jewelry from the street vendor.

Tedium.definition: The state of being tedious or monotonous.
Tedium.example: To relieve the tedium of the long journey, she listened to an audiobook.

Temerity.example: He had the temerity to question the professor's judgment in front of the entire class.

Temperance.definition: Moderation or self-restraint, especially in eating and drinking.
Temperance.example: Practicing temperance, he limited himself to one glass of wine with dinner.

Temperate.definition: Relating to or denoting a region or climate characterized by mild temperatures; showing moderation.
Temperate.example: The temperate climate of the region is perfect for growing grapes.

Tenable.definition: Able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
Tenable.example: His argument was not tenable and was quickly dismantled by the opposition.

Tenacious.definition: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
Tenacious.example: The tenacious reporter would not give up until she had the full story.

Tendentious.definition: Expressing or intending to promote a particular cause or point of view, especially a controversial one.
Tendentious.example: The newspaper article was criticized for its tendentious portrayal of the political situation.

Tenuous.example: He held a tenuous grasp on reality after the traumatic event.

Tepid.definition: Only slightly warm; lukewarm; showing little enthusiasm.
Tepid.example: The audience's response to the new play was tepid at best.

Terse.definition: Sparing in the use of words; abrupt.
Terse.example: Her terse reply made it clear she was not in the mood for conversation.

Timorous.definition: Showing or suffering from nervousness, fear, or a lack of confidence.
Timorous.example: The timorous kitten hid under the sofa whenever a stranger entered the room.

Tirade.definition: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
Tirade.example: The manager launched into a tirade against the employees who were consistently late.

Titillate.definition: To stimulate or excite someone in a pleasing way.
Titillate.example: The gossip columnist's stories were designed to titillate readers with scandalous details.

Toady.definition: A person who behaves obsequiously to someone important.
Toady.example: He was a shameless toady, always flattering the boss to gain favor.

Torpid.example: After the large holiday meal, everyone felt too torpid to move from the couch.

Torpor.definition: A state of physical or mental inactivity; lethargy.
Torpor.example: The bear emerged from its winter torpor, hungry and disoriented.

Tortuous.definition: Full of twists and turns; excessively lengthy and complex.
Tortuous.example: The tortuous mountain road made for a difficult but scenic drive.

Tout.definition: To attempt to sell something, typically by pestering people in an aggressive or bold manner.
Tout.example: The company hired marketers to tout their new product on social media.

Tractable.example: The new puppy was surprisingly tractable and learned commands quickly.

Traduce.definition: To speak badly of or tell lies about someone so as to damage their reputation.
Traduce.example: The politician's opponents tried to traduce him with false accusations.

Tranquility.definition: The quality or state of being calm and peaceful.
Tranquility.example: She found tranquility in her garden, away from the noise of the city.

Transcendent.definition: Beyond or above the range of normal or merely physical human experience.
Transcendent.example: The beauty of the symphony was a transcendent experience for the audience.

Transgress.definition: To infringe or go beyond the bounds of a moral principle or other established standard of behavior.
Transgress.example: He knew that to transgress the law would have serious consequences.

Transient.definition: Lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
Transient.example: The transient beauty of the cherry blossoms is a reminder of life's fleeting nature.

Transitory.example: Youth is a transitory phase of life that passes all too quickly.

Translucent.definition: Allowing light, but not detailed images, to pass through; semitransparent.
Translucent.example: The frosted glass of the bathroom window was translucent, providing privacy while letting in light.

Transmute.definition: To change in form, nature, or substance.
Transmute.example: The alchemist claimed he could transmute lead into gold.

Travesty.definition: A false, absurd, or distorted representation of something.
Travesty.example: The trial was a travesty of justice, with a predetermined outcome.

Treacly.example: The movie's treacly ending was predictable and left the audience feeling unsatisfied.

Treatise.definition: A written work dealing formally and systematically with a subject.
Treatise.example: She published a scholarly treatise on the economic policies of the 18th century.

Tremulous.definition: Shaking or quivering slightly; timid or nervous.
Tremulous.example: With a tremulous voice, he asked for her hand in marriage.

Trepidation.definition: A feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen.
Trepidation.example: He felt a great deal of trepidation before his first public speaking engagement.

Tribulation.definition: A cause of great trouble or suffering.
Tribulation.example: The pioneers faced many tribulations on their journey west.

Trite.definition: Overused and consequently of little import; lacking originality or freshness.
Trite.example: His speech was filled with trite clichs and offered no new insights.

Truculent.definition: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
Truculent.example: The truculent customer was shouting at the cashier over a minor issue.

Truncate.definition: To shorten something by cutting off the top or the end.
Truncate.example: The editor decided to truncate the lengthy article to fit the available space.

Tryst.definition: A private, romantic rendezvous between lovers.
Tryst.example: They arranged a secret tryst in the moonlit garden.

Tumultuous.definition: Making a loud, confused noise; uproarious; marked by disturbance and uproar.
Tumultuous.example: The team received a tumultuous welcome from their fans after winning the championship.

Turgid.definition: Swollen and distended; or (of language) tediously pompous or bombastic.
Turgid.example: The professor's turgid prose made his latest book nearly unreadable.

Turpitude.example: The dictator was known for his acts of moral turpitude.

Tyro.example: Even a tyro in the kitchen can follow this simple recipe.

Tergiversate.definition: To make conflicting or evasive statements; to equivocate.
Tergiversate.example: The politician began to tergiversate when asked about his campaign promises.

Termagant.example: The story featured a wicked queen who was a classic termagant.

Thorny.definition: Causing distress, difficulty, or trouble; full of difficulties.
Thorny.example: The issue of tax reform is a thorny one for any government.

Thwart.definition: To prevent someone from accomplishing something.
Thwart.example: The hero's plan to save the city was thwarted by the villain at the last moment.

Timbre.definition: The character or quality of a musical sound or voice as distinct from its pitch and intensity.
Timbre.example: The singer's voice had a rich, warm timbre that captivated the audience.

Tonic.definition: A medicinal substance taken to give a feeling of vigor or well-being.
Tonic.example: The fresh mountain air was a tonic for his weary spirit.

Topography.definition: The arrangement of the natural and artificial physical features of an area.
Topography.example: The topography of the region includes rolling hills and a large central lake.

Torrid.definition: Very hot and dry; or full of passion.
Torrid.example: They had a torrid love affair that was the talk of the town.

Touchstone.definition: A standard or criterion by which something is judged or recognized.
Touchstone.example: The novel became a touchstone for a generation of writers.

Toxicology.definition: The branch of science concerned with the nature, effects, and detection of poisons.
Toxicology.example: The toxicology report confirmed the presence of a lethal substance.

Trajectory.definition: The path followed by a projectile or an object moving under the action of given forces.
Trajectory.example: The missile's trajectory was calculated to hit the target with precision.

Trammel.definition: A restriction or impediment to freedom of action.
Trammel.example: She refused to let the trammels of society dictate her life's path.

Transfigure.definition: To transform into something more beautiful or elevated.
Transfigure.example: The morning sun seemed to transfigure the drab cityscape into a place of beauty.

Transfuse.definition: To transfer (blood or its components) from one person or animal to another; to instill.
Transfuse.example: The doctor needed to transfuse two pints of blood to the patient.

Transmogrify.definition: To transform in a surprising or magical manner.
Transmogrify.example: In the fairy tale, the witch could transmogrify princes into frogs.

Travail.example: The team's final victory was the result of months of hard travail.

Trenchant.definition: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style.
Trenchant.example: The critic's trenchant review highlighted the play's major flaws.

Tribute.definition: An act, statement, or gift that is intended to show gratitude, respect, or admiration.
Tribute.example: The concert was a tribute to the legendary musician.

Trifling.example: Don't waste your time on such trifling matters.

Trope.definition: A figurative or metaphorical use of a word or expression.
Trope.example: The 'damsel in distress' is a common trope in classic literature.

Trounce.definition: To defeat heavily in a contest.
Trounce.example: The home team is expected to trounce the visiting team by a wide margin.

Truism.definition: A statement that is obviously true and says nothing new or interesting.
Truism.example: He ended his speech with the truism that 'time is money'.

Trumpery.definition: Attractive articles of little value or use; worthless nonsense.
Trumpery.example: Her shelves were filled with trumpery she had collected from souvenir shops.

Tumid.definition: Swollen; or (of language) pompous or bombastic.
Tumid.example: After the bee sting, his hand became tumid and painful.

Turbid.definition: Cloudy, opaque, or thick with suspended matter, as in a liquid.
Turbid.example: The floodwaters turned the once-clear river into a turbid mess.

Tussle.definition: A vigorous struggle or scuffle, typically in order to obtain or achieve something.
Tussle.example: The politicians engaged in a heated tussle over the new budget.

Tutelage.definition: Protection of or authority over someone or something; guardianship.
Tutelage.example: Under the tutelage of her mentor, she quickly became a skilled artist.

Tutelary.definition: Serving as a protector, guardian, or patron.
Tutelary.example: In ancient Rome, each household had its own tutelary deities.

Twaddle.definition: Trivial or foolish speech or writing; nonsense.
Twaddle.example: I can't listen to any more of his political twaddle.

Typify.definition: To be a typical example of.
Typify.example: The architecture of the old city center seems to typify the colonial era.

Tyrannical.definition: Exercising power in a cruel or arbitrary way.
Tyrannical.example: The people rose up against the tyrannical ruler.

Tabula rasa.definition: An absence of preconceived ideas or predetermined goals; a clean slate.
Tabula rasa.example: The new leader approached the negotiations with a tabula rasa, hoping for a fresh start.

Tachygraphy.definition: Shorthand; the art of rapid writing.
Tachygraphy.example: The court reporter used tachygraphy to record every word of the testimony.

Tatterdemalion.definition: A person in tattered clothing; a ragged person.
Tatterdemalion.example: A group of tatterdemalion children played in the dusty streets.

Taut.definition: Stretched or pulled tight; not slack.
Taut.example: The rope was pulled taut between the two posts.

Taxonomy.definition: The branch of science concerned with classification, especially of organisms.
Taxonomy.example: In biology, taxonomy is essential for understanding the relationships between different species.

Technocrat.definition: An exponent or advocate of technocracy; an expert in a technical field who holds power.
Technocrat.example: Many citizens were wary of a government run by unelected technocrats.

Teleological.definition: Relating to the explanation of phenomena in terms of the purpose they serve rather than of the cause by which they arise.
Teleological.example: A teleological argument for the existence of God is based on the evidence of design in the universe.

Tempestuous.definition: Characterized by strong and turbulent or conflicting emotion.
Tempestuous.example: They had a tempestuous relationship, marked by frequent arguments and passionate reconciliations.

Temporal.definition: Relating to worldly as opposed to spiritual affairs; secular.
Temporal.example: The king was concerned with temporal power, while the church focused on spiritual matters.

Temporize.definition: To avoid making a decision or committing oneself in order to gain time.
Temporize.example: The committee chose to temporize rather than vote on the controversial proposal.

Tenet.definition: A principle or belief, especially one of the main principles of a religion or philosophy.
Tenet.example: One of the central tenets of the organization is a commitment to nonviolence.

Tentative.example: We have a tentative plan to go camping next weekend, depending on the weather.

Tenuity.definition: Lack of substance or strength; thinness or fineness.
Tenuity.example: The tenuity of the argument made it easy to refute.

Testimonial.definition: A formal statement testifying to someone's character and qualifications or the value of a product.
Testimonial.example: The company's website was full of glowing testimonials from satisfied customers.

Theocracy.definition: A system of government in which priests rule in the name of God or a god.
Theocracy.example: The ancient state was a theocracy ruled by a council of high priests.

Thespian.definition: Relating to drama and the theater; an actor or actress.
Thespian.example: The young thespian dreamed of one day performing on Broadway.

Thrall.definition: The state of being in someone's power or having great power over someone.
Thrall.example: He was in thrall to his own ambition, sacrificing everything for his career.

Tincture.definition: A slight trace of something; a medicine made by dissolving a drug in alcohol.
Tincture.example: There was a tincture of sadness in her voice as she recounted the story.

Titular.definition: Holding or constituting a purely formal position or title without any real authority.
Titular.example: While the queen is the titular head of state, the prime minister holds the real political power.

Tome.definition: A book, especially a large, heavy, scholarly one.
Tome.example: The professor pulled a dusty tome from the shelf to look up the ancient text.

Ubiquitous.example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society, connecting people across the globe.

Umbrage.definition: Offense or annoyance, often taken at a perceived slight.
Umbrage.example: He took umbrage at the suggestion that he was not qualified for the job.

Unabashed.example: She remained unabashed by the criticism and continued to voice her controversial opinions.

Unabated.definition: Without any reduction in intensity or strength.
Unabated.example: The storm raged unabated for three days, causing widespread flooding.

Unassuming.definition: Not pretentious or arrogant; modest and down-to-earth.
Unassuming.example: Despite his vast wealth, he was an unassuming man who preferred a simple lifestyle.

Unbecoming.definition: Not fitting or appropriate for a person's character or status.
Unbecoming.example: His rude behavior at the formal dinner was unbecoming of a diplomat.

Unbridled.example: The team celebrated their victory with unbridled joy.

Uncanny.definition: Strange or mysterious, especially in an unsettling way.
Uncanny.example: She had an uncanny ability to predict what I was going to say next.

Unconscionable.definition: Not right or reasonable; shockingly unfair or unjust.
Unconscionable.example: The company's unconscionable labor practices led to a public outcry.

Uncouth.definition: Lacking good manners, refinement, or grace.
Uncouth.example: His uncouth table manners embarrassed his dining companions.

Unctuous.definition: Excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily and insincere.
Unctuous.example: The unctuous salesman praised my questionable fashion choices to make a sale.

Undercurrent.definition: An underlying feeling or influence, contrary to the prevailing atmosphere.
Undercurrent.example: Despite the polite conversation, there was a strong undercurrent of hostility in the room.

Undergird.definition: To provide support or a firm basis for an argument or structure.
Undergird.example: The philosopher's entire theory is undergirded by a belief in rationalism.

Undermine.definition: To lessen the effectiveness, power, or ability of, especially gradually or insidiously.
Undermine.example: Constant criticism can undermine a person's confidence.

Underpin.definition: To support, justify, or form the basis for something.
Underpin.example: The principles of free speech underpin the country's constitution.

Underscore.definition: To emphasize the importance of something.
Underscore.example: The report's findings underscore the need for immediate action on climate change.

Understated.definition: Presented or expressed in a subtle and effective way.
Understated.example: Her elegant, understated dress was perfect for the occasion.

Underwrite.definition: To finance or guarantee something; to accept financial responsibility for.
Underwrite.example: A wealthy benefactor agreed to underwrite the costs of the new museum wing.

Undulate.definition: To move with a smooth, wavelike motion.
Undulate.example: The fields of wheat undulated in the gentle breeze.

Undue.definition: Unwarranted or inappropriate because excessive or disproportionate.
Undue.example: The witness claimed the police had used undue pressure to obtain a confession.

Unencumbered.definition: Not having any burden or impediment; free of baggage.
Unencumbered.example: After paying off his student loans, he felt unencumbered and free to travel.

Unequivocal.definition: Leaving no doubt; unambiguous and clear.
Unequivocal.example: The president's unequivocal denial of the rumors put an end to the speculation.

Unfathomable.definition: Incapable of being fully explored or understood.
Unfathomable.example: The sheer size of the universe is unfathomable to the human mind.

Unfeigned.example: She expressed unfeigned delight at seeing her old friend again.

Unfettered.example: The artist's unfettered imagination led to the creation of truly unique masterpieces.

Unflappable.definition: Having or showing calmness in a crisis.
Unflappable.example: The pilot remained unflappable as he guided the damaged plane to a safe landing.

Unfounded.definition: Having no foundation or basis in fact.
Unfounded.example: The rumors of his resignation proved to be completely unfounded.

Ungainly.definition: Awkward; clumsy in movement or posture.
Ungainly.example: The newborn giraffe was ungainly, stumbling on its long legs.

Unguent.definition: A soft, greasy, or viscous substance used as an ointment or for lubrication.
Unguent.example: The ancient healer applied a soothing unguent to the wound.

Unilateral.definition: Performed by or affecting only one party in a situation without the agreement of others.
Unilateral.example: The company made a unilateral decision to change the work schedules, angering the union.

Unimpeachable.definition: Not able to be doubted, questioned, or criticized; entirely trustworthy.
Unimpeachable.example: The witness was a person of unimpeachable integrity.

Uninitiated.definition: Without special knowledge or experience of a particular subject or activity.
Uninitiated.example: To the uninitiated, the complex rules of the game can seem baffling.

Unkempt.definition: Having an untidy or disheveled appearance.
Unkempt.example: His unkempt beard and wrinkled clothes suggested he had been sleeping rough.

Unmitigated.definition: Absolute; unqualified, often used to intensify a negative quality.
Unmitigated.example: The project was an unmitigated disaster from start to finish.

Unobtrusive.definition: Not conspicuous or attracting attention; low-profile.
Unobtrusive.example: The security cameras were small and unobtrusive, blending into the background.

Unorthodox.definition: Contrary to what is usual, traditional, or accepted.
Unorthodox.example: The coach's unorthodox training methods were surprisingly effective.

Unpalatable.definition: Difficult to put up with or accept; disagreeable.
Unpalatable.example: The unpalatable truth was that the company was on the verge of bankruptcy.

Unprecedented.example: The global pandemic created an unprecedented challenge for healthcare systems worldwide.

Unprepossessing.definition: Not attractive or appealing to the eye.
Unprepossessing.example: Despite its unprepossessing exterior, the restaurant served the best food in town.

Unpretentious.definition: Not attempting to impress others with an appearance of greater importance or talent.
Unpretentious.example: He was a brilliant but unpretentious scientist who was happy to share his knowledge.

Unprincipled.definition: Not having or showing moral principles.
Unprincipled.example: The unprincipled businessman would do anything to make a profit.

Unpropitious.definition: Not giving or indicating a good chance of success; unfavorable.
Unpropitious.example: The dark clouds and rising wind were unpropitious signs for their sailing trip.

Unqualified.definition: Without reservation or limitation; total and absolute.
Unqualified.example: The new policy was met with unqualified approval from the staff.

Unravel.definition: To investigate and solve or explain something complicated or puzzling.
Unravel.example: The detective worked tirelessly to unravel the complex mystery.

Unregenerate.definition: Not reforming or showing repentance; obstinately wrong or bad.
Unregenerate.example: He remained an unregenerate gambler despite losing all his savings.

Unremitting.definition: Never relaxing or slackening; incessant and persistent.
Unremitting.example: She cared for her sick mother with unremitting devotion.

Unrequited.definition: Not returned or rewarded (of a feeling, especially love).
Unrequited.example: His unrequited love for his best friend was a source of great sadness for him.

Unreserved.example: She gave her unreserved support to the new proposal.

Unruly.definition: Disorderly and disruptive and not amenable to discipline or control.
Unruly.example: The substitute teacher struggled to control the unruly class.

Unsavory.definition: Disagreeable to taste, smell, or look at; morally offensive.
Unsavory.example: He had a reputation for getting involved in unsavory business deals.

Unscathed.definition: Without suffering any injury, damage, or harm.
Unscathed.example: Miraculously, the driver walked away from the car crash completely unscathed.

Unscrupulous.definition: Having or showing no moral principles; not honest or fair.
Unscrupulous.example: The unscrupulous salesman sold them a faulty car at an inflated price.

Unseemly.definition: Not proper or appropriate in a given situation.
Unseemly.example: It was considered unseemly to celebrate so soon after the tragedy.

Unsparing.definition: Merciless and severe; given freely and generously.
Unsparing.example: The critic was unsparing in her review of the terrible new play.

Unstinting.definition: Given or giving without restraint; unsparing and generous.
Unstinting.example: She was unstinting in her praise for the volunteers who helped her.

Unsubstantiated.definition: Not supported or proven by evidence.
Unsubstantiated.example: The journalist was fired for publishing unsubstantiated claims.

Unswerving.definition: Not changing or becoming weaker; steady or constant.
Unswerving.example: She showed unswerving loyalty to her friends, even when they made mistakes.

Untenable.definition: Not able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection.
Untenable.example: The lawyer argued that the prosecution's position was untenable due to a lack of evidence.

Untoward.example: Nothing untoward happened during the school trip, much to the teachers' relief.

Untrammeled.definition: Not deprived of freedom of action or expression; not restricted or hampered.
Untrammeled.example: The First Amendment guarantees the untrammeled expression of ideas.

Unvarnished.example: He told the unvarnished truth about what had happened, sparing no details.

Unwavering.example: Her unwavering belief in her team's ability to win was inspiring.

Unwieldy.definition: Difficult to carry or move because of its size, shape, or weight.
Unwieldy.example: The old couch was too unwieldy to fit through the narrow doorway.

Unwitting.example: He became an unwitting pawn in their elaborate scheme.

Unwonted.example: He spoke with unwonted passion, surprising everyone in the audience.

Upbraid.definition: To find fault with someone; to scold severely.
Upbraid.example: The coach upbraided the team for their lackluster performance.

Upend.definition: To set or turn something on its end or upside down; to cause a major disruption to.
Upend.example: The underdog's victory threatened to upend the entire championship.

Upheaval.definition: A violent or sudden change or disruption to something.
Upheaval.example: The political scandal caused a major upheaval within the government.

Uphold.definition: To maintain or support a law, decision, or principle.
Uphold.example: The Supreme Court voted to uphold the lower court's ruling.

Uproarious.definition: Provoking loud laughter; very noisy and lively.
Uproarious.example: The comedian's final joke received an uproarious response from the crowd.

Upshot.definition: The final or eventual outcome or conclusion of a series of events.
Upshot.example: The upshot of the long negotiation was a compromise that satisfied both parties.

Urbane.definition: Suave, courteous, and refined in manner.
Urbane.example: He was an urbane host, making every guest feel welcome and at ease.

Urbanity.definition: Suaveness, courteousness, and refinement of manner.
Urbanity.example: She handled the awkward situation with her usual urbanity and grace.

Usurp.definition: To take a position of power or importance illegally or by force.
Usurp.example: The ambitious general planned to usurp the throne from the aging king.

Usurious.definition: Relating to or practicing the lending of money at unreasonably high rates of interest.
Usurious.example: The loan shark was arrested for his usurious lending practices.

Usury.definition: The illegal action or practice of lending money at unreasonably high rates of interest.
Usury.example: He fell into debt by borrowing money from a lender who practiced usury.

Utilitarian.definition: Designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive.
Utilitarian.example: The building had a stark, utilitarian design with no unnecessary ornamentation.

Utilize.definition: To make practical and effective use of.
Utilize.example: We must utilize all available resources to complete the project on time.

Utopia.definition: An imagined place or state of things in which everything is perfect.
Utopia.example: While a world without conflict seems like a utopia, it is an ideal worth striving for.

Uxorious.definition: Having or showing an excessive or submissive fondness for one's wife.
Uxorious.example: His friends often teased him for his uxorious behavior, calling him completely henpecked.

Ultimatum.definition: A final demand or statement of terms, the rejection of which will result in retaliation or a breakdown in relations.
Ultimatum.example: The union issued an ultimatum to the management: meet their demands or face a strike.

Unicameral.example: Nebraska is the only state in the U.S. with a unicameral legislature.

Unify.definition: To make or become united, uniform, or whole.
Unify.example: The new leader's goal was to unify the divided factions of the party.

Unison.definition: Simultaneous performance of action or utterance of speech.
Unison.example: The students recited the pledge in unison.

Unitary.definition: Forming a single or uniform entity.
Unitary.example: The country has a unitary system of government, with power concentrated at the national level.

Universal.definition: Affecting or done by all people or things in the world or in a particular group; applicable to all cases.
Universal.example: The desire for happiness is a universal human emotion.

Unnerve.definition: To make someone lose courage or confidence.
Unnerve.example: The eerie silence of the empty house began to unnerve him.

Unremunerative.definition: Bringing little or no profit or financial reward.
Unremunerative.example: He abandoned his unremunerative career as a poet to become a more practical accountant.

Unrestrained.example: The children showed unrestrained excitement on Christmas morning.

Unruffled.definition: Not disordered or disarranged; calm and composed.
Unruffled.example: She remained unruffled by the chaos around her.

Unshackle.definition: To release from restraints, either literal or figurative.
Unshackle.example: The new software aims to unshackle creativity by providing more flexible tools.

Unsurpassed.definition: As good as or better than any other.
Unsurpassed.example: The view from the mountaintop was of unsurpassed beauty.

Untainted.example: They found a source of pure, untainted water in the wilderness.

Unwarranted.example: The level of criticism she received was completely unwarranted.

Upright.example: He was known as an upright citizen who always followed the law.

Uprising.definition: An act of resistance or rebellion; a revolt.
Uprising.example: The government quickly suppressed the popular uprising.

Upsurge.definition: An upward surge in the strength or quantity of something.
Upsurge.example: There has been a recent upsurge in demand for electric vehicles.

Usufruct.definition: The legal right to use and enjoy the fruits or profits of something belonging to another.
Usufruct.example: The will granted him usufruct of the family farm, but he could not sell the land.

Utter.example: When he saw the mess, he was in a state of utter disbelief.

Utility.definition: The state of being useful, profitable, or beneficial.
Utility.example: The new software has a high degree of utility for graphic designers.

Vacillate.definition: To waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
Vacillate.example: The senator continued to vacillate on the controversial bill, frustrating both supporters and opponents.

Vacuous.definition: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless.
Vacuous.example: He had a vacuous expression on his face, as if he hadn't understood a word.

Vagary.definition: An unexpected and inexplicable change in a situation or in someone's behavior.
Vagary.example: The vagaries of the weather made it difficult to plan the outdoor event.

Vainglorious.definition: Excessively proud of oneself or one's achievements; boastful.
Vainglorious.example: The vainglorious general boasted of his victories to anyone who would listen.

Valediction.definition: A statement or address made as a farewell.
Valediction.example: He delivered a moving valediction at his mentor's retirement party.

Valedictory.example: The retiring CEO gave a valedictory speech, thanking his employees for their years of service.

Valiant.definition: Possessing or showing courage or determination.
Valiant.example: The valiant firefighters rushed into the burning building to save the trapped residents.

Validate.definition: To check or prove the validity or accuracy of something.
Validate.example: You will need to validate your parking ticket before you can exit the garage.

Valor.definition: Great courage in the face of danger, especially in battle.
Valor.example: The soldier was awarded the highest medal for his valor on the battlefield.

Vapid.definition: Offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging; bland.
Vapid.example: Their conversation was vapid, consisting of nothing more than celebrity gossip.

Variegated.definition: Exhibiting different colors, especially as irregular patches or streaks.
Variegated.example: The variegated leaves of the croton plant added a splash of color to the room.

Vaunt.definition: To boast about or praise something, especially excessively.
Vaunt.example: He vaunted his wealth by driving a different luxury car every day of the week.

Vehement.definition: Showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense.
Vehement.example: She was vehement in her denial of the accusations against her.

Venal.example: The venal judge was known for accepting money in exchange for favorable rulings.

Venerable.definition: Accorded a great deal of respect, especially because of age, wisdom, or character.
Venerable.example: The venerable professor had taught at the university for over fifty years.

Venerate.definition: To regard with great respect; revere.
Venerate.example: In many cultures, it is customary to venerate one's ancestors.

Venial.definition: Denoting a fault or offense that is slight and pardonable.
Venial.example: His white lie was a venial sin, easily forgiven.

Venturesome.definition: Willing to take risks or embark on new and daring enterprises.
Venturesome.example: The venturesome entrepreneur invested his life savings into the new tech startup.

Veracious.example: The witness was known to be veracious, so the jury believed his testimony.

Veracity.example: The journalist's reputation depended on the veracity of her sources.

Verbatim.definition: In exactly the same words as were used originally.
Verbatim.example: He quoted the passage verbatim from the book.

Verbiage.definition: Speech or writing that uses too many words or excessively technical expressions.
Verbiage.example: The report was filled with unnecessary verbiage that made it difficult to understand.

Verbose.definition: Using or expressed in more words than are needed.
Verbose.example: His verbose emails were a chore to read.

Verdant.definition: Green with grass or other rich vegetation.
Verdant.example: After the spring rains, the hills were lush and verdant.

Verisimilitude.definition: The appearance of being true or real.
Verisimilitude.example: The movie's attention to historical detail gave it a great sense of verisimilitude.

Veritable.definition: Used as an intensifier, often to qualify a metaphor; true.
Veritable.example: The overflowing library was a veritable treasure trove of knowledge.

Vernacular.definition: The language or dialect spoken by the ordinary people in a particular country or region.
Vernacular.example: The author was praised for his use of the local vernacular in his dialogue.

Vernal.definition: Of, in, or appropriate to spring.
Vernal.example: The vernal equinox marks the beginning of spring.

Versatile.definition: Able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
Versatile.example: The Swiss Army knife is a versatile tool with many uses.

Vestige.definition: A trace of something that is disappearing or no longer exists.
Vestige.example: The ancient ruins were the last vestige of a once-great civilization.

Vestigial.definition: Forming a very small remnant of something that was once much larger or more noticeable.
Vestigial.example: The human appendix is often considered a vestigial organ.

Vex.definition: To make someone feel annoyed, frustrated, or worried, especially with trivial matters.
Vex.example: The constant buzzing of the fly began to vex him.

Vexation.definition: The state of being annoyed, frustrated, or worried.
Vexation.example: In his vexation, he slammed the door shut.

Viable.example: The committee searched for a viable solution to the budget crisis.

Vicarious.definition: Experienced in the imagination through the feelings or actions of another person.
Vicarious.example: She took vicarious pleasure in her friend's travel stories.

Vicissitude.definition: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.
Vicissitude.example: He faced the vicissitudes of life with unwavering optimism.

Victual.example: The explorers packed enough victuals for a month-long journey.

Vigilant.definition: Keeping careful watch for possible danger or difficulties.
Vigilant.example: The security guard remained vigilant throughout the night.

Vignette.definition: A brief evocative description, account, or episode.
Vignette.example: The book is a series of vignettes about life in a small town.

Vigor.example: He tackled the project with renewed vigor after a good night's sleep.

Vilify.definition: To speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner.
Vilify.example: The politician's opponents tried to vilify him in the press.

Vindicate.definition: To clear someone of blame or suspicion.
Vindicate.example: The new evidence served to vindicate the wrongly accused man.

Vindictive.definition: Having or showing a strong or unreasoning desire for revenge.
Vindictive.example: The vindictive ex-employee spread false rumors about the company.

Virago.definition: A domineering, violent, or bad-tempered woman.
Virago.example: The neighborhood children were terrified of the old virago who lived on the corner.

Viridescent.example: The viridescent hue of the copper statue was caused by years of oxidation.

Virile.definition: Having strength, energy, and a strong sex drive (typically used of a man).
Virile.example: The actor was known for playing virile, heroic roles.

Virtuoso.definition: A person highly skilled in music or another artistic pursuit.
Virtuoso.example: He was a violin virtuoso, known for his incredible technical skill.

Virtuous.definition: Having or showing high moral standards.
Virtuous.example: She was known for her virtuous character and charitable work.

Virulent.definition: Extremely severe or harmful in its effects; bitterly hostile.
Virulent.example: The virulent strain of the flu spread rapidly through the community.

Visage.definition: A person's face, with reference to the form or proportions of the features.
Visage.example: His smiling visage was a welcome sight.

Visceral.definition: Relating to deep inward feelings rather than to the intellect.
Visceral.example: Her decision to quit her job was visceral; it just felt right.

Viscid.definition: Having a glutinous or sticky consistency.
Viscid.example: The viscid sap from the pine tree stuck to his hands.

Viscous.definition: Having a thick, sticky consistency between solid and liquid.
Viscous.example: Honey is a viscous liquid that pours slowly.

Visionary.definition: Thinking about or planning the future with imagination or wisdom.
Visionary.example: Steve Jobs was a visionary who revolutionized the tech industry.

Vitiate.definition: To spoil or impair the quality or efficiency of.
Vitiate.example: Fraudulent votes can vitiate the results of an election.

Vitreous.definition: Like glass in appearance or physical properties.
Vitreous.example: The pottery had a smooth, vitreous glaze.

Vitriolic.definition: Filled with bitter criticism or malice.
Vitriolic.example: The critic's review was a vitriolic attack on the new film.

Vituperate.definition: To blame or insult (someone) in strong or violent language.
Vituperate.example: The angry customer began to vituperate the manager over a minor mistake.

Vivacious.example: Her vivacious personality made her the life of the party.

Vivify.example: A splash of bright paint can vivify a dull room.

Vociferous.definition: Expressing or characterized by vehement opinions; loud and forceful.
Vociferous.example: The vociferous protestors demanded immediate action from the government.

Void.definition: Not valid or legally binding; completely empty.
Void.example: The contract was declared null and void.

Volition.definition: The faculty or power of using one's will.
Volition.example: He left the company of his own volition.

Voluble.definition: Speaking or spoken incessantly and fluently.
Voluble.example: The voluble tour guide chattered on for hours about the city's history.

Voluminous.definition: Occupying or containing much space; large in volume.
Voluminous.example: She gathered her voluminous skirts as she climbed the stairs.

Voluptuous.definition: Relating to or characterized by luxury or sensual pleasure.
Voluptuous.example: The painting depicted a voluptuous feast in a grand hall.

Voracious.definition: Wanting or devouring great quantities of food; having a very eager approach to an activity.
Voracious.example: He was a voracious reader, often finishing several books a week.

Vortex.definition: A mass of whirling fluid or air, especially a whirlpool or whirlwind.
Vortex.example: The boat was caught in a powerful vortex and began to spin.

Votary.definition: A person who has made vows of dedication to a cause or religious service; a devoted follower.
Votary.example: He was a votary of minimalist design, believing less is more.

Vouchsafe.definition: To give or grant (something) to (someone) in a gracious or condescending manner.
Vouchsafe.example: He would not vouchsafe a reply to my question.

Voyeur.definition: A person who gains pleasure from watching others' private lives.
Voyeur.example: The celebrity felt like her life was constantly being observed by voyeurs.

Vulgar.definition: Lacking sophistication or good taste; unrefined.
Vulgar.example: His vulgar jokes were inappropriate for the formal dinner.

Vulnerable.definition: Susceptible to physical or emotional attack or harm.
Vulnerable.example: The young birds are vulnerable to predators.

Vulpine.definition: Relating to a fox or foxes; crafty; cunning.
Vulpine.example: He had a vulpine grin that suggested he was up to no good.

Vanguard.definition: A group of people leading the way in new developments or ideas.
Vanguard.example: The tech company was in the vanguard of artificial intelligence research.

Vanity.definition: Excessive pride in or admiration of one's own appearance or achievements.
Vanity.example: His vanity was such that he couldn't pass a mirror without looking at his reflection.

Vantage.definition: A place or position affording a good view of something.
Vantage.example: From our vantage point on the hill, we could see the entire city.

Vassal.definition: A person or country in a subordinate position to another.
Vassal.example: The smaller kingdom was a vassal to the powerful empire.

Vaunt-courier.example: The dark clouds were the vaunt-couriers of the coming storm.

Vaticinate.example: The ancient seer was said to vaticinate the futures of kings.

Vaudeville.definition: A type of entertainment featuring a mixture of specialty acts.
Vaudeville.example: His grandfather had been a performer in the golden age of vaudeville.

Veer.example: The car veered off the road to avoid hitting the deer.

Vegetate.definition: To live or spend a period of time in a dull, inactive, and unchallenging way.
Vegetate.example: After his exams, he just wanted to vegetate on the couch for a week.

Velleity.definition: A mere wish, unaccompanied by an effort to obtain.
Velleity.example: His desire to learn piano was only a velleity, as he never bought a keyboard or took a lesson.

Venation.definition: The arrangement of veins in a leaf or in an insect's wing.
Venation.example: The botanist studied the unique venation of the newly discovered plant.

Vendetta.definition: A blood feud in which a family seeks vengeance on another.
Vendetta.example: The two families had been engaged in a bitter vendetta for generations.

Veneer.definition: A thin decorative covering of fine wood; an attractive but deceptive outer layer.
Veneer.example: Beneath his veneer of confidence, he was actually very insecure.

Verdure.example: The landscape was a tapestry of rich verdure.

Veridical.example: While his dream felt real, it was not a veridical experience.

Vermicular.definition: Resembling a worm in form or movement.
Vermicular.example: The clay squeezed through his fingers in vermicular shapes.

Vestry.definition: A room in a church used as an office or for changing into vestments.
Vestry.example: The choir assembled in the vestry before the service.

Vexillology.example: His interest in vexillology led him to collect flags from every country he visited.

Viand.example: The banquet table was laden with all manner of delicious viands.

Vicariate.definition: The office or authority of a vicar.
Vicariate.example: He was appointed to the vicariate of the northern diocese.

Vigesimal.definition: Relating to or based on the number twenty.
Vigesimal.example: The ancient Mayan civilization used a vigesimal number system.

Vindicatory.definition: Serving to vindicate, justify, or defend.
Vindicatory.example: He presented vindicatory evidence that cleared his client of all charges.

Vinaceous.definition: Of the color of red wine.
Vinaceous.example: The sunset painted the clouds in vinaceous and orange hues.

Virtu.definition: Knowledge of or expertise in the fine arts.
Virtu.example: The collector was a man of great virtu and had an impressive art collection.

Waggish.definition: Humorous in a playful, mischievous, or facetious manner.
Waggish.example: His waggish comments during the serious meeting were not appreciated by the board.

Wallow.definition: To indulge in an unrestrained way in something that creates a pleasurable sensation, typically self-pity or grief.
Wallow.example: After his breakup, he decided to wallow in self-pity for a few days before moving on.

Wan.definition: Pale and giving the impression of illness or exhaustion.
Wan.example: After pulling an all-nighter to study, her face was wan and her eyes were heavy.

Wane.definition: To decrease in vigor, power, or extent; to become weaker.
Wane.example: The public's interest in the celebrity scandal began to wane after a few weeks.

Wanton.definition: Deliberate and unprovoked cruelty, destruction, or violence.
Wanton.example: The wanton destruction of the historical monument was a tragedy for the entire nation.

Warble.definition: To sing in a trilling or quavering voice.
Warble.example: We woke to the sound of birds warbling outside our window.

Warmonger.definition: A person who encourages or advocates aggression or war towards other countries or groups.
Warmonger.example: The politician was accused of being a warmonger for his aggressive foreign policy rhetoric.

Warrant.definition: To justify or necessitate a particular course of action.
Warrant.example: The severity of the crime does not warrant such a harsh punishment.

Wary.definition: Feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems.
Wary.example: After being scammed once, she was wary of any unsolicited emails promising wealth.

Wassail.definition: A festive occasion with drinking; to drink plentiful amounts of alcohol and enjoy oneself with others in a noisy, lively way.
Wassail.example: The medieval festival concluded with a great wassail in the lord's hall.

Wastrel.example: He was a known wastrel who spent his inheritance on frivolous luxuries.

Watershed.definition: An event or period marking a turning point in a course of action or state of affairs.
Watershed.example: The invention of the internet was a watershed moment for communication and commerce.

Waver.definition: To be undecided between two opinions or courses of action; to be irresolute.
Waver.example: His confidence began to waver as the opposing lawyer presented damning evidence.

Wax.definition: To become larger or stronger; to increase in size, numbers, strength, prosperity, or intensity.
Wax.example: Her enthusiasm for the project began to wax as she saw the positive results.

Waylay.definition: To stop or interrupt someone and detain them in conversation or trouble them in some other way.
Waylay.example: The reporter would often waylay politicians in the hallway to ask them tough questions.

Wayward.definition: Difficult to control or predict because of unusual or perverse behavior.
Wayward.example: The wayward teenager constantly disobeyed his parents and school rules.

Wean.definition: To accustom someone to managing without something on which they have become dependent.
Wean.example: The government is trying to wean the economy off its dependence on oil.

Wearisome.definition: Causing one to feel tired or bored.
Wearisome.example: The long, wearisome journey seemed to have no end.

Weather.definition: To withstand a difficulty or storm.
Weather.example: The small company managed to weather the economic recession better than its larger competitors.

Welter.definition: A large number of items in no order; a confused mass.
Welter.example: His desk was a welter of papers, books, and old coffee mugs.

Weltschmerz.definition: A feeling of melancholy and world-weariness.
Weltschmerz.example: The poet's work is filled with a sense of Weltschmerz, lamenting the imperfect state of the world.

Wheedle.definition: To use flattery or coaxing in order to persuade someone to do something.
Wheedle.example: She managed to wheedle the secret recipe out of her grandmother.

Whet.definition: To excite or stimulate someone's desire, interest, or appetite.
Whet.example: The trailer for the new movie was designed to whet the audience's appetite for adventure.

Wherewithal.definition: The money or other means needed for a particular purpose.
Wherewithal.example: He wanted to start his own business but lacked the financial wherewithal.

Whimsical.definition: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing and amusing way.
Whimsical.example: The author is known for her whimsical stories featuring talking animals and magical lands.

Whittle.definition: To reduce something in size, amount, or extent by a gradual series of steps.
Whittle.example: The negotiators tried to whittle down the demands to a more manageable list.

Wholehearted.example: She gave her wholehearted support to the campaign for environmental protection.

Wield.definition: To hold and use a weapon or tool; to have and be able to use power or influence.
Wield.example: The CEO wields enormous power within the company.

Willful.definition: Having or showing a stubborn and determined intention to do as one wants, regardless of the consequences.
Willful.example: His willful disregard for the rules eventually got him expelled.

Willowy.example: The willowy ballet dancer moved across the stage with effortless grace.

Wily.definition: Skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully.
Wily.example: The wily fox managed to outsmart the hunters yet again.

Wince.definition: To give a slight involuntary grimace or shrinking movement of the body out of pain or distress.
Wince.example: He could not help but wince as the doctor cleaned the wound.

Windfall.definition: An unexpected gain, piece of good fortune, or profit.
Windfall.example: The small inheritance was a welcome windfall for the struggling family.

Winnow.definition: To sift through something to remove undesirable elements; to separate the good from the bad.
Winnow.example: The selection committee had to winnow a long list of applicants down to just five.

Winsome.definition: Attractive or appealing in a fresh, innocent way.
Winsome.example: With her winsome smile and cheerful personality, she quickly made friends.

Wiry.example: The wiry marathon runner had incredible stamina.

Wistful.definition: Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.
Wistful.example: She had a wistful look on her face as she remembered her childhood summers.

Withhold.definition: To refuse to give something that is due to or desired by another.
Withhold.example: The company decided to withhold bonuses until the end of the fiscal year.

Wizened.example: The old sailor had a wizened face, weathered by years of sun and sea.

Woebegone.example: The lost child had a woebegone expression on his face.

Wont.definition: One's customary behavior in a particular situation.
Wont.example: As was his wont, the professor arrived exactly on time for the lecture.

Workmanlike.definition: Showing competent and skillful work but not necessarily brilliant or inspired.
Workmanlike.example: He gave a workmanlike performance, hitting all his notes but lacking emotional depth.

Worldly.definition: Experienced and sophisticated; concerned with material values rather than a spiritual existence.
Worldly.example: After traveling for years, she had a very worldly perspective on life.

Worsted.definition: To get the better of; to defeat.
Worsted.example: In the final debate, the incumbent was worsted by the challenger's sharp wit.

Wrack.definition: To cause extreme pain, anguish, or distress to.
Wrack.example: He was wracked with guilt over his decision.

Wrangle.definition: To have a long and complicated dispute or argument.
Wrangle.example: The siblings would often wrangle over who got to use the car.

Wrath.example: She incurred the wrath of her boss by missing the critical deadline.

Wreak.definition: To cause a large amount of damage or harm.
Wreak.example: The hurricane is expected to wreak havoc on the coastal towns.

Wrest.definition: To forcibly pull something from a person's grasp.
Wrest.example: She managed to wrest the knife from her attacker's hand.

Writ.definition: A form of written command in the name of a court or other legal authority to act, or abstain from acting, in some way.
Writ.example: The court issued a writ of habeas corpus, demanding the prisoner be brought before them.

Writhe.definition: To make continual twisting, squirming movements or contortions of the body.
Writhe.example: The patient was writhing in agony on the hospital bed.

Wrongheaded.definition: Having or showing bad judgment; misguided.
Wrongheaded.example: His wrongheaded belief that he could fix the engine himself resulted in a much larger repair bill.

Wrought.definition: Beaten out or shaped by hammering; made or created.
Wrought.example: The finely wrought iron gates were a testament to the blacksmith's skill.

Wry.definition: Using or expressing dry, especially mocking, humor.
Wry.example: He gave a wry smile when he heard the ironic news.

Wake.definition: The aftermath or consequences of an event.
Wake.example: In the wake of the scandal, the company's stock price plummeted.

Wanderlust.example: Her wanderlust was insatiable; she was always planning her next trip.

War-horse.definition: A person with long experience in a field; a veteran.
War-horse.example: The old war-horse of the political scene knew exactly how to handle the press.

Warrantless.definition: Not having or requiring a legal warrant.
Warrantless.example: The defense argued that the warrantless search of the vehicle was unconstitutional.

Watchword.definition: A word or phrase expressing a principle or rule of a person or group.
Watchword.example: Efficiency became the watchword of the new management team.

Waxen.definition: Having a smooth, pale, translucent surface or appearance like wax.
Waxen.example: In the dim light of the morgue, the body had a still, waxen quality.

Weighty.example: The council had to make a weighty decision about the future of the town's library.

Well-disposed.definition: Having a positive, sympathetic, or friendly attitude towards someone or something.
Well-disposed.example: The judge seemed well-disposed towards the defendant's plea for leniency.

Well-founded.definition: Based on good evidence or reasons.
Well-founded.example: Her fears about the company's financial stability were well-founded.

Well-nigh.example: After the grueling hike, he was well-nigh exhausted.

Wellspring.definition: An original and bountiful source of something.
Wellspring.example: His grandmother's stories were a wellspring of inspiration for his novels.

Wherefore.example: O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?

Whit.definition: A very small part or amount.
Whit.example: I don't care one whit about his opinion on the matter.

Whitewash.definition: To deliberately attempt to conceal unpleasant facts about a person or organization.
Whitewash.example: The official report was accused of being a whitewash that ignored the company's negligence.

Whorl.definition: A pattern of spirals or concentric circles.
Whorl.example: The detective noticed the distinct whorl of the fingerprint left on the glass.

Wildcatter.definition: One who drills for oil or gas in an area not known to be a field.
Wildcatter.example: The old wildcatter risked his life savings on the hope of striking oil.

Will-o'-the-wisp.definition: A delusive or elusive goal or hope.
Will-o'-the-wisp.example: His dream of becoming a famous actor was a will-o'-the-wisp he chased for years.

Wizen.definition: To cause to shrivel or wrinkle.
Wizen.example: The relentless sun will wizen the fruit on the vine if it is not picked soon.

Windbag.definition: A person who talks at length but says little of value.
Windbag.example: I tried to avoid my neighbor, a notorious windbag who could talk for hours about nothing.

Wisecrack.definition: A clever and pithy, often sarcastic, remark.
Wisecrack.example: He couldn't resist making a wisecrack about the terrible food.

Wispy.example: A few wispy clouds drifted across the bright blue sky.

Wit.definition: The capacity for inventive thought and quick understanding; keen intelligence.
Wit.example: Her sharp wit made her a formidable opponent in any debate.

Witchery.definition: Powerful or fascinating influence or charm.
Witchery.example: He was completely captivated by the witchery of her voice.

Withal.definition: In addition; as a further factor or consideration.
Withal.example: He was a stern man, but a just one withal.

Wither.definition: To cause someone to feel humiliated or mortified; to become dry and shriveled.
Wither.example: She gave him a withering look that silenced him immediately.

Withstand.definition: To remain undamaged or unaffected by; to resist.
Withstand.example: The ancient castle was built to withstand a siege.

Witticism.example: Mark Twain was famous for his clever witticisms.

Wittingly.example: He would never wittingly harm another person.

Woe.example: The city's tale is one of triumph and woe.

Womanize.definition: (Of a man) to engage in numerous casual sexual relationships with women.
Womanize.example: His reputation for womanizing made him an unpopular choice for a serious relationship.

Woo.definition: To try to gain the love or favor of someone.
Woo.example: The company is trying to woo talented graduates with high salaries and excellent benefits.

Wordsmith.example: As a professional wordsmith, the journalist could craft a compelling story from any set of facts.

Workaday.definition: Not special, unusual, or exciting; ordinary.
Workaday.example: He longed for an escape from his mundane, workaday life.

Worm.definition: To obtain something by cunning or devious means.
Worm.example: He managed to worm his way into the exclusive club.

Worshipful.definition: Feeling or showing reverent honor and homage.
Worshipful.example: The fans had a worshipful admiration for the rock star.

Worthy.definition: Having or showing the qualities or abilities that merit recognition.
Worthy.example: The charity is a worthy cause that deserves our full support.

Wound.definition: To wrap or coil something around itself or something else (pronounced to rhyme with 'sound').
Wound.example: She wound the scarf tightly around her neck to protect against the cold.

Wraith.definition: A ghost or ghostlike image of someone, especially one seen shortly before or after their death.
Wraith.example: In the moonlight, the pale, thin figure looked like a wraith.

Wrenching.definition: Causing great mental or physical pain.
Wrenching.example: Saying goodbye to his family was a wrenching experience.

Wrinkle.definition: A clever trick or new method.
Wrinkle.example: The latest wrinkle in online marketing is the use of AI-generated influencers.

Wrongdoing.example: The investigation uncovered evidence of corporate wrongdoing.

Wryly.definition: In a way that expresses dry, especially mocking, humor.
Wryly.example: 'How very original,' he said wryly, looking at her clichd painting.

Wunderkind.definition: A person who achieves great success when relatively young.
Wunderkind.example: The tech industry is full of stories about a wunderkind who dropped out of college to start a billion-dollar company.

Xanthate.definition: A salt or ester of xanthic acid, often used in industrial processes like mining.
Xanthate.example: The mining company used a xanthate solution to separate valuable minerals from the ore.

Xanthein.definition: A water-soluble yellow pigment found in the cell sap of yellow flowers.
Xanthein.example: The bright yellow of the sunflower petal is due to the presence of xanthein.

Xanthic.definition: Having a yellowish color or relating to xanthine, a substance found in most body tissues and fluids.
Xanthic.example: The ancient manuscript had developed a xanthic tinge over the centuries.

Xanthippe.definition: An ill-tempered, scolding, or shrewish woman, named after the wife of the ancient Greek philosopher Socrates.
Xanthippe.example: His colleagues referred to the notoriously difficult manager as a modern-day Xanthippe.

Xanthocarpous.example: The botanist identified the rare, xanthocarpous shrub by its distinctive golden berries.

Xanthochroid.definition: Pertaining to individuals with fair skin and light-colored hair.
Xanthochroid.example: In the 19th century, anthropologists used terms like 'xanthochroid' to classify human populations.

Xanthocomous.example: The xanthocomous child stood out in the family of brunettes.

Xanthocyanopsy.definition: A form of color blindness in which only yellow and blue can be distinguished.
Xanthocyanopsy.example: Living with xanthocyanopsy, he perceived the world in a unique palette of blues, yellows, and grays.

Xanthoderma.definition: A condition characterized by a yellowish discoloration of the skin.
Xanthoderma.example: Excessive consumption of carotene-rich foods can sometimes lead to a harmless condition called xanthoderma.

Xanthodont.example: The paleontologist noted that the fossil belonged to a xanthodont species.

Xanthophyll.definition: A yellow or brownish-yellow carotenoid pigment that imparts the autumn colors to leaves.
Xanthophyll.example: In the fall, as chlorophyll breaks down, the underlying xanthophyll pigments become visible in the leaves.

Xanthopsia.definition: A visual defect in which objects appear to have a yellowish hue, sometimes a side effect of certain medications.
Xanthopsia.example: After taking the medication, the patient reported experiencing xanthopsia, making the white walls appear cream-colored.

Xanthosis.definition: A yellowish discoloration of degenerating tissues, especially in cancer.
Xanthosis.example: The pathologist observed xanthosis in the tissue sample under the microscope.

Xanthous.definition: Of a yellow or yellowish color.
Xanthous.example: The artist used a xanthous pigment to capture the warm glow of the sunset.

Xebec.definition: A small, three-masted sailing vessel with a distinctive hull, once common in the Mediterranean.
Xebec.example: Pirates favored the fast and maneuverable xebec for their raids along the coast.

Xenial.definition: Relating to hospitality or the friendly relationship between a host and a guest.
Xenial.example: The innkeeper was known for his xenial nature, always making travelers feel welcome.

Xenobiotic.definition: A chemical substance, such as a drug or pesticide, that is foreign to a living organism's biological system.
Xenobiotic.example: The liver plays a crucial role in metabolizing and eliminating xenobiotic compounds from the body.

Xenocentrism.definition: The preference for the products, styles, or ideas of another culture over those of one's own.
Xenocentrism.example: His xenocentrism was so pronounced that he refused to buy domestic products, believing foreign goods were always superior.

Xenocryst.definition: A crystal in an igneous rock that is not derived from the original magma from which the rock crystallized.
Xenocryst.example: The geologist identified a quartz xenocryst within the basalt, indicating it was incorporated from the surrounding rock.

Xenocracy.definition: Government by a body of foreigners.
Xenocracy.example: The local population resented the xenocracy imposed upon them after the invasion.

Xenodiagnosis.definition: A method for diagnosing a disease by using a laboratory-bred vector to pick up the parasite from the patient.
Xenodiagnosis.example: Xenodiagnosis for Chagas disease involves allowing an uninfected insect to feed on the patient and then examining the insect for the parasite.

Xenodochium.definition: In medieval times, a guesthouse or hospice for pilgrims or strangers.
Xenodochium.example: The monastery maintained a xenodochium to provide shelter for weary travelers.

Xenodochial.example: The remote village was known for its xenodochial inhabitants who warmly welcomed visitors.

Xenodochy.definition: The act of extending hospitality to strangers.
Xenodochy.example: Ancient traditions of xenodochy ensured that travelers could find food and lodging in foreign lands.

Xenogeneic.definition: Originating from or derived from an individual of a different species.
Xenogeneic.example: A xenogeneic transplant carries a high risk of rejection by the recipient's immune system.

Xenogenesis.definition: The supposed generation of an offspring that is completely different from its parents.
Xenogenesis.example: The concept of xenogenesis, such as a dog giving birth to a cat, belongs to the realm of fantasy, not biology.

Xenoglossia.definition: The supposed paranormal ability to speak a language that one has never learned.
Xenoglossia.example: Claims of xenoglossia are often met with skepticism from linguists and scientists.

Xenograft.definition: A tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species from the recipient.
Xenograft.example: Pig heart valves are sometimes used as xenografts in human cardiac surgery.

Xenolatry.definition: The worship of foreign gods or deities.
Xenolatry.example: The historian wrote about the ancient civilization's practice of xenolatry, incorporating gods from neighboring cultures.

Xenolith.definition: A piece of rock foreign to the igneous rock body in which it is embedded.
Xenolith.example: The granite contained a dark xenolith, a remnant of the rock that the magma had intruded.

Xenology.definition: The scientific study of extraterrestrial life, customs, and biology; a speculative field.
Xenology.example: Science fiction authors often explore complex themes of xenology in their stories about first contact.

Xenomania.definition: An obsessive enthusiasm for foreign things, such as customs, styles, or people.
Xenomania.example: His xenomania led him to decorate his entire house in a Japanese style, despite never having visited Japan.

Xenomancy.definition: A form of divination that uses the appearance or behavior of the first stranger one meets.
Xenomancy.example: The ancient seer practiced xenomancy, interpreting omens from the words of passing travelers.

Xenomorphic.definition: Having a form that is strange or foreign to its environment; in geology, having a crystal form not its own.
Xenomorphic.example: The xenomorphic crystals had irregular shapes because their growth was impeded by adjacent minerals.

Xenophile.definition: A person who is attracted to foreign peoples, cultures, or customs.
Xenophile.example: As a true xenophile, she loved traveling, learning new languages, and trying exotic foods.

Xenophilia.definition: A strong attraction to or admiration for foreign people, manners, or cultures.
Xenophilia.example: The country's growing xenophilia was evident in its embrace of international music, fashion, and cuisine.

Xenophobe.definition: A person who has an intense or irrational fear or hatred of foreigners.
Xenophobe.example: The xenophobe was suspicious of anyone who did not share his nationality and customs.

Xenophobia.definition: An intense or irrational dislike or fear of people from other countries.
Xenophobia.example: The politician's speech was criticized for promoting xenophobia and division.

Xenophonic.definition: Relating to or having the characteristics of a foreign or alien sound.
Xenophonic.example: The electronic music composer was known for his xenophonic soundscapes that felt truly otherworldly.

Xenops.definition: A genus of small, tropical birds found in rainforests, known for their unique bill shape.
Xenops.example: The birdwatcher was thrilled to spot a Plain Xenops foraging on a tree trunk.

Xenotransplantation.definition: The process of grafting or transplanting organs or tissues between members of different species.
Xenotransplantation.example: Research into xenotransplantation offers hope for solving the shortage of human donor organs.

Xeranthemum.definition: A type of plant, also known as an 'everlasting flower', that can be dried without losing its form or color.
Xeranthemum.example: She made a beautiful dried arrangement using xeranthemum and lavender.

Xerarch.definition: Describing an ecological succession that begins in a dry habitat.
Xerarch.example: The colonization of a sand dune by plants is a classic example of a xerarch succession.

Xerasia.definition: A medical condition characterized by abnormal dryness of the hair, making it brittle and lusterless.
Xerasia.example: The dermatologist diagnosed her with xerasia and recommended specialized moisturizing treatments.

Xeric.definition: Relating to, or adapted to an extremely dry environment.
Xeric.example: Cacti and succulents are xeric plants that thrive in the desert.

Xeriscape.definition: A landscaping method that uses drought-resistant plants to minimize water usage.
Xeriscape.example: To conserve water during the drought, many residents converted their lawns to xeriscapes.

Xerocline.definition: A gradient in environmental conditions from a drier area to a wetter one.
Xerocline.example: The ecologists studied the changing plant communities along the xerocline from the ridge to the valley.

Xerocolous.definition: Inhabiting a desert or other dry region.
Xerocolous.example: The camel is a well-known xerocolous animal, perfectly adapted to its arid environment.

Xerocopy.definition: A photocopy made using a dry, electrostatic process.
Xerocopy.example: Please make a xerocopy of this document for the meeting.

Xeroderma.definition: A skin condition characterized by abnormal dryness, roughness, and scaling.
Xeroderma.example: He used a heavy moisturizer to manage his xeroderma, especially during the dry winter months.

Xerodermia.definition: An alternative term for xeroderma, meaning abnormal dryness of the skin.
Xerodermia.example: The patient's symptoms included mild xerodermia and itching.

Xerography.definition: A dry copying process in which electrically charged powder is fused onto paper to form an image.
Xerography.example: The invention of xerography by Chester Carlson revolutionized office work.

Xeroloma.definition: A genus of fungi characterized by a dry, cracked cap surface.
Xeroloma.example: The mycologist identified the mushroom as a species of Xeroloma.

Xeroma.definition: An abnormal dryness of the conjunctiva, the membrane lining the eyelid and eyeball.
Xeroma.example: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to xeroma and other serious eye conditions.

Xerophagy.definition: The practice of eating only dry foods, such as bread and nuts, especially as a form of religious fasting.
Xerophagy.example: During Lent, some early Christians practiced xerophagy as a sign of penance.

Xerophilous.definition: Adapted to or thriving in a very dry climate; drought-loving.
Xerophilous.example: The desert is home to many xerophilous plants and animals.

Xerophyte.definition: A plant adapted to survive in an environment with little liquid water, such as a desert.
Xerophyte.example: The cactus is a classic xerophyte, storing water in its fleshy stem.

Xerophthalmia.definition: Abnormal dryness of the cornea and conjunctiva of the eye, often caused by a vitamin A deficiency.
Xerophthalmia.example: International health organizations work to prevent xerophthalmia in developing countries.

Xeroradiography.definition: A type of X-ray imaging that uses xerographic principles to produce an image on paper rather than film.
Xeroradiography.example: Before digital imaging, xeroradiography was used for certain types of medical diagnostics.

Xerosis.definition: Abnormal dryness of a body part or tissue, such as skin, eyes, or mucous membranes.
Xerosis.example: The elderly patient suffered from xerosis, which made his skin prone to cracking.

Xerostomia.definition: The medical term for a dry mouth, resulting from reduced or absent saliva flow.
Xerostomia.example: Xerostomia is a common side effect of many medications.

Xerothermic.definition: Relating to or characteristic of a climate that is both hot and dry.
Xerothermic.example: The Mediterranean region has a xerothermic climate, with long, dry summers.

Xerotripsis.definition: The act of rubbing a part of the body with a dry, stimulating substance; dry friction.
Xerotripsis.example: In ancient medicine, xerotripsis was a therapeutic technique used to invigorate the skin.

Xilinous.definition: Of, relating to, or resembling cotton.
Xilinous.example: The fabric had a soft, xilinous texture.

Xiphias.definition: The genus of billfishes that includes the swordfish.
Xiphias.example: The scientific name for the swordfish is Xiphias gladius.

Xiphisterum.definition: The xiphoid process, the cartilaginous section at the lower end of the sternum.
Xiphisterum.example: The doctor located the xiphisterum to begin chest compressions.

Xiphoid.definition: Shaped like a sword; relating to the cartilage at the lower end of the breastbone (sternum).
Xiphoid.example: Care must be taken during CPR not to apply pressure directly to the xiphoid process.

Xiphoidian.definition: Relating to or in the region of the xiphoid process.
Xiphoidian.example: The patient complained of a sharp, xiphoidian pain.

Xiphophyllous.definition: Having leaves that are shaped like a sword.
Xiphophyllous.example: The yucca plant is xiphophyllous, with long, sharp leaves.

Xiphopagus.definition: Conjoined twins who are united at the xiphoid process of the sternum.
Xiphopagus.example: The surgical separation of xiphopagus twins is a highly complex procedure.

Xiphosuran.definition: An aquatic arthropod of the class Xiphosura, which includes the horseshoe crabs.
Xiphosuran.example: The xiphosuran is often called a 'living fossil' because it has changed little over millions of years.

Xylal.definition: A type of sweet, syrupy alcohol derived from xylose.
Xylal.example: In the chemistry lab, they synthesized xylal as part of their experiment on sugar alcohols.

Xylan.definition: A complex carbohydrate (hemicellulose) found in plant cell walls and some algae.
Xylan.example: Industrial processes can break down xylan from agricultural waste to produce biofuels.

Xylem.definition: The vascular tissue in plants that conducts water and dissolved nutrients upward from the root and also helps to form the woody element in the stem.
Xylem.example: The rings of a tree are composed of old xylem tissue.

Xylenol.definition: A chemical compound derived from xylene, used as a disinfectant and in the manufacturing of plastics.
Xylenol.example: Xylenol is the active ingredient in some antiseptic cleaning solutions.

Xylidine.definition: An amine derivative of xylene, used in the production of dyes and pharmaceuticals.
Xylidine.example: The factory produced xylidine as a key component for a new class of pigments.

Xylocarp.definition: A fruit that has a hard, woody pericarp (the part of the fruit enclosing the seeds), such as a coconut.
Xylocarp.example: The coconut is a well-known example of a xylocarp.

Xylocarpous.definition: Bearing a hard and woody fruit.
Xylocarpous.example: The botanist classified the tree as xylocarpous after examining its tough, nut-like fruit.

Xylogen.definition: The nascent woody tissue in plants; the substance that develops into xylem.
Xylogen.example: The cambium layer produces xylogen, which differentiates into mature wood.

Xylograph.definition: An engraving made on a block of wood, or a print made from such an engraving.
Xylograph.example: The museum displayed a 15th-century xylograph depicting a religious scene.

Xylographer.definition: A person who practices the art of wood engraving.
Xylographer.example: The skilled xylographer spent weeks carving the intricate design into the woodblock.

Xylographic.definition: Relating to the art of wood engraving or printing from woodblocks.
Xylographic.example: Early books were often illustrated with simple xylographic prints.

Xylography.definition: The art of engraving on wood, especially for the purpose of printing.
Xylography.example: Xylography was a common method of book illustration before the development of metal engraving.

Xyloid.definition: Having the nature of or resembling wood; woody.
Xyloid.example: The fossilized plant had a xyloid texture, perfectly preserving its woody structure.

Xylol.definition: A volatile liquid hydrocarbon, commonly known as xylene, used as a solvent in laboratories and industries.
Xylol.example: The technician used xylol to clear the wax from the tissue samples before staining.
